C. Signatures On Certificates: The above certificates of compliance shall be signed by the mayor or city clerk. (1991 Code § 2-5; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-
2013)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 2018-04 - OCCUPATION TAXES . Go to new ordinance.
4-1-7: LICENSE FOR THE SALE AND SERVING OF ALCOHOL AND/OR 3.2 BEER:
A. License Required:
1. License Application: It shall be unlawful for any business, vendor or person within the city of Skiatook to serve, sell or offer for sale alcohol and/or 3.2
beer without a license issued by the city of Skiatook as hereinafter provided. Every vendor desiring to engage in business as a retail vendor serving
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 35/269
or selling alcohol and/or 3.2 beer, or to continue operating as a vendor selling or serving alcohol and/or 3.2 beer within the city of Skiatook if doing so
at the time this section is adopted, shall make application to the city clerk on forms available in the office of the city clerk. A license shall be issued to
each vendor whose application is approved.
2. Suspension Or Revocation Of License: The license granted by the city of Skiatook shall at all times be displayed in public view in the vendor's place
of business. This license may be suspended or revoked as provided herein if the vendor, or any person or agent employed by the vendor or acting
on the vendor's behalf, is convicted of the offense of selling or serving alcohol to a minor, or enters into a plea bargain agreement after being
charged with such offense. "Conviction" throughout this section shall be deemed to include entry of a guilty or nolo contendere plea by any person
charged with selling or serving alcohol and/or 3.2 beer to a minor. Each vendor making application for a license under this section shall expressly
acknowledge the vendor's awareness that a license granted pursuant to this section may be suspended or revoked by the city of Skiatook if an
owner, officer, director, manager, employee or agent of the vendor is either convicted of selling or serving alcohol and/or 3.2 beer to a minor on the
vendor's behalf or enters into a plea bargain agreement after being charged with such offense. It shall not be a defense under this section for a
vendor to assert or claim that an employee or agent of the vendor unlawfully sold or served alcohol and/or 3.2 beer to a minor contrary to the
vendor's rules, policies, procedures or training. Assertion of such a defense will not prevent the vendor's license from the penalties set forth in
subsection H of this section.
3. Acknowledgment Of Compliance Checks: A vendor shall specifically acknowledge awareness on the license application submitted to the city of
Skiatook that alcohol compliance checks are performed on a regular and ongoing basis in the community by law enforcement, and shall further
acknowledge the vendor's consent to such compliance checks as a necessary condition of obtaining and retaining a license from the city of Skiatook
under this section. The vendor shall also acknowledge on the application its awareness that conviction of the vendor's employee or agent for the
offense of selling or serving alcohol and/or 3.2 beer to a minor, or the acceptance of a plea bargain agreement by the employee or agent after being
charged with such offense, will result in suspension or revocation of the vendor's license as provided in subsection H of this section.
B. License Fee:
1. Alcohol And/Or 3.2 Beer Not To Be Consumed On The Vendor's Premises: An annual fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be paid by a vendor to the city
of Skiatook if the vendor intends to sell alcohol and/or 3.2 beer which is not intended to be consumed on the vendor's premises. This fee shall be
paid when the vendor's application for a license is submitted to the city clerk. Licenses under this section shall be granted for a calendar year from
January 1 through December 31. The license fee for an initial license shall be prorated if such license is granted for less than a full calendar year.
The fee for annual license renewals shall not be prorated.
2. Alcohol And/Or 3.2 Beer Which Is Intended To Be Consumed On The Vendor's Premises: An annual license fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be
paid by a vendor to the city of Skiatook if the vendor intends to sell or serve alcohol and/or 3.2 beer which is intended to be consumed on the
vendor's premises. This fee shall be paid when the vendor's application for a license is submitted to the city clerk. Licenses under this section shall
be granted for a calendar year from January 1 through December 31. The license fee for an initial license shall be prorated if granted for a period of
time less than a full calendar year. The fee for annual license renewals shall not be prorated regardless of when the application for annual renewal is
filed.
C. License Application: Application for a license to sell or serve alcohol and/or 3.2 beer by a vendor located within the city of Skiatook shall be made by
completing and submitting the application form to the city clerk. The form shall include the vendor's business name, the owner's name and address if
the business is a sole proprietorship, the name of the president and all other officers and directors if the business is a corporation, and the names of all
partners or members if the vendor is a partnership or a limited liability company. The application form shall also require the vendor to submit
information verifying that the vendor has obtained the necessary permits required by state law from the district court in the county where the vendor is
located and the Oklahoma tax commission. The application form shall also require information regarding the number of each permit and the date each
permit was granted to the vendor. It shall be unlawful for any person to make any false statement on the application form. Knowingly or intentionally
submitting an application containing false information shall be unlawful and shall serve as grounds for denial, suspension or revocation of a vendor's
license issued by the city of Skiatook.
D. License Issuance: A license under this section shall be issued to a vendor when the applicant has completed each of the following requirements:
1. Obtained a county permit from the district court clerk and satisfied other applicable requirements under state law.
2. Satisfactorily submitted the application required under this section to the city clerk.
3. Paid the required license fee as set forth in subsection B of this section to the city of Skiatook.
All licenses shall be issued for one calendar year from January 1 to December 31. The fee for any license issued after the effective date of this
section, and for a period of less than one calendar year, shall be prorated accordingly. Payment of annual license fees must be made within thirty
(30) days from the date the license expires. Any vendor failing to pay the annual fee within thirty (30) days from the date the license expires, or within
thirty (30) days from the date the vendor begins selling or serving alcohol and/or 3.2 beer if a new application, shall be subject to the penalties set
forth in subsection H2 of this section.
E. Sale, Barter Or Gift: It shall be unlawful for any person or business licensed under this section to sell, serve, barter or give to any person under the age
of twenty one (21) any beverage containing alcohol and/or 3.2 beer. Conviction, or acceptance of a plea bargain, by an employee or agent of the
vendor for such an offense shall subject the vendor's license to sell or serve alcohol and/or 3.2 beer to suspension or revocation by the city as provided
in subsection H of this section.
F. Misrepresentation Of Age: It shall be unlawful for any person to misrepresent their age to any vendor for the purpose of obtaining or facilitating the sale
or serving of alcohol and/or 3.2 beer.
G. Transfers: Each license shall be issued to the applicant only and shall not be transferable to another holder. Each license shall be issued only for the
premises described in the application. If a business holding a license under this section is sold, a new license must be obtained by the new owner. A
separate license for each location of businesses with common ownership, including all chain stores and businesses owned and operated pursuant to
franchise agreements, must be obtained by a vendor operating more than one business engaged in the business of selling or serving alcohol and/or
3.2 beer within the city of Skiatook.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 36/269
H. Penalties:
1. Suspension Of License:
a. A license granted under this section may be revoked or suspended by the city manager, without a hearing subsequent to conviction of the vendor,
its employees or agents, for the sale of alcohol and/or 3.2 beer to a minor, or by the acceptance of a plea bargain for such an offense. In addition
to the fines and penalties which may be imposed upon the employee or agent serving or selling alcohol and/or 3.2 beer to a minor, the following
sanctions shall be imposed upon the vendor:
(1) First conviction of the vendor or its employees or agents within a twenty four (24) month period will result in the issuance of an official written
warning to the vendor that additional convictions will result in suspension of the vendor's license.
(2) Second conviction of the vendor or its employees or agents within a twenty four (24) month period will result in suspension of the vendor's
license to sell or serve alcohol and/or 3.2 beer for three (3) consecutive days.
(3) Third conviction of the vendor or its employees or agents within a twenty four (24) month period will result in suspension of the vendor's license
to sell or serve alcohol and/or 3.2 beer for up to seven (7) consecutive days.
(4) Each additional conviction of a vendor or its employees or agents within a twenty four (24) month period will result in an additional suspension
of the vendor's license to sell or serve alcohol and/or 3.2 beer for an additional thirty (30) day period.
b. The vendor shall have the right to appeal the decision of the city manager to the city council within five (5) business days of the city manager's
decision to revoke or suspend a vendor's license. The city council shall hold a public hearing at the next regularly scheduled city council meeting to
consider the matter, and thereafter shall affirm or reverse the decision of the city manager. If the city council determines that suspension of the
vendor's license is warranted under this section, the suspension shall begin within five (5) business days from the hearing date. During the
suspension period the vendor may not sell or serve alcohol and/or 3.2 beer.
2. Failure To Obtain A Permit As Required By This Section: Any existing vendor who fails to obtain a permit within thirty (30) days from the date this
section becomes effective shall be prohibited from selling or serving alcohol and/or 3.2 beer until such time as a license is obtained by the vendor. All
new businesses intending to sell or serve alcohol, for consumption either on or off the vendor's premises, shall be required to obtain a license under
this section within thirty (30) days of the date the vendor begins selling or serving alcohol and/or 3.2 beer. A vendor who continues to sell or serve
alcohol and/or 3.2 beer without obtaining an initial or renewed license under this section shall receive an initial written warning and thereafter shall
have three (3) business days to file an application with the city clerk to obtain a license in compliance with this section. Subsequent to the issuance
of a warning under this section, a vendor who continues to sell or serve alcohol and/or 3.2 beer after the three (3) day period without obtaining the
required license shall be subject to a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day for each day alcohol and/or 3.2 beer are served or sold by the
vendor without a license. The city shall also be entitled to pursue injunctive relief and all other available legal remedies in the district courts against
the vendor. In addition, the city shall notify all state agencies vested with licensing, regulatory or review power, including, but not limited to, the ABLE
commission and the Oklahoma tax commission, of the vendor's failure to obtain a permit as required by this code.
3. Vendor Serving Or Selling Alcohol And/Or 3.2 Beer While Under Suspension: Any vendor who fails to adhere to the conditions of a suspension
imposed by the city manager or the city council and continues to serve or sell alcohol and/or 3.2 beer during such suspension is in violation of this
section and shall be subject to a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per day for each day alcohol and/or 3.2 beer are sold or served by the vendor
while its license is under suspension. In addition, the city shall be entitled to pursue any legal and injunctive relief, and shall notify the relevant
agencies set forth in subsection H2 of this section. (Ord. 2013-22, 11-12-2013)
Chapter 2
ITINERANT VENDORS, PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS
4-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
INTERSTATE COMMERCE: As used in this chapter, items or property from another state which are consigned to any other state and eligible under the
tariffs, rules and regulations approved by the U.S. congress and/or federal administrative agencies as not subject to taxation due to their temporary
presence in this state.
PEDDLER AND/OR ITINERANT VENDOR (Used Interchangeably): Means and includes all persons, firms or corporations, as well as their agents and
employees who engage in the temporary or transient business in the city of selling or offering for sale any goods or merchandise, amusement or services,
or exhibiting the same for sale or exhibiting the same for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof and who for the purpose of carrying on such
business or conduction of such exhibits thereof either hire, rent, lease or occupy any room or space in any building, structure, other enclosure, vacant lot
or any other property whatever in the city in, through, or from which any goods or merchandise may be sold, offered for sale or exhibited for the purpose of
taking orders for the sale thereof.
PERSON: Shall include the singular and plural and shall also mean and include any person, firm, corporation, association, club, partnership, society or any
other organization.
SOLICITOR OR CANVASSER: A person who travels from place to place taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise
or property of any nature for future delivery or for services to be furnished or performed in the future.
TEMPORARY: As used in the definition of "interstate commerce", any such business transacted or conducted in the city for which definite arrangements
have not been made for the hire, rental or lease of premises for at least one hundred (100) days, in or upon which such business is to be operated or
conducted.
TRANSIENT: As used in the definition of "peddler and/or itinerant vendor", any such business of any such itinerant vendor as may be operated or
conducted by persons, firms or corporations, or by their agents or employees who reside away from the city or who have fixed places of business in places
other than the city or who move stocks of goods or merchandise or samples thereof into the city with the purpose or intention of removing them, or the
unsold portion thereof, away from the city before the expiration of one hundred (100) days. (Ord. 2012-02, 4-10-2012)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 37/269
4-2-2: LICENSING REQUIREMENTS; FEES:
A. License Required: It is unlawful for any "peddler", "itinerant vendor", "solicitor" and/or "canvasser" to sell, offer for sale, exhibit for sale, or exhibit for the
purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof, any goods or merchandise in the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a license as herein
provided for. The city clerk shall issue to each person a license authorizing such person to sell, exhibit for sale, offer for sale, or exhibit for the purpose
of taking orders for the sale thereof in the city his goods or merchandise only after such person shall have fully complied with all provisions of this
chapter and shall have paid the license fees hereinafter provided, which sum shall be compensation to the city for the services herein required of it and
to enable the city to partially defray the expenses of enforcing the provisions of this chapter. A separate license is required for each person. (Ord. 2012-
02, 4-10-2012; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
B. Nontransferable: No license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be used or worn at any time by any person other than the one to whom it
was issued.
C. Exhibition Of License: Peddlers, itinerant vendors, solicitors and canvassers shall exhibit and display their license or badge as evidence thereof to all
persons when they are engaged in itinerant vending, peddling, canvassing or soliciting. (Ord. 2012-02, 4-10-2012)
D. Fees:
1. Rate: For the issuance of a license, the city clerk shall assess and receive a fee of either five dollars ($5.00) per day; ten dollars ($10.00) per week;
or thirty dollars ($30.00) per month. (Ord. 2012-02, 4-10-2012; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
2. Basis For Fees: For the purpose of this chapter, any period of days less than seven (7) calendar days shall be considered per day; any period of
seven (7) calendar days in total shall be considered one week; any period of more than seven (7) calendar days and not more than thirty (30)
calendar days shall be considered one month. The applicant may choose whichever basis (whether per day, per week or per month) as the applicant
so desires. (Ord. 2012-02, 4-10-2012)
3. Exemption: An itinerant vendor, peddler, solicitor or canvasser which considers itself exempt from this chapter by reason of being engaged in
interstate commerce shall have the right to request a hearing before the city clerk to determine the burden, if any, imposed on the vendor by this
chapter. (Ord. 2012-02, 4-10-2012; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
E. License Term: All licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire on the date specified in the license. (Ord. 2012-02, 4-10-2012)
4-2-3: EXCLUDED PERSONS:
The following persons are excluded from the application of the provisions of this chapter and no license is required:
A. Persons engaged in selling personal property at wholesale to dealers in such property;
B. Merchants having regular places of business in the city and their employees in taking orders at the houses of their customers for goods, wares and
merchandise held in stock at such places of business and in delivering the goods so ordered;
C. Persons selling daily or weekly newspapers;
D. Agents of Skiatook schools, churches or other nonprofit organizations permanently located within the boundaries of the city or within an eight (8) mile
radius thereof;
E. Ordinary commercial travelers who sell or exhibit for sale goods or merchandise to parties engaged in the business of buying and selling and dealing in
goods or merchandise or service, or to sales at wholesale and not retail, or to sales of advertising in any phone book or other professional directories;
F. Sales of goods or merchandise donated by the owners thereof, the proceeds whereof are to be applied to any charitable purpose; and
G. Vendors of farm produce, agricultural products or firewood in their natural states. (Ord. 2012-02, 4-10-2012)
4-2-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
A. Filing Of Application: Applicants for a license under this chapter shall file with the city clerk in duplicate a sworn application in writing on a form to be
furnished by the clerk setting forth the information required by this chapter. (Ord. 2012-02, 4-10-2012; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
B. Contents Of Application: The application shall provide the following information, when applicable:
1. Full name, description, birth date, and a copy of a valid driver's license or state issued photo identification card of each individual applicant.
2. Address, both legal and local.
3. Nature of business and kinds of goods or services to be sold.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 38/269
4. If employed by another, the name and address of the applicant's employer, together with a brief description of the credentials showing the exact
relationship.
5. Length of time for which right to do business is requested.
6. Description and license number or other identification of any vehicle to be used.
7. A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a felony or other offense involving dishonesty, the nature of the offense and the
punishment or penalty assessed therefor.
8. A written, notarized statement by the legal owner of the land upon which any fixed business location shall be located authorizing the use of the land
for the purposes desired by the applicant.
9. A copy of a valid state of Oklahoma sales tax permit, or proof that the applicant is exempt from the payment of sales tax; or other applicable
municipal, county, state or federal licenses or permits.
10. A certified copy of its corporate charter, permit or authority to do business in the state of Oklahoma. (Ord. 2012-02, 4-10-2012)
4-2-5: INVESTIGATION AND ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
A. Police Report: Upon receipt of an application for license, the city clerk shall refer one copy to the chief of police who shall note thereon any record
concerning the applicant which may appear from the official records in his charge and return the same promptly to the clerk.
B. Other Investigation Or Inquiry: The city clerk shall cause such other investigation or inquiry to be made concerning the applicant's employer as may be
deemed necessary to determine the character and business responsibility of the applicant and whether his application is in compliance with the terms
and conditions of this chapter.
C. Issuance Of License; Badge: If, as a result of the investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory
and the application is in compliance with the terms and conditions of this chapter, the city clerk, upon payment of the prescribed license fee, shall issue
the license. Upon issuance of the license, the city clerk shall also issue and deliver to the applicant a badge in a size and of a nature to be designed by
the clerk which shall indicate that the applicant has received a license from the city.
D. Disapproval: If, as a result of the application and/or investigation provided for in this section, the applicant's character or business responsibility or that
of his employer are found to be unsatisfactory; and/or the facts stated in such application are found to be untrue and/or incomplete; and/or the applicant
fails to provide any document(s), proof, permit(s) and/or information as required in support of the application the chief of police or city clerk shall
endorse on such application his/her disapproval thereof and the reasons for the same, and the clerk shall then notify the applicant that his application
has been disapproved and that no license will be issued.
E. Appeal: Any applicant aggrieved by the action of the chief of police or the city clerk in the denial or revocation of a license as provided herein shall have
the right to appeal therefrom to the city council. Such appeal shall be filed in writing with the city council within fourteen (14) days after notice of the
action complained of has been given to the applicant personally or mailed, postage prepaid, to the address stated in his application. The city council
shall set a time and place for a hearing on such appeal, notice of which shall be given to the applicant at least five (5) days prior to the date set for
hearing. The decision and order of the city council on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. (Ord. 2012-02, 4-10-2012; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-
2013)
4-2-6: MINIMUM AGE OF LICENSEE:
No license shall be issued as an itinerant vendor, peddler, canvasser or solicitor to any person under the age of sixteen (16) years, nor shall any licensee
under this chapter employ or engage any minor under the age of sixteen (16) years to be employed as an itinerant vendor, canvasser, solicitor or peddler.
(Ord. 2012-02, 4-10-2012)
4-2-7: RESTRICTED AND PROHIBITED ACTS:
A. Loud Noises: No itinerant vendor, peddler, canvasser or solicitor, nor any person in his behalf, shall shout, blow a horn or use any sound amplifying
device or system upon any of the streets, alleys, parks or sidewalks of the city where loud and raucous sound is emitted or produced.
B. Use Of Streets: No itinerant vendor, peddler, canvasser or solicitor shall have any exclusive right to any location in the public streets nor shall any be
permitted a stationary location, nor shall any be permitted to operate in a congested area where operations might impede or inconvenience the public.
C. Use Of Public Property To Establish A Business: No itinerant vendor, peddler, canvasser or solicitor shall use any public property within the corporate
limits of the city, including streets, parks and public rights of way, to establish a business or service operation. Exempt from this provision are any
itinerant vendors, peddlers, canvassers, or solicitors engaged in a special event or other activity authorized by the city council, city
manager/administrator, chief of police or other person(s) permitted to make such authorizations. (Ord. 2012-02, 4-10-2012)
4-2-8: POLICE RECORD OF CONVICTIONS:
The chief of police shall report to the city clerk all convictions for violations of this chapter and the clerk shall maintain a record for each license issued and
record the reports of violations therein. (Ord. 2012-02, 4-10-2012; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 39/269
4-2-9: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
A. Grounds For Revocation: Licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked by the city clerk after notice has been served on the
applicant for any of the following causes: (Ord. 2012-02, 4-10-2012; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
1. Fraud, misrepresentation, omission or any false statement contained in the application for license.
2. Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on his business as an itinerant vendor, peddler, solicitor or canvasser.
3. Any violation of this chapter.
4. Conviction of any felony or other crime involving dishonesty.
5. Conducting the business of itinerant vendor, peddler, solicitor or canvasser in an unlawful manner or in such a manner to constitute a breach of the
peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. (Ord. 2012-02, 4-10-2012)
B. Notice Of Revocation And Hearing: Notice of the revocation of a license shall be in writing, setting forth with particularity the grounds of complaint. Upon
receipt of a complaint, the city clerk shall forthwith revoke the license so issued and shall contemporaneously therewith set a time and place for
hearing. The hearing shall be conducted by the city clerk, at which hearing evidence may be presented by the complainant and the licensee. After
receiving and considering such evidence, the city clerk shall reinstate the license or shall permanently revoke the same. The hearing before the city
clerk must be conducted within five (5) days from the date of the receipt of the complaint. Any person aggrieved by a decision of the city clerk shall
have the right to appeal to the city council as set forth in subsection 4-2-5E of this chapter. (Ord. 2012-02, 4-10-2012; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
4-2-10: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof, be subject to penalty as provided in
section 1-4-1 of this code. Violation of this chapter shall also be grounds for revocation or suspension of any license granted. (Ord. 2012-02, 4-10-2012)
Chapter 3
ADULT ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENTS
4-3-1: DESCRIPTION:
"Adult entertainment establishments" shall be described as businesses which cater primarily to adults twenty one (21) years of age or older and/or which
sell intoxicating beverages and/or low point beer to be consumed on the premises, and all sexually oriented businesses. (Ord. 2004-07, 9-14-2004)
4-3-2: INCLUDED USES:
Bar/tavern, beer bar, billiard parlor/pool hall, private club/nightclub, and sexually oriented business are considered included uses. (Ord. 2004-07, 9-14-
2004)
4-3-3: LOCATION RESTRICTION:
No person shall exercise supervisory control, manage, operate, cause or permit the establishment of any of the sexually oriented businesses as described
in this chapter in any area zoned other than CG or CH. (Ord. 2004-07, 9-14-2004)
4-3-4: USE CONDITIONS:
A. Illegal Activities Prohibited: Some of the businesses and activities described in this chapter may be illegal under state or federal law, and persons
associated therewith may be subject to criminal prosecution. Nothing in this chapter is intended to make legal any business or activity now illegal under
state or federal law.
B. Screening From Residential District: The uses included in this chapter, when located on a lot which is abutting a residential district, must be screened
from such residential district by the construction and maintenance of a screening fence or wall along the lot line or lines in common with such district.
C. Spacing Standards: Adult entertainment establishments must meet the minimum spacing standards listed below:
1. Public entrance doors shall be located at least fifty feet (50') from a residential district, which shall be measured in a straight line from the nearest
point on a residential zoning district boundary line to the nearest public entrance door of the adult entertainment establishment.
2. Such establishments shall not be located closer than three hundred feet (300') from a public park, school or church, which shall be measured from
the nearest point on the property line of a park, school or church to the nearest public entry door of the adult entertainment establishment measured
along the street right of way line providing the nearest direct route usually traveled by pedestrians between such points. For purposes of determining
measured distance, property situated on the opposite side of the street from such park, school or church shall be considered as if it were located on
the same side of the street.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 40/269
3. Such establishments shall be spaced at least three hundred feet (300') from any other adult entertainment establishment listed herein, which shall be
measured in a straight line from the nearest point of the wall of the portion of the building in which said business is conducted, to the nearest point of
the wall of the portion of the building in which another adult entertainment establishment is located.
4. The uses included in this chapter are prohibited except within a completely enclosed building. (Ord. 2004-07, 9-14-2004)
Chapter 4
OIL WELL DRILLING
4-4-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to establish minimum requirements for the drilling of wells on properties located within the corporate limits of the city, in
addition to those imposed by other governmental agencies. (1991 Code § 14-270)
4-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
CORPORATE LIMITS: All areas legally annexed by the city of Skiatook, excluding those areas enclosed by a narrow strip of annexed territory, commonly
known as a "fence line".
DRILLING EQUIPMENT: All such items that may be necessary and proper to facilitate the access to mineral resources or the exploration for these
resources, specifically exempting those operations whose intent is to secure potable water supplies.
PRODUCTION EQUIPMENT: Those devices necessary and proper to extract mineral resources after access has been attained.
RESIDENTIAL DWELLING: Any house, apartment, duplex or other structure which is normally occupied by a person as his or her place of abode and is
not located within an area zoned for commercial services.
SECURITY DEVICE: Any physical barrier to human or domestic animals. (1991 Code § 14-271)
4-4-3: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS; FEES:
A. Application; Information Required: At least ten (10) days prior to any activity by drilling equipment, the owner of mineral rights or his agent shall apply
with the building inspector of the city for a permit to drill, on such forms as the building inspector shall provide. Forms shall include the following
information:
1. Plot Plan: Plot plan containing distances from proposed wellhead to:
a. Adjoining surface property lines.
b. Streets, alleys, and/or other public/private roadways.
c. All structures, habitable or otherwise.
d. Known utility lines.
2. Proof Of Insurance: Proof of liability insurance, either specific or general in nature, insuring the driller or operator in the minimum amount of one
hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for drilling purposes.
3. Security Device: Proposed security device.
4. Emergency Number: A twenty four (24) hour phone number to be used for notification in case of emergency. (1991 Code § 14-273)
B. Permit Fees: A fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be charged to process a drilling application, and, in addition, a fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each of the
following applicable inspections. All fees shall be payable at the time application is made. The following inspections shall be made, when applicable:
1. Temporary electrical service.
2. Permanent electrical service.
3. Security device installation.
4. Special inspections where necessary and appropriate. (1991 Code § 14-274)
4-4-4: SETBACK REQUIREMENTS:
A minimum one hundred foot (100') setback shall be required from all public and private roadways or alleys, and surface property lines, including rights of
way, except those designated as easements; and for all structures, a minimum setback of twenty five feet (25') shall be maintained from all public or
private utility lines located underground. Variances may be granted only by the city council. (1991 Code § 14-275)
4-4-5: ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 41/269
A. Discharge Onto Liquid Surfaces: No discharge onto the surface of any liquid, drilling mud, salt, water or other noxious or deleterious substances shall
be permitted from the well site or pits, tanks or other accessories to the operation.
B. Gases: No gases or other flammable vapors shall be released except in compliance with the rules of the Oklahoma corporation commission. (1991
Code § 14-276)
C. Noise: Noise emitted from such operation shall be limited so as not to cause a disturbance of the peace as provided for in state law. No operations may
be conducted after nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and before six o'clock (6:00) A.M., at any well site within one thousand feet (1,000') of a residential,
commercial or other establishment where there are persons reasonably expected to be annoyed thereby. (1991 Code § 14-276; amd. 2011 Code)
4-4-6: SECURITY DEVICES:
Upon completion of drilling and placement of production equipment, an approved security device shall be placed around all mechanical and electrical
devices. Security devices shall be designed to restrict the accidental electrocution or entanglement in moving devices by humans or domestic animals. At
a minimum, the security device shall be a wooden or metal fence not less than fifty two inches (52") in height with positive locks at all access points. (1991
Code § 14-277)
4-4-7: DRILLING RESTRICTIONS:
A. Location: No person, firm or corporation shall conduct any drilling or other oil and gas mining operations within two hundred fifty feet (250') of a
residence; provided, that this provision shall not apply to any oil and gas well which was drilled prior to the effective date hereof, and in constant
production since the date drilling operations ceased.
B. City Permit: No person, firm or corporation shall engage in any oil and gas mining or exploration operation without having first applied for and received
from the city a permit for the same. No person, firm or corporation shall engage in mining operations except in compliance with any restrictions
imposed by the permit issued by the city. (1991 Code § 14-278)
4-4-8: DUPLICATED REQUIREMENTS; MOST RESTRICTIVE PROVISIONS APPLY:
In all cases where the requirements of this chapter are duplicated, more or less, by the state of Oklahoma or the corporation commission of the state of
Oklahoma, the more restrictive set of regulations shall apply. (1991 Code § 14-280)
4-4-9: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
A. Penalty Imposed: Violation of this chapter is hereby declared a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to penalty as provided in
section 1-4-1 of this code. Each day during which a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. (1991 Code § 14-281; amd. 2011 Code)
B. Nuisance Declared: A violation of this chapter shall be deemed a nuisance and subject to abatement as other nuisances by civil action for injunction
and other remedies afforded by state law for abatement of nuisances. (1991 Code § 14-281)
Title 5
HEALTH AND SANITATION
Chapter 1
TOBACCO USE IN CITY BUILDINGS, VEHICLES
5-1-1: TOBACCO AND ELECTRONIC SMOKING DEVICE DEFINED:
"Tobacco", as used in this chapter, includes, but is not limited to, smoking tobacco such as used in pipes, cigarettes and cigars, and chewing or dipping
tobacco, such as snuff and chewing tobacco. It also includes tobacco substitutes and replacements consumed by the inhalation of smoke in the manner of
smoking cigarettes. "Electronic smoking device", as used in this chapter, means an electronic and/or battery operated device, the use of which may
resemble smoking that can be used to deliver an inhaled dose of nicotine or other substances. An electronic smoking device includes any such device,
whether manufactured, distributed, marketed or sold as an electronic cigarette, also known as an e-cigarette, an electronic cigar, an electronic cigarillo, an
electronic pipe, an electronic hookah, or any other product name or description which can be classified as an electronic smoking device, including
electronic nicotine delivery systems (ENDS), and vapor products. (Ord. 2014-05, 2-11-2015)
5-1-2: USE PROHIBITED:
The use of tobacco or an electronic smoking device in any form is hereby prohibited on all real property, including all buildings and structures owned by the
city of Skiatook or the Skiatook public works authority. The use of tobacco or an electronic smoking device in any form is hereby prohibited in all vehicles
and equipment owned, operated or utilized by the city of Skiatook or the Skiatook public works authority. (Ord. 2014-05, 2-11-2015)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 42/269
5-1-3: EMPLOYEES AND CONTRACTORS:
A. Compliance Required: Compliance with the provisions of this chapter by employees and independent contractors of the city shall be a condition of
continued employment or contractual relations. All contracts between the city and contractors shall be deemed to include a provision requiring
compliance with this chapter.
B. Posting Of Signs: The city council shall cause conspicuous signs to be posted which conspicuously state that smoking in the municipal places
described in section 5-1-2 of this chapter is prohibited. (Ord. 93-02, 3-9-1993)
5-1-4: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Violation of this chapter is hereby declared to be a misdemeanor and subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. Each occurrence of a
violation of this chapter shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 93-02, 3-9-1993; amd. 2011 Code)
Chapter 2
FOOD HANDLERS
5-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
FOOD: Shall include all commodities used for food, drink, confectionery, or condiment by man or animals, whether the same be simple or compound.
HEALTH OFFICER: The superintendent of health of the applicable county, whether Osage or Tulsa, or his authorized representative. (1991 Code § 11-1;
amd. 2011 Code)
5-2-2: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS; FEES:
A. Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for any person who operates or who is employed by any business which produces, prepares, manufactures, sells
or packages "food", as defined in section 5-2-1 of this chapter, in the city to not have in his or her possession a current and unrevoked permit approved
by the health officer. (1991 Code § 11-3)
B. Application For Permit: Application for such a permit must be made in writing to the health officer by the person desiring such permit. Prior to approval
of such application and the issuance of such permit, the health officer shall instruct such person in approved sanitation practices in food handling;
provided, that the health officer is hereby authorized, in lieu of the above instruction, to require applicants for permits to attend a course of instruction in
sanitary practices of food service, prior to approval of such application and issuance of such permit. (1991 Code § 11-5)
C. Permit Fee: Upon approval of such application, the city-county health department of Tulsa County and/or Osage County shall issue said person, a
permit; provided, that there shall be collected a fee as provided by the city council, but in no event shall the fee be less than six dollars ($6.00) for each
permit to help defray the expenses of conducting the required course of instruction in sanitary practices of food services. Said permit shall entitle such
person to work in a food establishment during the thirty six (36) months following the date on which said permit is issued. (1991 Code § 11-6; amd.
2011 Code)
D. Temporary Permits: The health officer is hereby authorized to issue temporary permits permitting said applicant to work as a food handler, except as
described in section 5-2-3 of this chapter, until the next regular course of instruction in sanitary practices of food handling is conducted; provided, that
such temporary permit shall expire on the day the above mentioned course of instruction begins. (1991 Code § 11-7)
E. Medical Examinations: Before approval of application for a permit, the health officer may require, in his discretion, such medical and laboratory
examinations as he may deem necessary to minimize the possibility of transmission of communicable diseases. (1991 Code § 11-8)
5-2-3: EMPLOYMENT OF DISEASED PERSONS:
No employer shall employ, permit or suffer any person to work, nor shall any person work, in a building, room or vehicle occupied or used for the
production, preparation, manufacture, packaging, storage, sale, distribution and transportation of food, when such person is afflicted with any contagious
or infectious disease. (1991 Code § 11-2)
5-2-4: HIRING PERSONS POSSESSING PERMITS:
It shall be unlawful for any person who conducts or operates a business wherein food is produced, prepared, manufactured, sold, or packaged, other than
a temporary establishment, in the city, to hire or permit to be hired, or permit to work gratis, any person who does not possess a current and unrevoked
permit approved by the health officer. "Temporary food establishment" shall mean any food services establishment which operates at a fixed location, not
to exceed two (2) weeks. (1991 Code § 11-4)
5-2-5: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 43/269
The health officer may at any time revoke the permit of any person handling food for failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter, for carelessness
on the part of such person in the handling of food, or for any act affecting the health of the public. Such permit may be reinstated only by the health officer
upon showing that the matter complained of has been remedied. (1991 Code § 11-9)
5-2-6: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any section or provision of this chapter, or who shall violate any unlawful rule or regulation made by the superintendent of
health of Tulsa County or Osage County shall be guilty of an offense, and any person who shall refuse or fail to do anything herein commanded in this
chapter, or who does that which is prohibited herein shall likewise be guilty of an offense, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an amount not less
than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than thirty five dollars ($35.00), including costs; provided, that each and every violation, and each day of violation shall
be a separate offense. (1991 Code § 11-10; amd. 2011 Code)
Chapter 3
HYPODERMIC SYRINGES
5-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and terms have the following meanings:
CONTROLLED DANGEROUS SUBSTANCE: A drug, substance or immediate precursor in schedules I through V of the Oklahoma uniform controlled
substances act1 as that act now exists and may be hereafter amended.
DISPOSABLE SYRINGE: A hypodermic syringe which is manufactured for use one time or the needle of which is designed for use only one time.
HYPODERMIC SYRINGE OR SYRINGE: A device manufactured or designed to inject or extract a substance below the layer of the epidermis of any living
thing. (1991 Code § 11-101)
5-3-2: SALE OF SYRINGES PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS:
No person or firm may sell a hypodermic syringe to another, except to a hospital or one licensed to prescribe or dispense a "controlled dangerous
substance" by the laws of this state or the United States, without first requiring identification of the purchaser of a prescription, certificate of need or an
authorization, written or verbal, for the purchase of the hypodermic syringe from a licensed physician or official of a state, county, or city-county health
department; and if the need is for use of the hypodermic syringe with animals or fowl, the certificate, prescription or authorization may be from a doctor of
veterinary medicine. (1991 Code § 11-102)
5-3-3: RECORD OF SALES:
A. Records Required: Any person who sells hypodermic syringes shall maintain a written record of sales, showing the name of persons to whom the
syringe was sold, the address of the buyer, the date of the sale, the number and type (by capacity) of syringes sold. (1991 Code § 11-103)
B. Inspection Of Records: Records required by this section to be maintained shall be made available for inspection during business hours to the chief of
police, the assistant chief of police or any other person who the chief of police may designate in writing. (1991 Code § 11-104)
5-3-4: USE RESTRICTIONS:
A. Destruction Of Used Syringes: Any person who uses any disposable syringe shall, immediately after use of it, destroy it or render it or its needle
inoperable so that it cannot be used again by any other person. (1991 Code § 11-105)
B. Multiple Use: Any person who uses a needle or syringe intended for use more than one time shall, immediately after the final use of the same, destroy
the needle or syringe, or either, rendering it inoperable so that the needle or syringe cannot be used again by any other person. (1991 Code § 11-106)
5-3-5: PROVISIONS CUMULATIVE:
The provisions of this chapter shall be cumulative to and shall not operate to repeal any other ordinances. (1991 Code § 11-109)
5-3-6: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
A. Separate Violations: Every article sold and every day a sale is conducted in violation of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. (1991 Code
§ 11-107)
B. Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to penalty as
provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. (1991 Code § 11-108; amd. 2011 Code)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 44/269
Chapter 4
AMBULANCE SERVICE
5-4-1: PURPOSE; UTILITY SERVICE RATE INCREASE:
The City Council finds that the current cost for ambulance service provided by the City to its citizens and others is frequently a hardship upon those
compelled to call up such service and that the best interests of the residents of the City would be served by providing for ambulance service at a rate equal
to existing medical insurance coverage to certain classes of residents and by funding such ambulance service by an increase in the charge made for utility
services by seven dollars ($7.00) per month. Therefore, the ambulance service provided by this chapter shall be deemed a service supplemental to
insurance coverage afforded persons entitled to ambulance service by this chapter and shall be construed accordingly. (Ord. 2017-04, 6-13-2017)
5-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases as used in this chapter shall, for the purposes of this chapter, have the following meanings:
AMBULANCE: Any ground, air or water vehicle which is or should be approved by the Commissioner of Health, designed and equipped to transport a
patient or patients and to provide appropriate on scene and en route patient stabilization and care as required. Vehicles used as ambulances shall meet
such standards as may be required by the State Board of Health for approval, and shall display evidence of such approval at all times.
AMBULANCE SERVICE: Any private firm or governmental agency which is or should be licensed by the State Department of Health to provide levels of
medical care based on certification standards promulgated by the board.
CITY: The incorporated City of Skiatook excluding therefrom any area located within the City's "fence line" and not within the actual corporate limits of the
City.
EMERGENCY: A sudden and unexpected illness or injury requiring immediate transportation to a hospital or other place where emergency medical
attention is rendered and circumstances in which life or limb is in imminent danger of loss. Under no conditions shall any person be entitled to the
supplemental ambulance service provided by this chapter unless transportation of such person by ambulance was medically reasonable and necessary.
Ambulance service shall not be utilized as a taxi service or means of transportation.
GEOGRAPHIC CENTER: The intersection of the centerlines of Highway 20 and Osage Avenue in the City of Skiatook, Oklahoma.
ILLNESS OR INJURY: A physical impairment or disability which arose suddenly and unexpectedly and which requires immediate medical attention. It does
not include any mental illness or ambulance transportation when the person transported was biologically dead when the ambulance transportation
commenced. It does, however, include attempted suicide.
INSURANCE: Medical, hospitalization or other insurance or indemnity agreement which provides benefits or pays claims for medical services, automobile
insurance providing for payment of medical benefits to the insured or his family, third party liability coverage resulting in payment of medical expenses of
residents, workers' compensation benefits, Medicare and other welfare programs providing for payment of medical care or services. "Insurance benefits"
means the proceeds of such insurance or programs.
PHYSICIAN: Any medical doctor or osteopathic physician licensed to practice within the State of Oklahoma. It does not include any other practitioners of
the healing arts, including, but not limited to, psychologists, psychiatrists, and chiropractors.
PLACE OF BUSINESS OR BUSINESS: Any commercial establishment having a location separate and apart from any other such establishment.
RESIDENCE: One (1) single-family dwelling unit.
RESIDENT: A person permanently residing in the City of Skiatook for a continuous period of not less than sixty (60) days and who resides in the City with
the permanent intention of making the City his or her only place of residence for an indefinite period of time.
Other words and phrases used in this chapter are defined parenthetically in this chapter following the use of such word or phrase. (1991 Code § 11-12;
amd. Ord. 2012-12, 10-30-2012)
5-4-3: ELECTRIC SERVICE SURCHARGE:
A. Service Charges Not Affected: Nothing herein shall be construed to repeal or alter existing ordinances relating to charges made for electric service by
the City, which schedule of rates are set forth in title 9, chapter 3, article A of this Code. (1991 Code § 11-24)
B. Surcharge Imposed; Exceptions:
1. Except for the exemptions set forth in subsection B2 of this section, there is hereby imposed upon the monthly charge for electric service furnished
by the City of Skiatook and/or Skiatook Public Works Authority to all subscribers of its electric service, wherever located, a surcharge in the sum of
seven dollars ($7.00) per electric meter, which monthly surcharge is in addition to any other charges for electric service which are now or may be
hereafter imposed by the City of Skiatook and/or Skiatook Public Works Authority. (Ord. 2017-04, 6-13-2017)
2. There is hereby excluded from the electric service surcharge imposed by this chapter the following:
a. All meters in excess of one (1) for any residence or business where multiple meters are employed to provide electricity to one (1) residence or one
(1) business, such as are found when multiple meters are used for the convenience of the utility or a single business or residence;
b. Public schools and churches (but not the parsonages); and (1991 Code § 11-13)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 45/269
c. Any electric meter which, if subjected to the surcharge, would, in the opinion of the City Clerk, result in charging one (1) residence or business
twice for ambulance service or imposing the surcharge under circumstances where there is little likelihood that the residence or business would
ever receive a benefit from supplemental ambulance service. (1991 Code § 11-13; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
5-4-4: ALLOCATION OF FUNDS FOR AMBULANCE SERVICE:
All monies derived by means of the rate increase set forth in section 5-4-3 of this chapter shall be deposited in the General Fund. (1991 Code § 11-14)
5-4-5: AMBULANCE SERVICE SUPPLEMENTAL TO INSURANCE BENEFITS:
After the effective date hereof, emergency ambulance service supplemental to insurance benefits will be furnished to all eligible persons in accordance
with the EMS operational protocols as approved by the Oklahoma State Department of Health and the Skiatook Fire Department (EMS) Medical Director.
A copy of the current EMS operational protocols shall be available for review at City Hall during normal business hours and are also available on the City's
website. (Ord. 2012-04, 2-20-2012)
5-4-6: PERSONS ELIGIBLE FOR SERVICE:
The following persons ("eligible persons") are eligible to receive the supplemental ambulance service provided for in this chapter:
A. Residents of the City whose residence receive electric service from the City, members of their family and relatives permanently residing with such
resident and who are themselves residents of the City (including their newborn children). (1991 Code § 11-16)
B. Persons permanently residing without the City but within the area in which the City of Skiatook provides ambulance service, whether in its licensed
service area or the area in which the City of Skiatook is the primary provider of ambulance service, and have resided there for a continuous period of
not less than sixty (60) days and who reside there with the permanent intention of making the same their only place of residence, and who:
1. Subscribe to electric service from the City; or
2. Who, pursuant to section 5-4-8 of this chapter, make a written election to pay for and receive supplemental ambulance service and be subject to the
terms of this chapter, or who pay a monthly ambulance service surcharge at the ambulance subscription rate on a public utility bill, which said
ambulance surcharge is billed and collected by the utility provider and the surcharge is remitted to the City, subject to the terms of this chapter.
C. Nonresidents of the City who are employed by a place of business located in the City subscribing to the City's electric service or a place of business
located within the area in which the City of Skiatook provides ambulance service, whether in its licensed service area or the area in which the City of
Skiatook is the primary provider of ambulance service (a "covered business"), which place of business meets the requirements of subsection B of this
section when emergency ambulance service is the result of illness or injury arising out of and in the course of such nonresident's employment by a
covered business and when such employee is located:
1. Within the corporate limits of the City; or
2. On the place of business located outside the Municipal limits of the City but within the area in which the City of Skiatook provides ambulance service,
whether in its licensed service area or the area in which the City of Skiatook is the primary provider of ambulance service, and when such injury or
medical emergency occurs at the place of business where there exists an electric meter subscribing to the electric service of the City and when the
person or entity in whose name such service exists is subscribing to ambulance service of the City and is remitting the monthly ambulance service
surcharge established pursuant to this chapter, or who pay a monthly ambulance surcharge at the ambulance subscription rate on a public utility bill,
which said ambulance surcharge is billed and collected by the utility provider and the surcharge is remitted to the City, subject to the terms of this
chapter and section 5-4-8 of this chapter, or who pursuant to section 5-4-8 of this chapter, make a written election to pay for and receive
supplemental ambulance service, subject to the terms of this chapter. (Ord. 2013-08, 6-11-2013)
D. Any person requiring emergency ambulance service while lawfully upon the premises of any covered business as a business invitee or customer.
E. Residents of nursing homes, hospitals and other institutions or organizations located within the City or within five (5) miles of the geographic center of
the City who subscribe to and agree to pay for ambulance service from the City as provided in section 5-4-8 of this chapter. Residents of such
institutions who do not subscribe to membership in the ambulance service are not covered by the ambulance service provided by this chapter.
F. Persons who have no "insurance", as defined herein, but who otherwise qualify for supplementary ambulance service shall be provided such service at
no cost. (1991 Code § 11-16)
5-4-7: PERSONS EXCLUDED:
Supplemental ambulance service shall not extend to the following:
A. Where more than one (1) residence or business receives electricity through one (1) electric meter, the ambulance service provided for by this chapter
shall extend only to the resident in whose name the electric service account is carried and shall not extend to any other separate place of residence or
business, even though such separate place of residence or business may be occupied by a relative of the person in whose name the electric account is
carried; provided, however, that any such residence or place of business which is excluded by this section shall have the right to subscribe to the
supplemental ambulance service provided for in this chapter in the same manner and with the same effect as if such person were a nonresident of the
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 46/269
City and elected to pay for and receive supplemental ambulance service, and such places of residence or business may make such written election in
the same manner as a nonresident.
B. Hospitals, medical clinics, nursing homes and other similar organizations or institutions caring for the ill or infirm are excluded from the service offered
by this chapter, unless the person for whom emergency treatment is needed is otherwise provided ambulance service by the provisions of this chapter.
C. Nursing homes. Where a person for eligible ambulance service pursuant to this chapter is transported to or from a nursing home for illness or injury,
such person shall be charged and be liable for such amount as is allowed by Medicare under the Social Security Act for such transportation, regardless
of destination, which charge the person being transported shall be obligated to pay whether such person is insured by Medicare or not. Furthermore,
whomsoever shall request transportation by ambulance in behalf of another person shall, by having requested the same, be deemed to have agreed to
pay therefor and shall be obligated for such charge. (1991 Code § 11-17)
5-4-8: ELECTION TO SUBSCRIBE TO AMBULANCE SERVICE:
All persons residing within the area in which the City of Skiatook provides ambulance service, whether in its licensed service area or the area in which the
City of Skiatook is the primary provider of ambulance service, and who do not receive electric service from the City, are hereby granted the right and
privilege to subscribe to such ambulance service as follows: (Ord. 2013-08, 6-11-2013)
A. By filing at annual intervals, on a form to be furnished by the City, a written request for ambulance service and payment of the sum of eighty four dollars
($84.00), or such sum as is later amended by ordinance or resolution of the City Council, which sum shall constitute the payment for the ambulance
service from the date of such payment to the following June 30. The yearly subscription fee shall be due on or before July 1 of each year, and the
subscription period shall end on June 30 of the following year. (Ord. 2017-04, 6-13-2017)
B. By payment of subscription fees through a third party public utility provider, upon written agreement with the City, which assesses and collects the
ambulance service subscription monthly, which said monthly fee amount shall be the yearly subscription amount payable in twelve (12) equal
installments, and remits the same to the City of Skiatook, as agreed between the City of Skiatook and the public utility provider.
C. The City Manager is authorized to enter into agreements with third party public utility providers to assess, collect and remit monthly ambulance service
subscription fees to the City of Skiatook for ambulance service subscribers residing outside of the Municipal limits of the City of Skiatook, but who
reside or whose business is located within its licensed service area or the area in which the City of Skiatook is the primary provider of ambulance
service. The subscription fees may be assessed without written consent of the subscriber, but the subscriber shall be allowed to elect not to participate
or "opt out" as set forth in subsection D of this section.
D. Any ambulance service subscriber located outside of the corporate or Municipal limits of the City of Skiatook and who remits subscription payments
monthly pursuant to a surcharge on a third party public utility bill and who does not wish to subscribe for ambulance services, either before or after the
subscription period begins, shall be entitled to elect not to participate or "opt out" on forms prescribed and approved by the City Manager and Fire
Chief. Any ambulance service subscriber, not within the corporate or Municipal limits of the City of Skiatook who elects not to participate or to "opt out"
of the ambulance service subscription shall not be billed the monthly subscription fee beginning with the following billing cycle for that particular utility
provider, and shall be deemed to be a subscriber until the last day of the month in which the final ambulance surcharge is assessed on the utility bill.
(Ord. 2013-08, 6-11-2013)
5-4-9: TERMINATION OF ELECTRIC SERVICE:
If electric service shall for any reason be discontinued or terminated to any resident of the City or any other person eligible for supplemental ambulance
service, such person shall be entitled to receive ambulance service by making application for membership to the City and paying the sum of eighty four
dollars ($84.00) per year for the service. (Ord. 2017-04, 6-13-2017)
5-4-10: SERVICE FOR OTHERS:
Ambulance service furnished for persons who are not provided supplemental ambulance service as set forth in this chapter or who do not subscribe as set
forth in this chapter will be served on a call basis at rates and charges prescribed by the City Council, which rates and charges shall be a base charge and,
in addition, a charge for mileage and medical supplies. (1991 Code § 11-20)
5-4-11: WATER SUBSCRIBERS:
All persons residing within the corporate limits of the City who are furnished water by the City of Skiatook and/or Skiatook Public Works Authority, but not
electric service, will be provided supplemental ambulance service as set forth in this chapter, and, with respect to such persons, the monthly charge for
water is hereby increased by the sum of seven dollars ($7.00) per meter, as a surcharge on the monthly utility billing. With respect to persons residing
outside the corporate limits of the City who receive water from the City of Skiatook and/or Skiatook Public Works Authority, but not electric service, such
persons shall be eligible to subscribe to the ambulance service as set forth in this chapter, and upon subscription to the ambulance service, the water rates
for such person shall, upon subscription, be increased by the sum set forth in this section as a monthly surcharge. (Ord. 2017-04, 6-13-2017)
5-4-12: RATES FOR AMBULANCE SERVICE:
Rates for ambulance service may be set by the City Council at any time by ordinance or resolution. The rates set forth in this chapter are subject to
increase or decrease by ordinance or resolution of the City Council. (Ord. 2017-04, 6-13-2017)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 47/269
5-4-13: SUBROGATION AND ASSIGNMENT OF BENEFITS:
All persons subscribing to the City's supplemental ambulance service shall be deemed to have agreed to an assignment to the City of all their rights and
entitlement to the benefits of any insurance attributable to ambulance service provided by the City pursuant to this chapter. Similarly, all residents of the
City subject to the provisions of this chapter shall be obligated to pay for ambulance service a sum equivalent to their insurance coverage. Any person
receiving insurance benefits who fails to pay them to the City shall be liable for the same. (1991 Code § 11-23)
5-4-14: LIMITATION OF CITY OBLIGATION:
Under no condition shall the City be obligated to pay any sums of money to any person eligible for the benefits conferred by this chapter, and when any
person elects to use any ambulance service other than that provided by the City, the City shall have no liability or obligation to pay such person any
benefits therefor. When the City is unable for any reason to provide ambulance service as contemplated by this chapter, no person being refused
ambulance service at such time shall be entitled to make any claim or demand against the City or receive any benefits from the City. The operation of the
ambulance service by the City is hereby declared to be a governmental function of the City for the health and welfare of all persons for whom benefits are
provided by this chapter. (1991 Code § 11-25)
5-4-15: ESTABLISHMENT OF SOLE SOURCE PROVIDER:
The City of Skiatook, through its Fire Department/ambulance service/emergency medical service ("SFD" hereinafter), pursuant to 63 Oklahoma Statutes
section 2515 is hereby established as the "sole source provider" for ambulance service transports originating within the Municipal limits of the City of
Skiatook, Oklahoma. No other ambulances or ambulance services may respond to emergency medical calls originating within the City of Skiatook except
upon mutual aid requests from SFD or with the consent of the City of Skiatook/SFD, or except as set forth in subsection A of this section.
A. Exceptions: No ambulance or ambulance service may transport patients to or from the Municipal limits of the City of Skiatook, Oklahoma, or otherwise
respond to medical calls within the Municipal limits of the City of Skiatook, Oklahoma, except as provided by the following:
1. On a mutual or automatic aid request from SFD during such times as SFD cannot promptly and adequately respond to a request for emergency
medical services;
2. By request of City of Skiatook/SFD or with the consent of the City of Skiatook/SFD;
3. Any ambulance owned or operated by, or under contract to perform ambulance transport services for, the Federal or State government, or any
agency thereof;
4. Any ambulance owned and operated by a hospital and in use to transport a patient of the owner hospital, which patient has been admitted to and not
been discharged from the owner hospital, to or from another hospital or medical care facility at which the patient receives a diagnostic or therapeutic
procedure not available at the owner hospital;
5. Any ambulance engaged in a routine transport call to transport a patient from a hospital, nursing home, or dialysis center located within the Municipal
limits of the City of Skiatook to any location outside the Municipal limits of the City of Skiatook;
6. Any ambulance engaged in the transport of a patient from a location outside the Municipal limits of the City of Skiatook to a location inside the
Municipal limits of the City of Skiatook;
7. Any ambulance engaged in the interstate transport of a patient.
B. Mutual Aid Agreements Not Affected: Mutual aid agreements between the City of Skiatook/SFD and surrounding ambulance services/emergency
medical services are not affected by this section. (Ord. 2012-12, 10-30-2012)
Title 6
PUBLIC SAFETY AND NUISANCES
Chapter 1
POLICE DEPARTMENT
6-1-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby created a police department for the city, the head of which shall be the chief of police. (2011 Code)
6-1-2: CHIEF OF POLICE:
A. Appointment; Term: The chief of police shall be appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term, and is removable by the city manager. The chief of
police is an officer of the city. (Ord. 2013-20, 9-24-2013)
6-1-3: POLICE OFFICERS:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 48/269
A. Appointment: One or more police officers may be appointed by the chief of police upon approval by the city manager. All police officers are officers of
the city. (Ord. 2013-20, 9-24-2013)
6-1-4: POWERS AND DUTIES OF CHIEF AND OFFICERS:
A. Powers Generally: The chief of police and all police officers shall possess the powers, and be subject to the liabilities possessed and conferred by law
upon municipal police officers, in executing the orders of the city council, or enforcing the provisions of this code. All police officers shall be considered
officers of the city.
B. Enforcement Duties; Serve Warrants: It shall be the duty of the chief of police and/or all police officers to bring to justice all violators of city ordinances
and federal and state laws, and to turn such violators over to the proper authorities. The chief of police shall be responsible for the service of all
warrants, writs, executions and other processes, properly directed and delivered.
C. Other Duties: The chief of police and each police officer shall perform all other duties prescribed by law or ordinance. (2011 Code)
6-1-5: COMPENSATION:
The chief of police and each police officer shall be paid such compensation as the city council may prescribe. (2011 Code)
Chapter 2
FIRE DEPARTMENT
6-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
MUNICIPALITY: One which has qualified to participate in the firemen's relief and pension fund.
VOLUNTEER FIRE DEPARTMENT: One which has in its employ not more than two (2) full time salaried firefighters.
VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTER: One who is enrolled as a member of a fire department and who serves in said capacity without receiving a regular salary.
(1991 Code § 1-202)
6-2-2: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENTS:
A. Department Established; Scope Of Regulations: There is hereby established a fire department for the city providing officers therefor, defining their
duties, and defining the duties and powers of the members of the fire department, and establishing rules and regulations for the work of the fire
department, and the use of the firefighting equipment, and providing for a penalty for violation of any of the provisions hereof. (1991 Code § 1-201)
B. Fire Chief: The fire chief shall be appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term, and is removable by the city manager.
C. Assistant Fire Chief And Members: Assistant fire chief, and all members of the fire department, including volunteers, of the city may be appointed by the
fire chief upon approval by the city manager. (Ord. 2013-20, 9-24-2013)
6-2-3: ORGANIZATION OF DEPARTMENT:
The fire department shall consist of a chief of the department and two (2) assistant chiefs, and as many firefighters of the age of eighteen (18) years and
not more than forty (40) years old at the time of their election to membership, and who are citizens and residents of the city, as are or may be elected and
be approved by the city council; however, under no circumstances shall there be more than a total of twenty (20) members. (1991 Code § 1-204)
6-2-4: FIRE CHIEF AND ASSISTANT FIRE CHIEFS:
A. General Powers And Duties:
1. Powers And Duties Of Chief:
a. The chief shall be at the head of the department, subject to the laws of the state of Oklahoma, ordinances of the city and the rules and regulations
herein adopted.
b. The chief shall be held responsible for the general condition and efficient operation of the department, the training of members, and the
performance of all other duties imposed upon him.
c. The chief may inspect or cause to be inspected by members of the department, the fire hydrants, cisterns and other sources of water supply at
least twice a year.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 49/269
d. The chief shall maintain a library or file of publications on fire prevention and fire protection and shall make use of it to the best of advantage of all
members.
e. The chief shall make every effort to attend all fires and direct the officers and members in the performance of their duties.
f. The chief shall see that the citizens are kept informed on fire hazards in the community and on the activities of the department.
g. The chief shall see that each fire is carefully investigated to determine its cause, and, in the case of suspicion of incendiarism, shall notify the
proper authorities and secure and preserve all possible evidence for future use in the case.
2. Assistant Chief, Duties: In the absence of the chief, the assistant chief on duty shall command the department and be held responsible therefor in all
respects with the full powers and responsibilities of the chief. (1991 Code § 1-205)
B. General Supervisor: The chief of the fire department shall have the general supervision of the department when it is not in actual duty at a fire, which
supervisor shall be subject to, and not conflict with, such rules and bylaws for the government and management of the department as may from time to
time be adopted by the board of fire officers, as herein provided. (1991 Code § 1-223)
6-2-5: COMPANY OFFICERS:
A. Qualifications: The company officers shall be selected upon their ability to meet the following requirements:
1. Their knowledge of firefighting,
2. Their leadership ability,
3. Their knowledge of firefighting equipment. (1991 Code § 1-206; amd. 2011 Code)
B. Secretary And Treasurer:
1. One member elected by the fire department shall be secretary. His duties shall consist of the following:
a. Calling the roll at the opening of each meeting,
b. Keeping the minutes of each meeting,
c. Reporting once each month to the board of fire officers in accordance with such rules and regulations as may be established by said board.
If the secretary of any company neglects or refuses to make such report, the board of fire officers shall immediately prefer charges against such
delinquent secretary in accordance with the rules and regulations of said board.
2. One member elected by the fire department shall be treasurer. His duties shall consist of the following:
a. Collect any money due the department by the members,
b. Pay any bills owed by the firemen's fund as authorized by the fire board,
c. Report monthly to the firefighters, the status of their fund. (1991 Code § 1-207)
6-2-6: FIRE COMPANIES:
A. Division Into Companies: When the membership is large enough, the firefighters shall be divided into companies, such to consist of not more than
twenty (20) members of which not less than ten (10) must be employed in the city. (1991 Code § 1-219)
B. Transfer Membership Between Companies: When more than one company is formed, any member desiring to transfer his membership from one
company to another shall present to the board of fire officers a certificate in writing signed by the foremen and secretaries of both the companies
showing the consent of each company to the transfer. Upon receipt of such certificate, the board of fire officers shall permit or deny such transfer, their
decision being final and conclusive. (1991 Code § 1-220)
C. Company Officers: When more than one company is formed, each of the companies of the department shall and may choose from their own number a
foreman, assistant foreman and a secretary, in such manner and at such time or times as the board of fire officers may, in its rules and bylaws for the
government of the department, provide and prescribe. (1991 Code § 1-221)
D. Company Duties: It shall be the duty of said companies, so often as any fire shall break out, to respond immediately upon the alarm thereof to their
respective firehouses and to convey their apparatus to the place where the fire shall happen, unless otherwise directed by the chief or other officer who
may be in charge; and upon such direction, they shall return their apparatus well washed and cleaned to their several places of deposit. (1991 Code
§ 1-222)
6-2-7: BOARD OF FIRE OFFICERS:
A. Membership; Authority: The chief and assistant chiefs shall constitute a board of fire officers, who shall meet monthly or more frequently for the
