transaction of all business of the department, which board shall have entire and absolute control over and management of the department and its
government, when such department is not upon active duty, subject to the approval of the city council, to which approval the acts of said board of fire
officers shall only be subject as herein particularly and specifically provided. (1991 Code § 1-214)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 50/269
B. Adoption Of Bylaws And Rules: The board of fire officers is hereby authorized, empowered and required from time to time to adopt a code of bylaws
and rules for the control, management and government of the department, and for the regulating of the proceedings and business of the said board,
which code or codes of bylaws and rules, after adoption by such board, shall not become effective and operative until presented to and approved by
the city council. (1991 Code § 1-216)
C. Inspection Of Buildings: The board of fire officers is hereby authorized, empowered and required to inspect from time to time, but at least twice annually,
all buildings and premises where accumulations of combustible materials or other hazardous conditions are liable to exist and to order such changes or
removals as in their opinion are necessary to allow safety from fire. For purposes of inspection, they are hereby empowered to enter any and all
buildings and premises at any reasonable hour. (1991 Code § 1-217)
D. Keeping Records: The board of fire officers is required to devise forms or methods of keeping records and shall see that records are kept of all alarms
of fire, fire losses, methods of extinguishment, drills, hose, apparatus, minor equipment, condition of hydrants, starting of motors and inspections. (1991
Code § 1-218)
6-2-8: BYLAWS OF DEPARTMENT:
The bylaws of the department shall include:
A. All volunteer firefighters are required, when notified, to respond to alarms of fire and other emergencies.
B. Volunteers are required to be present at all regular meetings, call meetings, and schools presented for the benefit of the firefighters.
C. There shall be at least one regular business meeting each month.
D. Any volunteer firefighter having two (2) unexcused absences in succession or three (3) unexcused absences in a period of three (3) months, will be
dropped from the fire department rolls.
E. Volunteer firefighters leaving city for an extended period of time will be required to notify the chief.
F. Any volunteer firefighter refusing to attend training classes provided for him will be dropped from the fire department rolls.
G. Any volunteer member of the fire department shall be dropped from the rolls for any of the following offenses:
1. Conduct unbecoming a firefighter;
2. Any act of insubordination;
3. Neglect of duty;
4. Any violation of rules and regulations governing the fire department; or
5. Conviction of a felony. (1991 Code § 1-209)
6-2-9: COMPENSATION AND SALARIES:
A. Salary Of Chief And Assistant Chiefs: The chief and assistant chiefs of the fire department shall receive compensation as provided by the city council.
Such compensation will be in addition to the hourly rate as paid to all firefighters. (1991 Code § 1-210)
B. Compensation For Volunteer Members: Volunteer members of the fire department shall receive reimbursement for expenses incurred on a per call
basis as determined by the city manager for reporting to all called fires, assistance in automobile accidents when required, and certain other fires
located outside the corporate limits of the city. (Ord. 2014-02, 1-28-2014)
6-2-10: MEMBERSHIP REGULATIONS:
A. Propositions To Membership: The names of all persons elected to membership in the company or companies and proposed as members of the
department shall be presented through the board of fire officers in writing, signed by the foreman or secretary of the company in which they are so
elected, to be approved by the said board of fire officers previous to being presented, and no name not so approved shall be presented to the city
council for confirmation. (1991 Code § 1-212)
B. Resignation: All resignations from the department shall take the same course as elections and propositions to membership as provided for in subsection
A of this section. (1991 Code § 1-213)
C. Retirement: Any member of the department is eligible for retirement as provided under subsection 1-6-3B of this code. (1991 Code § 1-215)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 51/269
6-2-11: COMMAND IN ABSENCE OF CHIEF AND ASSISTANT CHIEFS:
Should the chief of the fire department and the assistant chiefs be absent from a fire, the person having charge of the apparatus first arriving at the fire
shall assume the duties of the chief until the arrival of his superior officer. (1991 Code § 1-225)
6-2-12: DEPARTMENTAL AUTHORITY, REQUIREMENTS AND SPECIFIC DUTIES:
A. Control At Scene Of Fire: In all cases of fire, the chief of the fire department or, in his absence, an assistant, shall have full power and absolute control
and command and cause the several pieces of apparatus to be worked in the most advantageous manner. (1991 Code § 1-224)
B. Monthly Report To City Council: It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to report monthly to the city council the condition of the various
pieces of apparatus and appurtenances, the number of hydrants and the condition of same, the number of fires during the month, their location, cause,
date of same and loss occasioned thereby; the number of members in each company and the total number of active members in the department, and
resignations and expulsions passed upon by the board of fire officers. (1991 Code § 1-226)
C. Authority: The chief of the fire department and his assistants or officers in command at any fire are hereby clothed with full and complete authority as
prescribed by law and are hereby authorized and directed to require and secure the removal of any and all obstructions from in front of and around fire
hydrants, and for such purpose are hereby authorized to call upon the head of any of the municipal departments for aid and assistance in securing
such removal of obstructions. (1991 Code § 1-227; amd. 2011 Code)
D. Care Of Fire Hoses:
1. Washing And Drying: It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to see that company officers have all hoses thoroughly washed and dried
after use at fires and drills, and that no wet or dirty hose is placed on the apparatus. (1991 Code § 1-228)
2. Maintenance: It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to see that company officers have all hoses on apparatus changed every thirty
(30) days if not otherwise used, and have water run through hoses every sixty (60) days. (1991 Code § 1-229)
3. Testing Of Hoses: It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to see that all new hoses are subjected to a test of two hundred (200)
pounds' hydrostatic pressure and that all hoses are tested annually at a hydrostatic pressure of one hundred fifty (150) pounds. (1991 Code § 1-232)
E. Operation Of Motors Of Vehicles: It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to see that company officers have the motors of all automobile
apparatus "turned over" and operated for five (5) minutes at least once each day and that a permanent record is kept of such operation at the company
quarters. (1991 Code § 1-230)
F. Heating Of Firehouse: It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to see that the company officers have the firehouses heated during the
winter season. (1991 Code § 1-231)
G. Report Defective Fire Hydrants:
1. It shall be the duty of the company officer in charge of his company at a fire or drill to report to the chief of the fire department all fire hydrants that
are found frozen, out of order, leaky, or that are set in such a manner as to make it difficult to connect thereto. (1991 Code § 1-233)
2. It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to make a permanent record of all reports of defective, inoperative or improperly set fire
hydrants, and he shall submit a report to the city council giving the location of the hydrant, name of the maker, with a specification of the troubles.
(1991 Code § 1-234)
H. Record Of Drill Service: It shall be the duty of the foreman of each company to keep a permanent record of the fire and drill service of each member of
his company. A copy of this record shall be submitted to the board of officers at the close of each year. (1991 Code § 1-235)
I. Appointment Of Drivers And Mechanics:
1. Drivers: It shall be the duty of the board of fire officers to appoint five (5) drivers for the automobile apparatus, who shall be thoroughly instructed in
the operation of the apparatus to which they are assigned. (1991 Code § 1-236)
2. Mechanics: It shall be the duty of the board of fire officers to appoint two (2) mechanics to each company, who shall be charged with the duty of
maintaining all the apparatus of the company in good condition and ready for immediate service. (1991 Code § 1-237)
J. Fire Apparatus:
1. Tampering With: No member of any company shall be permitted to tamper with, or fix, or repair any of the apparatus unless so directed by the chief
of the fire department or, in his absence, the assistant chief. (1991 Code § 1-238)
2. Driving: No member of any company shall drive the automobile apparatus except the regularly appointed drivers unless directed to do so by the
company officer or one of the chiefs, and then only in case of an emergency. (1991 Code § 1-239)
3. Unauthorized Handling: No person shall be allowed to enter any firehouse or handle any apparatus or implements belonging to the department
unless accompanied by an active member of the department. (1991 Code § 1-244)
4. Moving: No fire apparatus, during any fire or the report of any fire, shall be taken or moved out of its house unless the foreman, assistant foreman or
at least one member of the company to which the same shall belong shall be present and assent thereto. (1991 Code § 1-245)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 52/269
5. Hiring Out: No apparatus shall be let out for hire, or let in any case, except upon consent of the city and of the chief of the fire department and then
only in the case of a fire in an adjacent or neighboring municipality. (1991 Code § 1-246)
K. Attend Drills: It shall be the duty of each and every member to attend all drills of his company. Any member finding it impossible to drill, who makes
application prior to the drill hour, may be excused by his company officer, provided not more than one excuse is asked for consecutive drills, except in
case of sickness or disability. Absence from four (4) consecutive drills, except for the above causes, shall constitute a dismissal from the department.
Officers and call members will be fined one dollar ($1.00) for failure to report at fires and drills unless due notice has been given in advance, and such
money will be turned into the treasurer of the firemen's fund. (1991 Code § 1-241)
6-2-13: REQUEST FOR REPAIRS OR SUPPLIES:
All requests for repairs or supplies for the various companies of the department shall be presented to the board of fire officers for the approval or
recommendation of said board by the secretary of such companies at the time the monthly report mentioned in subsection 6-2-12B of this chapter is
presented, but in case any apparatus shall become so disabled that immediate repairs are necessary, the foreman or acting foreman of the company
operating such apparatus shall immediately report the condition of the same to the chief who is hereby empowered to have the same repaired at once.
(1991 Code § 1-240)
6-2-14: PRACTICE DRILLS:
A. Duty Of Chief To Call: It shall be the duty of the chief to call out for practice drill one or more companies of the department, and the said chief may,
whenever he deems it necessary, call out any or all such company or companies for such drills when and where he may think advisable, but each
company shall be drilled and trained not less than once each month except during the winter season. For any company, officer or member who is
reported to the board of fire officers for refusal or failure to respond to any such order, such company, officer or member shall be liable to a fine or to
suspension or expulsion as provided for by the rules and regulations of the board of fire officers. (1991 Code § 1-249)
B. Procedure: It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to arrange the drills and training so that they will include the proper and efficient use of
all appliances and apparatus, the quick handling, laying and raising of hose, handling of streams, use of shutoff nozzles, siamese connections, forcible
entry tools, salvage work, ladder work, lifesaving and modern methods of extinguishment. (1991 Code § 1-250)
6-2-15: REFUSAL TO OBEY ORDERS:
A. Foreman, Assistant Foreman: Any foreman, assistant foreman, or the member having charge of any fire company, while on fire duty, who shall refuse or
voluntarily neglect to obey or execute any orders from the officer in charge of any fire, shall, for such offense, be subject to a fine or suspension or
expulsion from the department by the board of fire officers in such manner and upon such hearing or trial as may be prescribed or provided by the
bylaws and rules of the board of fire officers. (1991 Code § 1-242)
B. Officers Or Members: Any officer or member of the department or any company or companies of the department who shall refuse or voluntarily neglect
to obey or execute any orders from the officer in charge of any fire, or who shall violate or wilfully neglect or refuse to be controlled, governed, or
managed by any of the rules and bylaws of the board of fire officers that may be adopted from time to time as herein provided, shall be subject to
suspension or expulsion from the department by the board of fire officers in such manner and upon such hearing or trial as may be prescribed or
provided by the bylaws and rules of the board of fire officers; the suspension or expulsion of any company member being subject to the approval of the
city council. (1991 Code § 1-243)
6-2-16: EXPULSION OR SUSPENSION OF MEMBERS:
A. Vote To Expel Or Suspend: If any of the companies shall vote for expulsion or suspension of any of its members, the result of such vote shall be
reported to the board of fire officers at their next meeting. (1991 Code § 1-247)
B. Appeal: The expelled or suspended member shall have the right to appear before the said board of fire officers and state cause (if any) why such
penalty should not be confirmed; and in case of the nonappearance, or in case his appeal is not sustained, the chief shall report his name to the city
council as expelled or suspended, as the case may be. (1991 Code § 1-248)
6-2-17: FAILURE TO PERFORM DUTY:
A. Charges; Trial: All charges for offenses or neglect of duty or insubordination while on duty at a fire that may be preferred against any company, officer or
member of the department shall be tried and determined by the board of fire officers, subject, however, to an appeal from such decision to the city
council who shall either confirm the action of the board of fire officers or refer the same back to them for retrial. (1991 Code § 1-251)
B. Retrial: In event of a retrial being ordered by the city council, the decision arrived at by the board of fire officers at such retrial shall be final, conclusive
and not subject to appeal. (1991 Code § 1-252)
6-2-18: FIRE RUNS WITHIN AND OUTSIDE SERVICE AREA:
A. Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
CENTER OF SKIATOOK: The Skiatook municipal building.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 53/269
FIRE PROTECTION: Providing fire extinguishing equipment and personnel for extinguishing fires, which service is also referred to in this service as
"fire runs".
SERVICE AREA: That territory as set forth by resolution 2013-11, passed and approved on April 30, 2013, by the city council of the city of Skiatook,
Oklahoma, and as may later be amended by resolution. (1991 Code § 1-275; amd. Ord. 2013-6, 4-30-2013)
B. Providing Fire Protection Service: Subject to the limitations set forth in this section, the city shall make fire runs within the service area when requested
to do so, subject, however, to the availability of equipment and personnel. (1991 Code § 1-276)
C. Priority Of Service: It shall be the policy of the city to grant priority in making fire runs to the corporate limits of the city of Skiatook, and fire protection
service will be provided in the event of a conflict to that area constituting the corporate limits of the city of Skiatook, to the exclusion, if necessary, of the
service area lying outside the corporate limits of the city. (1991 Code § 1-277)
D. Condition For Providing Service Outside Corporate Limits: The extension of fire protection service to the service area lying outside the corporate limits
of the city is expressly conditioned upon the availability of equipment and personnel, and be establishing the policies set forth in this section. The city
assumes no liability of any nature by reason of any inability to provide fire protection service to the area lying outside the corporate limits of the city.
(1991 Code § 1-278)
E. Nature Of Service: When fire runs are made to the service area lying outside the corporate limits of the city, the service provided shall consist only of
exercising the best efforts to extinguish the fire, and the service provided will not include remaining at the fire site until all smoldering debris and
embers are extinguished. (1991 Code § 1-279)
F. Incorporated Municipalities: Incorporated municipalities shall not be included in the service area; provided, however, that the city will continue to offer to
municipalities located with the service area aid and assistance upon request as it is able to do so. (1991 Code § 1-280)
G. Charges:
1. Charges for fire runs made to the service area lying outside the corporate limits of the city shall be in such sums as may hereinafter by established
by the city council by resolution; provided, however, that no emergency will be declined because of the inability of the person summoning help to pay
or because of the lack of any insurance coverage.
2. Until otherwise established by the city council, the minimum charge for fire runs to the service area lying outside the corporate limits of the city shall
be one hundred seventy five dollars ($175.00). (1991 Code § 1-281)
6-2-19: FIRE SERVICE SUBSCRIPTION; HAZARDOUS WASTE REMOVAL:
A. Subscription For Fire Service: Persons residing outside the corporate city limits and within the Skiatook fire department "service area", as defined in
subsection 6-2-18A of this chapter, may subscribe for fire service provided by the Skiatook fire department, subject to the following conditions and
limitations:
1. Fees created by this section may be changed by resolution of the city council from time to time.
2. Fees are due annually, on July 1, unless the fee is paid monthly through a surcharge on a utility bill as approved by the city council, nor shall the
subscription fee be prorated.
3. One subscription shall afford fire service to one individual residence and the real property on which the residence is situated, and contiguous
acreage owned in common, and shall be nontransferable to any other residence, property, structure or territory.
4. A current subscription shall allow the property covered by the subscription fire calls at no charge, other than what can be recovered from any
applicable insurance policy. (Ord. 2013-23, 11-12-2013)
B. Fees:
1. All fire runs, except those covered under subsections A4 and B2 of this section, shall be billed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per hour per unit
for all units deemed appropriate by the fire chief.
2. Mutual aid requested by other organized fire services shall not be billed.
3. Incidents involving hazardous materials shall be billed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per hour per unit, local personnel, and all costs, plus ten
percent (10%) administrative fees, for outside contractors and mutual aid of other services.
C. Hazardous Materials:
1. Definitions: For the purpose of this subsection C, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them herein:
HAZARDOUS WASTES: a. Waste that is subject to regulation as a hazardous waste under the federal resource conservation and recovery act, 42
USC section 6901 et seq., and regulations adopted pursuant thereto;
b. Waste that is subject to regulation as a hazardous waste under the Oklahoma hazardous waste management act1; or
c. Waste that is ignitable, corrosive, reactive or toxic as determined by testing for the characteristics of ignitability, corrosivity, reactivity or toxicity as
provided in 40 code of federal regulations sections 261.21 through 261.24.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 54/269
WASTES: At least twenty eight (28) gallons or two hundred twenty (220) pounds, whether liquid or solid, of discarded materials and byproducts
including, but not limited to, trash, refuse, garbage by all medical wastes, sewage, ash, sludge, deleterious substances, oil field wastes, commercial
and industrial wastes, and chemical wastes.
2. Liability Of Responsible Person: Whenever the fire department of the city is reasonably required or called upon to remove, clean up, dispel, wet
down or protect others or property from the hazards of wastes or hazardous wastes, any person, firm or corporation having a proprietary interest in,
or having control of, the waste shall be liable at the rate of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per hour per unit for all units dispatched to assist in
such cleanup or protection without regard to negligence or care.
D. Earmarking:
1. All revenues from subscriptions for fire service shall be accounted for in a capital improvements fund for the fire department.
2. All billed fire run revenues in excess of labor, cost and contract expenses, subsection B3 of this section, shall be accounted for at the end of the
city's fiscal year, and surpluses shall be placed in the capital improvements for the fire department. (Ord. 94-13, 10-11-1994)
ARTICLE A. FIRE PREVENTION BUREAU; PROTECTION AND ENFORCEMENT
6-2A-1: BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION:
A. Bureau Established: A bureau of fire prevention in the fire department of the city is hereby established which shall be operated under the supervision of
the chief of the fire department. (1991 Code § 1-253)
B. Chief Inspector Of Bureau: The chief of the department shall designate an officer (or member) of the department as chief inspector of the bureau, who
shall hold this office at the pleasure of the chief of the department. (1991 Code § 1-254)
C. Assistant Inspectors: The chief of the department may also designate such number of assistant inspectors as shall from time to time be authorized by
the city council. (1991 Code § 1-255)
D. Duties And Powers:
1. It shall be the duty of the officers of the bureau of fire prevention to enforce all laws and ordinances of the state, county, and city covering the
following:
a. The prevention of fires.
b. The storage and use of explosives and inflammables.
c. The installation and maintenance of automatic and other fire alarm systems, and fire extinguishing equipment.
d. The maintenance and regulation of fire escapes.
e. The means and adequacy of exits in case of fire, from factories, schools, hotels, lodging houses, asylums, hospitals, churches, halls, theaters,
amphitheaters, and all other places in which numbers of persons work, live or congregate, from time to time, for any purpose.
f. The investigation of the cause, origin and circumstances of fires.
2. Such officers of the bureau shall have such powers and perform such other duties as are set forth in other sections of this article, and as may be
conferred and imposed from time to time by law. (1991 Code § 1-256)
6-2A-2: DELEGATION OF POWERS:
The chief of the fire department (fire marshal) may delegate any of his powers or duties under this article to the chief inspector. (1991 Code § 1-257)
6-2A-3: RECOMMEND ORDINANCES:
It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to investigate and to recommend to the city council such additional ordinances as he may deem
necessary for safeguarding life and property against fire. (1991 Code § 1-258)
6-2A-4: CHIEF TO INSTRUCT INVESTIGATORS:
The chief of the fire department (fire marshal) shall prepare instructions for the chief inspector and his assistants and forms for their use in the reports
required by this article. (1991 Code § 1-259)
6-2A-5: BUREAU TO INVESTIGATE FIRES:
A. Investigation: The bureau of fire prevention shall investigate the cause, origin and circumstances of every fire occurring in the city by which property has
been destroyed or damaged and, so far as possible, shall determine whether the fire is the result of carelessness or design. Such investigations shall
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 55/269
be begun immediately upon the occurrence of such fire by the assistant in whose district the fire occurs, and if it appears to the officer making such
investigation that such fire is of suspicious origin, the chief of the fire department shall be immediately notified of the fact and he shall take charge
immediately of the physical evidence, shall notify the proper authorities designated by law to pursue the investigation of such matters, and shall further
cooperate with the authorities in the collection of evidence and in the prosecution of the case.
B. Report: Every fire shall be reported in writing to the bureau of fire prevention within two (2) days after the occurrence of the same, by the officer in
whose jurisdiction such a fire has occurred. Such report shall be in such form as shall be prescribed by the chief of the fire department, and shall
contain a statement of all facts relating to the cause, origin, and circumstance of such fire, the extent of the damage thereof, and the insurance upon
such property, and such other information as may be required. (1991 Code § 1-260)
6-2A-6: LICENSE FOR INFLAMMABLE MATERIALS:
Before licenses may be issued for the keeping, storage, use, manufacture, sale, handling, transportation, or other disposition of highly inflammable
materials and rubbish, crude, petroleum or any of its products, gun or blasting powder, dynamite, or explosives, the chief of the fire department, the chief
inspector, or his assistants, shall inspect and approve the receptacles, vehicles, buildings or storage places to be used for any such purposes. (1991 Code
§ 1-261)
6-2A-7: ADDITIONAL DUTIES OF CHIEF:
A. Inspection Of Hazardous Processes, Materials: The chief of the fire department, chief inspector, or an assistant specially designated thereto, shall
inspect, as often as may be necessary, but not less than four (4) times a year, all specially hazardous manufacturing processes, storage or installations
of acetylene or other gases, chemicals, oils, explosive and inflammable materials, all interior fire alarms and automatic sprinkler systems, and such
other hazards or appliances as the chief of the fire department shall designate and shall make such orders as may be necessary for the enforcement of
the laws and ordinances governing the same and for safeguarding of life and property from fire.
B. Inspection Of Buildings And Premises: It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to inspect, or cause to be inspected by the bureau of fire
prevention, or by the fire department officers and members as often as may be necessary, but not less than twice a year in outlying districts and four
(4) times a year in the closely built portions of the city, all buildings, premises and public thoroughfares, except the interiors of the private dwellings, for
purpose of ascertaining and causing to be corrected, any conditions liable to cause fire, or any violations of the provisions or intent of any ordinances of
the city affecting the fire hazard. (1991 Code § 1-262)
6-2A-8: PROCEDURE UPON DISCOVERY OF FIRE HAZARD:
A. Order For Removal: Whenever any inspector, as described in section 6-2A-7 of this article, shall find in any building or upon any premises or other
place combustible or explosive matter or dangerous accumulations of rubbish or rubble or unnecessary accumulation of wastepaper, boxes, shavings,
or any highly inflammable materials especially liable to fire, and which is so situated as to endanger property; or shall find obstructions to or on fire
escapes, stairs, passageways, doors or windows liable to interfere with the operations of the fire department or egress of occupants, in case of fire, he
shall order the same to be removed or remedied, and such order shall forthwith be complied with by the owner or occupant of such premises or
buildings, subject to appeal within twenty four (24) hours to the chief of the fire department as provided in subsection 6-2A-9B of this article. (1991
Code § 1-263)
B. Penalty For Failure To Comply With Order: Any owner or occupant failing to comply with such order within a reasonable period after the service of said
order shall be liable to a penalty as hereinafter provided. (1991 Code § 1-264)
C. Service Of Such Order: The service of any such order may be made upon the occupant of the premises to whom it is directed, either by delivering a
copy of same to such occupant personally or by delivering the same to and leaving it with any person in charge of the premises, or in case no such
person is found upon the premises, by affixing a copy thereof in a conspicuous place on the door to the entrance of the said premises. Whenever it
may be necessary to serve such an order upon the owner of the premises, such order may be served either by delivering to and leaving with the said
person a copy of the said order, or, if such owner is absent from jurisdiction of the officer making this order, by mailing such copy to the owner's last
known post office address, by certified mail. (1991 Code § 1-265)
6-2A-9: INSPECTIONS AND INVESTIGATIONS; APPEAL:
A. Inspection Upon Complaint; Voluntary Inspection: The chief of the fire department or inspector of the bureau of fire prevention, upon the complaint of
any person, or whenever he or they shall deem it necessary, shall inspect all buildings and premises within their jurisdiction. Whenever any of said
officers shall find any building or other structure which, for want of repairs, lack of or insufficient fire escapes, automatic or other fire alarm apparatus or
fire extinguishing equipment or by reason of age or dilapidated condition, or from any other cause, is especially liable to fire, and which is so situated as
to endanger other property or the occupants thereof, and whenever such officer shall find in any building combustible or explosive matter or
inflammable conditions dangerous to the safety of such buildings or the occupants thereof, he or they shall order such dangerous conditions or
materials to be removed or remedied, and such order shall forthwith be complied with by the owner or occupant of such premises or buildings. If such
order is made by the chief inspector or any of his assistant inspectors, such owner or occupant may, within twenty four (24) days, review such order
and file his decision thereon, and unless by his authority the order is revoked or modified, it shall remain in full force and be complied with within the
time fixed in said order or decision of the chief of the department. (1991 Code § 1-266)
B. Appeal From Order:
1. Provided, however, that any such owner or occupant may, within five (5) days after the making or affirming of any such order by the chief of the
department, file his petition with the municipal judge, praying a review of such order, and it shall be the duty of such court to hear the same within not
less than five (5) days nor more than ten (10) days from the time the petition is filed, and to make such order in the premises as right and justice may
require, and such decision shall be final.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 56/269
2. Such parties so appealing to the municipal judge shall file with said judge within two (2) days a bond in an amount to be fixed by the court, to be
approved by the judge, conditioned to pay all costs of such appeal in case such appellant fails to sustain his appeal of the same to be dismissed for
any cause. (1991 Code § 1-267)
C. Power To Enter Any Building: The chief of the fire department, the chief inspector, or any assistant inspector may, at all reasonable hours, and with the
consent of the owner or occupant, enter any building or premises within his jurisdiction for the purpose of making any inspection or investigation which,
under the provisions of this article, he or they may deem necessary to be made. (1991 Code § 1-268; amd. 2011 Code)
D. Assistance Of City Attorney In Investigation Of Fire: The city attorney, upon request of the bureau of fire prevention, shall assist the inspector in the
investigation of any fire which, in their opinion, is of suspicious origin. (1991 Code § 1-269)
6-2A-10: SCHOOL FIRE DRILLS:
It shall be the duty of the chief of the department to require teachers of public, private, and parochial schools and educational institutions to have one fire
drill each month and to keep all doors and exits unlocked during school hours. (1991 Code § 1-270)
6-2A-11: KEEPING RECORDS OF FIRES:
A. The chief of the department shall keep in his office of the bureau of fire prevention, a record of all fires and of all the facts concerning same, including
statistics as to the extent of such fires and the damage caused thereby, and whether such losses were covered by insurance, and if so, in what
amount.
B. Such record shall be made daily from the reports made by the inspectors under the provision of this article. All such records shall be public. (1991 Code
§ 1-271)
6-2A-12: ANNUAL REPORT OF BUREAU:
The annual report of the bureau of fire prevention shall be made on or before June 30, and transmitted to the city council. Such report shall contain all
proceedings under this article, with such statistics as the chief of the department may wish to include therein. The chief of the department shall also
recommend any amendments to this article which, in his judgment, shall be desirable. (1991 Code § 1-272)
6-2A-13: FAILURE TO PERFORM DUTIES:
Any officer referred to in this article who refuses or neglects to perform the duties herein imposed upon him shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor.
(1991 Code § 1-273)
6-2A-14: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article, or neglecting to comply with any order issued pursuant to any section thereof,
shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall forfeit and pay a fine of not more than fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each
offense, and in addition thereto a fine of not more than fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each day that said violation is permitted to exist beyond a reasonable
period after service of notice is provided. (1991 Code § 1-274)
ARTICLE B. OUTDOOR AND OPEN BURNING REGULATIONS
6-2B-1: PURPOSE:
The following provisions are intended to promote the public health, safety and welfare and to safeguard the health, comfort, living conditions, safety and
welfare of the citizens of the city of Skiatook due to the hazards attendant to open burning and outdoor burning. (Ord. 2013-11, 6-25-2013)
6-2B-2: APPLICABILITY:
A. This article applies to all outdoor burning and open burning within the city of Skiatook, regardless of zoning classification.
B. This article does not apply to grilling or cooking using charcoal, wood, propane or natural gas in cooking or grilling appliances.
C. This article does not apply to burning in a stove, furnace, fireplace or other heating device within a building used for human or animal habitation.
D. This article does not apply to the use of propane, acetylene, natural gas, gasoline or kerosene in a device intended for heating, construction or
maintenance activities. (Ord. 2013-11, 6-25-2013)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 57/269
6-2B-3: SEVERABILITY:
Should any portion of this article be declared unconstitutional or invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this article shall not be
affected or invalidated. (Ord. 2013-11, 6-25-2013)
6-2B-4: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this article, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
CAMPFIRE: A small outdoor fire intended for recreation or cooking but not including a fire intended for disposal of waste wood or refuse.
CLEAN WOOD: Natural wood which has not been painted, varnished or coated with a similar material; has not been pressure treated with preservatives;
and does not contain resins or glues as in plywood or other composite wood products.
CONSTRUCTION AND DEMOLITION WASTE: Building waste materials, including, but not limited to, waste shingles, insulation, lumber, treated wood,
painted wood, wiring, plastics, packaging, and rubble that results from construction, remodeling, repair, and demolition operations on a house, commercial
or industrial building, or other structure.
FIRE CHIEF: The chief of the Skiatook fire department or other person designated by the fire chief.
MUNICIPALITY: The incorporated city of Skiatook, Oklahoma.
OPEN BURNING: Kindling or maintaining a fire where the products of combustion are emitted directly into the ambient air without passing through a stack
or a chimney. This includes burning in a burn barrel.
OUTDOOR BURNING: Open burning or burning in an outdoor wood fired boiler or patio wood burning unit.
OUTDOOR WOOD FIRED BOILER: A wood fired boiler, stove or furnace that is not located within a building intended for habitation by humans or
domestic animals.
PATIO WOOD BURNING UNIT: A chimenea, patio warmer, other portable wood burning device, or permanent outdoor fireplaces and barbecues used for
outdoor recreation and/or heating.
REFUSE: Any waste material except trees, logs, brush, stumps, leaves, grass clippings, and other vegetative matter. (Ord. 2013-11, 6-25-2013)
6-2B-5: GENERAL PROHIBITION ON OPEN BURNING, OUTDOOR BURNING, AND REFUSE BURNING:
Open burning and outdoor burning are prohibited in the city of Skiatook unless such burning is specifically permitted by this article. (Ord. 2013-11, 6-25-
2013)
6-2B-6: OPEN BURNING OF REFUSE:
A. Open burning of refuse from a commercial or industrial establishment is prohibited.
B. Open burning of refuse from and at a one- or two-family dwelling or multi-family dwelling is prohibited.
C. Open burning of the following materials is prohibited:
1. Construction and demolition waste;
2. Hazardous substances including, but not limited to, batteries, household chemicals, pesticides, used oil, gasoline, paints, varnishes, and solvents;
3. Furniture and appliances;
4. Tires;
5. Any plastic materials including, but not limited to, nylon, PVC, ABS, polystyrene or urethane foam, and synthetic fabrics, plastic films and plastic
containers;
6. Newspapers or magazines;
7. Corrugated cardboard, container board, office paper;
8. Treated or painted wood including, but not limited to, plywood, composite wood products or other wood products that are painted, varnished or
treated with preservatives. (Ord. 2013-11, 6-25-2013)
6-2B-7: OPEN BURNING OF TREES, LOGS, BRUSH, STUMPS, LEAVES, AND GRASS CLIPPINGS:
A. Open burning of leaves and grass clippings is prohibited.
B. Open burning of trees, logs, brush, vegetative ground cover, and stumps is allowed only in accordance with all of the following conditions:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 58/269
1. Open burning may occur only on agriculturally zoned tracts of three (3) acres or more.
2. Except for barbecue, gas, and charcoal grills, no open burning shall be undertaken during periods when the governor of the state of Oklahoma or
board of county commissioners for the applicable county has issued a burning ban applicable to the area.
3. All allowed open burning shall be conducted in a safe, nuisance free manner, when wind, of twelve (12) miles per hour or less, and weather
conditions minimize adverse effects and do not create a health hazard on roadways or airfields. Open burning shall be conducted in conformance
with all local and state fire protection regulations.
4. Open burning under this section shall only be conducted at a location at least one hundred feet (100') from the nearest building which is not on the
same property for small campfires and at least two hundred fifty feet (250') from the nearest building which is not on the same property for all other
fires.
5. Except for campfires, open burning shall only be conducted between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) P.M.
6. Open burning shall be constantly attended and supervised by a competent person of at least eighteen (18) years of age until the fire is extinguished
and is cold. The person shall have readily available for use such fire extinguishing equipment as may be necessary for the total control of the fire.
7. No materials may be burned upon any street, curb, gutter or sidewalk.
8. Except for barbecue, gas, and charcoal grills, no burning shall be undertaken within twenty five feet (25') from any combustible material, combustible
wall or partition, exterior window opening, exit access or exit unless authorized by the fire chief.
9. No open burning may be conducted on days when the department of environmental quality has declared an "ozone alert" for Tulsa, Osage, or
Washington County. (Ord. 2013-11, 6-25-2013)
6-2B-8: OUTDOOR WOOD FIRED BOILERS:
No person shall install, use, or maintain an outdoor wood fired boiler within the city of Skiatook. (Ord. 2013-11, 6-25-2013)
6-2B-9: PATIO WOOD BURNING UNITS:
A patio wood burning unit may be installed and used in the city of Skiatook only in accordance with all of the following provisions:
A. The patio wood burning unit shall not be used to burn refuse.
B. The patio wood burning unit shall burn only clean wood.
C. The patio wood burning unit shall be located at least one hundred feet (100') from the nearest structure which is not on the same property as the patio
wood burning unit.
D. The patio wood burning unit shall not cause a nuisance to neighbors. (Ord. 2013-11, 6-25-2013)
6-2B-10: FIRE SUPPRESSION TRAINING:
Notwithstanding sections 6-2B-5 and 6-2B-6 of this article, structures and other materials may be burned for fire prevention training by the Skiatook fire
department only in accordance with all of the following provisions:
A. Burning must be exclusively for fire suppression training. The burning shall not be used as a means to dispose of waste material, including tires and
other hazardous materials.
B. Any standing structure that will be used in fire suppression training must be inspected by a licensed asbestos inspector. A notification of this inspection
shall be submitted to the Oklahoma department of environmental quality at least ten (10) business days prior to burning a standing structure.
C. All asbestos must be removed from a structure prior to conducting the fire suppression training. If the structure is a residential dwelling, the owner may
remove the asbestos or have it removed by a licensed abatement contractor. If it is a commercial building, all asbestos must be removed by a licensed
abatement contractor.
D. All ash shall be disposed of in an approved landfill or at an alternate location approved by the Oklahoma department of environmental quality.
E. Asphalt shingles and asphalt or plastic siding shall be removed prior to the fire suppression training unless the fire chief determines that they are
necessary and beneficial for training.
F. At least seven (7) days before a planned practice burn, residents within two thousand feet (2,000') of the site of the proposed burn shall be notified.
G. All fire suppression training should conform to the guidelines established by the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) standard on live fire
evolutions (NFPA 1403). (Ord. 2013-11, 6-25-2013)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 59/269
6-2B-11: BURNING NOTIFICATION:
A. Any person desiring to burn trees, logs, brush, or other vegetative debris under section 6-2B-7 of this article shall notify the Skiatook fire department of
their intent to burn, and shall furnish their name, the location of the open burning and telephone number to the Skiatook fire department.
B. When weather or safety conditions warrant, the fire chief may temporarily suspend open burning. (Ord. 2013-11, 6-25-2013)
6-2B-12: LIABILITY:
A person utilizing or maintaining an outdoor fire shall be responsible for all fire suppression costs and any other liability resulting from damage caused by
the fire. (Ord. 2013-11, 6-25-2013)
6-2B-13: RIGHT OF ENTRY AND INSPECTION:
The fire chief, fire marshal, police officer or any authorized officer or agent of the city of Skiatook may inspect any property either prior to, during or after an
occurrence of open burning or outdoor burning for the purpose of ascertaining compliance with the provisions of this article. (Ord. 2013-11, 6-25-2013)
6-2B-14: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY:
A. The fire chief, fire marshal and Skiatook police department are authorized to enforce the provisions of this article.
B. Any person, firm, association, partnership, corporation, or governmental entity who violates any of the provisions of this article or fails to comply with a
duly authorized order issued pursuant to this article shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction, such offense shall be punishable pursuant to
section 1-4-1 of this code.
C. Upon conviction of an offense in violation of this article, the offender shall pay costs which may include all expenses, direct and indirect, which the city
of Skiatook has incurred in connection with the municipal infraction. In addition, the city shall have the right to proceed in any court of competent
jurisdiction for the purpose of obtaining an injunction, restraining order, or other appropriate remedy to compel compliance with the provisions of this
article. Each day that a violation of this article exists shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2013-11, 6-25-2013)
Chapter 3
CIVIL DEFENSE ORGANIZATION
6-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
CIVIL DEFENSE: The preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency functions other than functions for which primary responsibility is assigned
elsewhere by federal, state, or local law or ordinance, to protect the public peace, health, and safety, and to preserve lives and property, in the city of
Skiatook, Oklahoma, during any emergency resulting from enemy attack, sabotage or other hostile action, or from any flood, drought, fire, hurricane,
earthquake, storm or other catastrophe in or near the city of Skiatook, Oklahoma, and involving imminent or actual peril to life and property in the city of
Skiatook, Oklahoma. The functions include administration, organization, planning, recruiting, training, education, information, welfare service, police
service, warden service, fire service, rescue service, medical service, health service, transportation service, communication service, streets and sewers
service, utilities service, general engineering service, plant protection service, supply service, mutual aid, mobile support, evacuation, and all other
functions necessary or incidental to the preparation for and carrying out of the foregoing functions.
The term "civil defense", when used in this chapter, shall be synonymous with the term "emergency management".
ENEMY CAUSED EMERGENCY: Any state of emergency caused by actual or impending attack, sabotage or other hostile action, anywhere within the
United States, and involving imminent peril to lives and property in the city of Skiatook, Oklahoma. Such emergency shall be deemed to continue to exist
until the foregoing mayor shall declare its termination by public proclamation, or until the city council shall declare its termination by resolution.
NATURAL EMERGENCY: Any state of emergency caused by any actual or impending flood, drought, fire, hurricane, earthquake, storm, or other
catastrophe in or near the city of Skiatook, Oklahoma, and involving imminent peril to lives and property in the city of Skiatook, Oklahoma. Such
emergency shall be deemed to exist and to be terminated under the same condition as prescribed for an "enemy caused" emergency. (1991 Code § 1-
700; amd. 2011 Code)
6-3-2: CIVIL DEFENSE AUTHORITY:
There is hereby established within the executive branch of the city government a civil defense administration. This office shall consist of:
A. Director: A director of civil defense, who shall be appointed by the governing body and shall serve at their pleasure or until the repeal of this chapter.
The director shall be the executive head of the office of civil defense, and shall be responsible to the city council for carrying out the civil defense
program of the city. He shall coordinate the activities of all organizations for civil defense within the city, and shall maintain liaison with and cooperate
with civil defense agencies and organizations of other governmental units both within and without the state of Oklahoma, and of the federal
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 60/269
government, and shall have such additional authority, duties, and responsibilities as may be authorized under this chapter, or amendments thereof.
(1991 Code § 1-701; amd. 2011 Code)
B. Advisory Committees: Such other volunteer civil defense advisory committees as may be created by the director, for the evaluation of technical,
professional, or other phases of the work of the office of civil defense, and which may provide advisory assistance on any matters pertaining to the
city's civil defense. (1991 Code § 1-701)
6-3-3: DIRECTOR OF CIVIL DEFENSE:
A. Responsibilities: The director of civil defense shall have general direction and control of the office of civil defense, and shall be responsible for carrying
out the provisions of this chapter. In so carrying out the provision of this chapter, the director is expressly authorized to cooperate, insofar as permitted
by other appropriate legislation, with the federal government, the governments of Oklahoma, and its subdivisions, with other states and their
subdivisions and with private agencies, in all matters pertaining to civil defense in the city. (1991 Code § 1-703)
B. General Powers: Prior to an emergency as defined in this chapter, the director shall have the following powers:
1. To make recommendations to the city council with respect to orders, rules and regulations for the purpose of accomplishing the purposes of the
office of the civil defense director, having due consideration to the plans and powers of the federal government, the government of Oklahoma and
other public and private agencies and organizations empowered to act in either enemy caused emergencies or natural emergencies.
2. To prepare for consideration by the city council comprehensive plans for the civil defense of the city in both enemy caused and natural emergencies,
such plans and programs of the federal government, of the government of Oklahoma, and of other public and private agencies and organizations
empowered to act in either enemy caused or natural emergencies.
3. To make recommendations to the city council for public warning systems and other acceptable warning devices.
4. To establish and carry out recruitment and training programs as may be necessary to develop an adequate, qualified civil defense volunteer corps.
5. To conduct drills, exercises, and similar programs as may be necessary to develop a well trained, alert, fully prepared civil defense organization.
6. To make such studies and surveys of the industries, resources, and facilities of the city as he deems necessary to ascertain its capabilities for civil
defense, and plan for the most efficient emergency use thereof.
7. To recommend to the city council the formation of mutual aid arrangements with surrounding communities.
8. To delegate any administrative authority vested in him under this chapter and to provide for the subdelegation of any such authority.
9. To take any other action proper and lawful under his authority to prepare for either an enemy caused or natural emergency. (1991 Code § 1-704)
C. Enemy Caused Emergency Powers: In the event any actual enemy caused emergency, as proclaimed by the mayor, the civil defense director, with the
approval of the mayor, may exercise, during such emergency, the power to enforce all rules and regulations relating to civil defense, and acting under
the authority of statutes now in force or to be enacted, or under the authority of the mayor as an agent of the governor of the state of Oklahoma, may
take control of all means of transportation and communications, all stocks, fuel, food, clothing, medicine, and supplies, and all facilities including
buildings and plants, and exercise all powers necessary to secure the safety and protection of the civilian population. In exercising such powers, he
shall be guided by regulations and orders issued by the federal government and the governor of the state of Oklahoma, relating to civil defense and
shall take no action contrary to orders which may be issued by the governor under similar emergency powers. (1991 Code § 1-705)
D. Natural Emergency Powers: In the event of any natural emergency as proclaimed by the mayor, the director of civil defense, with the approval of the
mayor and acting under his instructions, shall coordinate in every way proper the activities of the civil defense organization. He is specifically charged
in such emergency with the collection, evaluation and dissemination of information to all agencies, both public and private, participating in the city's civil
defense organization or cooperating in any such emergency. He shall, as director, have the power to recommend appropriate action, but he shall not
otherwise have control over the participating agencies. He shall also recommend to the mayor the allocation of any funds received from the federal or
state governments or from any other source to alleviate distress and aid in restoring normal conditions. (1991 Code § 1-706)
6-3-4: NONLIABILITY DURING EMERGENCY:
Neither the city, nor any officer or member of the civil defense organization provided for in this chapter, shall be liable for personal injury or property
damage sustained by any person appointed or acting as a volunteer civil defense worker or member of any agency engaged in civil defense activity prior
to or during either an enemy caused or natural emergency. Nor shall the city or any such officer or member be liable for the death or injury of any person,
or damage to property, resulting from such civil defense activity prior to or during either an enemy caused or natural emergency. (1991 Code § 1-707)
6-3-5: ACCEPTANCE OF SERVICES, GIFTS:
Whenever the federal government or the state of Oklahoma, or any person, firm or corporation shall offer to the city any services, equipment, supplies,
materials, or funds by way of gift, grant, or loan, for purposes of civil defense, the mayor may accept such offer and may authorize the director of civil
defense to receive same subject to the terms of the offer and the rules and regulations, if any, of the agency making the offer. (1991 Code § 1-708)
6-3-6: OFFICE SPACE, FURNITURE AND SUPPLIES:
Appropriate office space, furniture, equipment, and supplies as required shall be provided for the office of civil defense. Expenditures for these purposes,
within the appropriations therefor, shall be made only on the authority of the city council. The director shall also, within the appropriations therefor,
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 61/269
establish a primary and one or more secondary control centers, as he deems necessary to serve during an enemy caused or a natural emergency. (1991
Code § 1-702)
6-3-7: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter, or who shall fail to carry out any of the provisions of this chapter or to comply therewith, or with
any of the orders, rules, or regulations made under the authority hereof, shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of
this code. (1991 Code § 1-709; amd. 2011 Code)
Chapter 3A
PUBLIC SAFETY CAPITAL FEE
6-3A-1: PUBLIC SAFETY CAPITAL FEE ESTABLISHED:
A. There is hereby established a public safety capital fee effective February 1, 2014, in the amount of three dollars ($3.00) per month, per utility customer
of the city of Skiatook/Skiatook public works authority lying within the municipal limits of the city of Skiatook, Oklahoma, whether such customer
receives electric service, water service, sanitary sewer service, refuse collection service, or any combination of utility services.
B. The public safety capital fee shall be assessed monthly to every residential utility customer, multi-family dwelling utility customer, commercial or
industrial utility customer. The public safety capital fee is to be charged and collected by the city of Skiatook/Skiatook public works authority in the same
manner as existing electric, water, sewer, refuse, and other utility fees and charges.
C. Only one monthly public safety capital fee shall be assessed per each separate utility bill regardless of the utility service, or any combination thereof,
received by the customer. Customers having multiple utility accounts shall be assessed the public safety capital fee for each separate utility bill. (Ord.
2013-24, 12-30-2013)
D. Public utility providers which have multiple utility accounts and receive a separate utility bill for electrical service, the sole purpose of which is to provide
electricity to power equipment related to the provision of public utilities, shall not be assessed an additional public safety capital fee on such separate
utility bill. This exception shall not be deemed to exclude the public safety capital fee assessed on other utility accounts or utility bills of the public utility
provider under this chapter which do not fall under this exception.
E. Wholesale water customers, including, but not limited to, statutory rural water districts which purchase potable water from the Skiatook public works
authority and/or city of Skiatook pursuant to contract and receive water purchased through a master water meter and then resell such potable water to
its customers, shall not be assessed an additional public safety capital fee on such billing for wholesale water. This exception shall not be deemed to
exclude the public safety capital fee which would otherwise be assessed on other utility accounts or utility bills of the wholesale water customer under
this chapter which do not fall under this exception. (Ord. 2014-14, 5-13-2014)
6-3A-2: ESTABLISHMENT OF PUBLIC SAFETY CAPITAL FUND:
A. There is hereby created a separate revenue fund denoted as the public safety capital fund. Only funds collected by the monthly public safety capital fee
shall be deposited into the public safety capital fund. The city of Skiatook/Skiatook public works authority shall deposit at least monthly, the public
safety capital fees remitted. (Ord. 2013-24, 12-30-2013)
6-3A-3: EXPENDITURES AUTHORIZED:
The public safety capital fund is to be utilized only for the purchase of equipment, vehicles, and apparatus for police and fire departments, ambulance/EMS
service, and any repairs or improvements to the same, or for any capital expenditure related to the provision of emergency services. All expenditures from
the public safety fund, regardless of amount, must be authorized and approved by the city council. (Ord. 2013-24, 12-30-2013)
Chapter 4
OFFENSES AND NUISANCES
6-4-1: ADOPTION OF STATE STATUTES:
A. Adoption: The city hereby adopts by reference the following state statutes:
1. Title 21: All misdemeanor offenses now contained or hereafter contained in 21 Oklahoma Statutes.
2. Title 47: All misdemeanor traffic offenses now contained or hereafter contained in 47 Oklahoma Statutes.
3. Title 37: All misdemeanor offenses now contained or hereafter contained in 37 Oklahoma Statutes.
4. Title 63: All misdemeanor offenses now contained or hereafter contained in 63 Oklahoma Statutes.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 62/269
B. Penalty For Violation: The violation of any section of any such statutes hereby adopted by reference constitutes an offense against the city and, upon
conviction thereof, the guilty person shall be subject to punishment as set forth in section 1-4-1 of this code. (2011 Code)
6-4-2: INVESTIGATION OF OFFENSES BY POLICE:
A. Definition: "Police officer" shall mean any duly appointed and sworn full time officer of the regular police department whose duties are to preserve the
public peace, protect life and property, prevent crime, serve warrants, enforce all laws and municipal ordinances, and who is authorized to bear arms in
the execution of such duties; provided, however, that any person in the regular police department who is a member of the police pension and
retirement system on the effective date hereof shall remain a member thereof subject to all conditions prescribed for membership in the system.
B. Duty To Investigate: It shall be the duty of the police department to investigate offenses of the city ordinances, state and federal laws, and to arrest and
to assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with violations of law. (2011 Code)
ARTICLE A. OFFENSES BY OR AGAINST PUBLIC OFFICERS OR GOVERNMENT
6-4A-1: ESCAPE OR AIDING ESCAPE:
A. Escape: It is unlawful for any person confined in the city jail or other place of confinement by the city, or working upon the streets or other public places
of the city in pursuance of any judgment, or otherwise held in legal custody by authority of the city, to escape or attempt to escape from any such jail,
prison, or custody.
B. Aiding Escape Or Providing Contraband: It is unlawful for any person, in any unlawful manner, to set at liberty, rescue, or attempt to set at liberty or
rescue, any prisoner or prisoners, from any officer or employee of the city having legal custody of the same or from the city jail or other place of
confinement by the city; to assist such prisoner in any manner to escape from such prison or custody; to convey to a prisoner any instrument or thing
which could facilitate his escape; to bring contraband into the municipal jail or to furnish to a prisoner any alcoholic beverage or narcotics; or to loiter
about the city jail or other place where prisoners are held without consent of the officer in charge. (2011 Code)
6-4A-2: REFUSAL TO ASSIST:
A. Calling For Assistance: An officer of the city making or about to make an arrest, or executing or about to execute a warrant or other process, in
accordance with the ordinances of the city or with state or federal law, or suppressing or about to suppress a riot, affray, or unlawful assembly, may call
upon a person or persons to assist him in making such arrest, executing such process, or suppressing such riot, affray, or unlawful assembly.
B. Failure To Assist: It is unlawful for any person lawfully called upon to assist an officer of the city to refuse or fail to do so. (2011 Code)
6-4A-3: RESISTING OR OBSTRUCTING OFFICER:
It is unlawful for any person knowingly or wilfully to resist, oppose, or obstruct the chief of police, any other police officer, the municipal judge, or other
officer or employee of the city in the discharge of his official duties; or, by threats or otherwise, to intimidate or attempt to intimidate any such officer or
employee from the discharge of his official duties; or to assault or beat, or revile, abuse, be disrespectful to, or use abusive or indecent language toward or
about, any such officer or employee while such officer or employee is in the discharge of his official duties. (2011 Code)
6-4A-4: IMPERSONATING OFFICER OR EMPLOYEE:
It is unlawful for any person to impersonate any officer or employee of the city, falsely represent himself to be an officer or employee of the city, or exercise
or attempt to exercise any of the duties, functions, or powers of an officer or employee of the city without being duly authorized to do so. (2011 Code)
6-4A-5: FALSE INFORMATION OR ALARMS:
A. False Information: It is unlawful for any person or any agent or employee thereof, knowingly to make any material misrepresentation to any officer,
employee, or agency of the city government in any official application to, or official dealing or negotiation with, such officer or agency; or to commit
perjury before any tribunal or officer of the city.
B. False Alarm: It is unlawful for any person to turn in a false fire alarm, or in any manner to deceive or attempt to deceive the fire department or any officer
or employee thereof with reference to any fire alarm or reported fire, or knowingly to cause the fire department or its officers or employees to make a
useless run.
C. False Reporting Of Crime: It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully, knowingly and without probable cause make a false report to any person of any
crime, which report causes or encourages the exercise of police action by any law enforcement officer. (2011 Code)
6-4A-6: EXCESSIVE FALSE ALARMS:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 63/269
A. Purpose: While recognizing the value of effective alarm systems in deterring crime and preventing fire loss, and while encouraging the use of such
alarm systems, it is the purpose of this section to prohibit excessive false alarms and to reduce, insofar as possible, the misuse of emergency public
services.
B. Definition: As used herein, "excessive false alarm" means:
1. Four (4) police responses to false alarms at the same location within one calendar month;
2. More than four (4) police responses to false alarms at the same location within a six (6) month period; or
3. More than six (6) police responses to false alarms at the same location within a twelve (12) month period.
C. False Alarm Described: For the purpose of this section, a "false alarm" includes those calls by the following:
1. Error or mistake. Any action by any person, firm, corporation or other entity, or agent thereof, owning or occupying any dwelling, building or place
which results in the activation of any alarm system while no emergency exists.
2. Malfunction. Any activation of any alarm system caused by a flaw in the normal operation, design, installation, maintenance of the system, faulty
equipment, or a change in the environment or premises upon or within which the alarm system is operating.
3. Intentional misuse. Any intentional activation of an alarm system when no burglary, robbery, vandalism, fire or other emergency is in progress.
D. Alarms Not Considered False Alarm: For the purpose of this section, an alarm shall not be considered a false alarm if it is determined that the alarm
was caused by any of the following:
1. Natural or manmade catastrophe or act of God, including tornadoes, floods, earthquakes or similarly violent conditions.
2. Vandalism causing physical damage to the premises.
3. Telephone line outage.
4. Attempted entry of a location causing visible physical or other evidence of damage to such location.
5. Severe weather causing physical damage to the premises.
6. The testing of a local/audible alarm system by a licensed alarm business agent or employee who is present at the premises, servicing, repairing, or
installing the alarm when such testing does not result in the alarm being activated for an uninterrupted period exceeding sixty (60) seconds.
E. Violation: It is a violation of law for a facility to have excessive false alarms. In such an event, the occupant and/or owner of the facility shall be guilty of
an offense against the city.
F. Good Faith Effort Considered: In the event of a violation of this section, the municipal judge shall consider good faith efforts to prevent future violations
prior to imposing sentence for the violation hereof. (2011 Code)
6-4A-7: BARRICADE REMOVAL:
It is unlawful for any person, except by proper authority, to remove any barricade or obstruction placed by authority of the city to keep traffic off any
pavement, street, curb, sidewalk or other area. (2011 Code)
6-4A-8: OBSTRUCTING OR TAMPERING WITH HYDRANTS:
A. Obstructing: No person shall place or cause to be placed upon or about any fire hydrant any rubbish, plant, building material, fence or other obstruction
of any character whatsoever, nor shall any person fasten to a fire hydrant any guyrope, cable, or brace, nor park any vehicle nearer than fifteen feet
(15') to a fire hydrant.
B. Tampering With: No person shall, without authority, turn on any water plug or fire hydrant, as the same is generally known and designated, nor shall in
any way damage, injure, tamper with, or interfere with any such water plug or fire hydrant. (2011 Code)
ARTICLE B. OFFENSES AGAINST THE PERSON, PUBLIC PEACE
6-4B-1: ASSAULT AND BATTERY:
A. Definitions: As referred to in this section, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
ASSAULT: Any wilful and unlawful attempt or offer, with force or violence, to do a corporal hurt to another.
BATTERY: Any wilful and unlawful use of force or violence upon the person of another, except as qualified in subsection B of this section and subject to
the exceptions and qualifications contained herein.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 64/269
B. Force Against Another Allowed In Certain Instances: To use or attempt to offer to use force or violence upon or toward the person of another is not
unlawful in the following cases:
1. When necessarily committed by a public officer in the performance of any legal duty, or by any other person assisting him or acting by his direction.
2. When necessarily committed by any person in arresting one who has committed any felony and delivering him to a public officer competent to
receive him in custody.
3. When committed either by the party about to be injured or by any other person in his aid or defense, in preventing or attempting to prevent an
offense against his person, or any trespass or any other unlawful interference with real or personal property in his lawful possession; provided, the
force or violence used is not more than sufficient to prevent such offense.
4. When committed by a parent or authorized agent of any parent, or by any guardian, master, or teacher in the exercise of lawful authority to restrain
or correct his child, ward, apprentice, or scholar, provided restraint or correction has been rendered necessary by the misconduct of the child, ward
apprentice, or scholar, or by his refusal to obey the lawful command of such parent, authorized agent, guardian, master, or teacher, and the force or
violence used is reasonable in manner and moderate in degree.
5. When committed by a carrier of passengers, or the authorized agent or servants of such carrier, or by any person assisting him at their request in
expelling from any carriage, railroad car, or other vehicle any passenger who refuses to obey a lawful and reasonable regulation prescribed for the
conduct of passengers, if such vehicle has first been stopped and the force and violence used is not more than sufficient to expel the offending
passenger with a reasonable regard to his personal safety.
6. When committed by any person in preventing a person who is impaired by reason of mental retardation or developmental disability, a mentally ill
person, insane person, or other person of unsound mind, including persons temporarily or partially deprived of reason, from committing an act
dangerous to himself or to another, or enforcing such restraint as is necessary for his restoration to health, during such period only as is necessary to
obtain legal authority for the restraint or custody of his person. (2011 Code)
6-4B-2: PREVENTING WITNESS FROM GIVING TESTIMONY:
Every person who wilfully prevents any person from giving testimony or threatens physical or mental harm through force or fear with the intent to prevent
the witness from appearing in municipal court to give his testimony, or to alter his testimony, is guilty of an offense against the city. (2011 Code)
6-4B-3: DESTROYING EVIDENCE:
Every person who, knowing that any book, paper, record, instrument in writing, or other matter or thing, is about to be produced in evidence upon any trial,
proceeding, inquiry or investigation whatever, authorized by law, wilfully destroys the same, with intent thereby to prevent the same from being produced,
is guilty of an offense against the city. (2011 Code)
6-4B-4: POSSESSION OR USE OF LASER POINTING DEVICE:
A. Injury To Another: It shall be unlawful for any person to focus, point or shine a laser beam directly or indirectly on another person or animal in such a
manner as to harass, annoy or injure said person or animal.
B. Possession By Minor Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to possess a laser pointing device. A person
shall not be in violation of this section if his possession of a laser pointing device is necessary for his employment, trade or occupation and it is
necessary for the pointer to be carried on his person. (2011 Code)
6-4B-5: DISTURBING RELIGIOUS MEETINGS:
A. Acts Constituting Disturbance: The following are the acts deemed to constitute disturbance of a religious meeting:
1. Uttering any profane discourse, committing any rude or indecent act, or making any unnecessary noise, either within the place where such meeting
is held, or so near it as to disturb the order and solemnity of the meeting.
2. Exhibiting, within one mile, any shows or plays without a license by the proper authority.
3. Engaging in, or aiding or promoting within the like distance, any racing of animals or gaming of any description.
4. Obstructing in any manner, without authority of law, within the like distance, the free passage along any highway to the place of such meeting.
B. Disturbing Religious Worship Prohibited: It is unlawful for any person to wilfully disturb, interrupt or disquiet any assemblage of people met for religious
worship, by any of the acts or things enumerated in subsection A of this section. (2011 Code)
6-4B-6: USE OF PROFANE OR ABUSIVE LANGUAGE:
It is unlawful for any person to make use of any profane, violent, abusive or insulting language toward or about another person, in the presence or hearing,
which language, in its common acceptation, is calculated to arouse to anger the person about or to whom it is spoken or addressed, or to cause a breach
of the peace or an assault. Every such person shall be deemed guilty of a breach of the peace. (2011 Code)
6-4B-7: NOISE DISTURBANCES:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 65/269
A. Disturbing The Peace: It is unlawful for any person to wilfully or maliciously disturb, either by day or night, the peace and quiet of the city, family or
person by loud or unusual noise, or by abusive, violent, obscene or profane language, whether addressed to the parties so disturbed or to some other
person, or to threaten to kill, do bodily harm, or injure, destroy property, fight or quarrel, or challenge to fight, or shoot off any firearms, or brandish the
same.
B. Animal Noises; Penalty For Violation: It is unlawful to allow the habitual howling, yelping, barking or other annoyance by the owner, keeper or possessor
of any dog or other animal. Upon determination that an individual is in violation of this section, such individual shall be given an oral warning that such
noise is a violation of law. A warning to any one occupant of a residence is considered to be a warning to all residents or occupants of the premises. A
subsequent violation within the next fourteen (14) days may result in a citation being issued. Upon the first conviction for the violation of this section,
the maximum penalty is a suspended sentence. Upon conviction for subsequent violations of this section, a fine shall be imposed not to exceed fifty
dollars ($50.00).
C. Investigation And Arrest: It shall be the duty of the police department to investigate all disturbances of the peace, to arrest where, in the officer's
judgment, it is proper and lawful to arrest, and to assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with violations of this section.
D. Issuance Of Citation: Upon the arrest of a citizen within the limits of the city on a disturbance of the peace charge, the arresting officer may take the
violator's name, address and other appropriate information and issue to him in writing a citation to answer to the charge against him at the municipal
court if the accused gives his promise in writing to appear voluntarily. In all other instances, the arresting officer is authorized to arrest the accused
pursuant to regular procedure.
E. Payment Of Fine: Any person who has received any citation to appear in answer to a disturbance of the peace charge under the ordinances of the city
may, within the time specified in the citation, answer at the municipal court clerk's office to the charge set forth in such citation, by paying a fine of one
hundred dollars ($100.00) plus court costs, or such person may appear before the municipal court, or, in case of violation of subsection B of this
section, may pay a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00), plus court costs, or appear before the municipal court.
F. Question Of Guilt: No person shall pay a fine at the municipal court clerk's office in accordance with subsection E of this section where such person
questions his guilt of the offense charged. Upon any question of guilt, the accused must appear before the municipal court. (2011 Code)
6-4B-8: UNLAWFUL ASSEMBLY:
It shall be unlawful and shall constitute an unlawful assembly for a person to assemble or act in concert with three (3) or more persons for the purpose of
