engaging in conduct constituting the crime of riot, or to remain at the scene of a riot, after being instructed to disperse by law authorities. (2011 Code)
6-4B-9: WEAPONS:
A. Throwing Or Shooting: It is unlawful for any person to throw or shoot any stone, shot, snowball, or other object into or across any street or alley, or in
any place where he is likely to hit another person wrongfully or to injure property, or to throw or shoot any stone, shot, snowball or other object at any
person, vehicle, structure, electric light, or other property of another (whether public or private), except in case where such is done in defense of
oneself, of another person, or of property.
B. Carrying Weapons, Exceptions: It shall be unlawful for any person to carry upon or about his person, or in his portfolio or purse, any pistol, revolver,
dagger, bowie knife, dirk knife, switchblade knife, spring type knife, sword cane, knife having a blade which opens automatically by hand pressure
applied to a button, spring, or other device in the handle of the knife, blackjack, loaded cane, billy, hand chain, metal knuckles, or any other offensive
weapon, except as otherwise provided by Oklahoma law. Provided further, that this section shall not prohibit the proper possession of guns and knives
for hunting, fishing or recreational purposes, nor shall this section be construed to prohibit any possession of weapons in a manner otherwise permitted
by statute.
C. Bows And Arrows:
1. No person shall shoot with, or use out of doors, a bow and arrow, the bow of which has a pull of ten (10) pounds or over.
2. No person shall use any arrow with a steel pointed tip or a hunting point affixed to the tip.
3. The city administrator or his designee may grant an exemption to subsections C1 and C2 of this section for the operation of an archery range or
other supervised event if it is duly determined that such exemption will not be detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of the public.
D. Firearms; Reckless Conduct: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in reckless conduct while having in his possession any shotgun, rifle or
pistol, such actions consisting of creating a situation of unreasonable risk and probability of death or great bodily harm to another and demonstrating a
conscious disregard for the safety of another person.
E. Transporting Loaded Firearm: Except as otherwise provided by the provisions of the Oklahoma self-defense act1, sections 1 through 25, or other
provision of law by the state, it shall be unlawful to transport a loaded pistol, rifle, or shotgun in a landborne motor vehicle over a public highway or
roadway. However, a rifle or shotgun may be transported when clip or magazine loaded and not chamber loaded when transported in an exterior locked
compartment of the vehicle or trunk of the vehicle.
F. Prohibition Of Firearms On City Property:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 66/269
1. No person shall possess a firearm on any city property or in any city owned structure with the following exceptions:
Duly authorized law enforcement personnel.
2. For purposes of this section only, city streets, alleys, and parking lots serving city buildings are not considered city property. (2011 Code)
ARTICLE C. OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC MORALITY
6-4C-1: ACTING AS DOORKEEPER OR LOOKOUT:
It is unlawful for any person in the city to act as doorkeeper or lookout for any room or building where any crime is carried on, or to use any signal, electric
bell, or other apparatus, or in any manner to obstruct or hinder any police officer attempting to prevent or discover violations of this chapter or to discover
or arrest persons violating same. (2011 Code)
6-4C-2: HOUSES OF ILL FAME OR PROSTITUTION:
A. Keeping:
1. No person, either as owner or agent, shall, within the limits of the city, keep any bawdyhouse, house of ill fame, or house of assignation or
prostitution, or any other house for persons to visit for the purpose of unlawful sexual intercourse, or for any lewd, obscene, or indecent purpose.
2. No person shall keep any disorderly house or house of public resort by which the peace, comfort, or decency of the immediate neighborhood is
disturbed.
B. Person Frequenting: It shall be unlawful for any person to reside in, enter or remain in any house, place, building, vehicle, trailer or other conveyance for
the purpose of lewdness, prostitution or assignation. (2011 Code)
6-4C-3: INDECENT EXPOSURE:
A. Definition: "Lewd" means licentious, lecherous, dissolute, debauched, impure, salacious or pornographic.
B. Prohibition: Every person who wilfully either lewdly exposes his person, or private parts thereof, in any public place, or in any place where there are
present other persons to be offended or annoyed thereby, or procures, counsels, or assists any person to lewdly expose himself, or to make any other
exhibition of himself to public view, or to the view of any number of persons such as is offensive to decency, or is adapted to excite vicious or lewd
thoughts or acts, shall be guilty of an offense against the city. (2011 Code)
6-4C-4: LEWD CONDUCT:
Every person who conducts himself in a lewd manner, or in any manner suggestive of lewdness, shall be guilty of an offense against the city. (2011 Code)
6-4C-5: OBSCENE, THREATENING OR HARASSING TELEPHONE CALLS:
A. Prohibited Acts: It shall be unlawful for a person who, by means of a telephone, wilfully either:
1. Makes any comment, request, suggestion, or proposal which is obscene, lewd, lascivious, filthy or indecent;
2. Makes a telephone call, whether or not conversation ensues, with intent to put the party called in fear of physical harm or death;
3. Makes a telephone call, whether or not conversation ensues, without disclosing his identity and with intent to annoy, abuse, threaten, or harass any
person at the called number;
4. Knowingly permits any telephone under his control to be used for any purpose prohibited by this section; or
5. In conspiracy or concerted action with other persons, makes repeated calls or simultaneous calls solely to harass any person at the called
number(s).
B. Use Described: Use of a telephone facility under this section shall include all use made of such a facility between the points of origin and reception. Any
offense under this section is a continuing offense and shall be deemed to have been committed at either the place of origin or the place of reception.
(2011 Code)
ARTICLE D. OFFENSES INVOLVING ALCOHOL AND DRUGS
6-4D-1: PUBLIC INTOXICATION:
A. Consumption: Any person who shall, in any public place or in any vehicle, drink or otherwise consume any intoxicating liquor containing more than three
and two-tenths percent (3.2%) alcohol measured by weight, except as authorized by the Oklahoma beverage control act1, or any other intoxicating
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 67/269
substance, or intoxicating compound of any kind; or inhale glue, paint or other intoxicating substance, shall be guilty of an offense.
B. Intoxication In Public Place: Any person who shall be drunk or intoxicated in or upon any public or private road, in any vehicle, any public place or
building, at any public gathering, place accessible to the public or open to being viewed by others, from drinking or consuming such intoxicating liquor,
intoxicating substance, or intoxicating compound; or from the inhalation of glue, paint, or other intoxicating substances, shall be guilty of an offense.
C. Disorderly Conduct: Any person who shall be drunk or intoxicated from any cause and who disturbs the peace of any person, or to be drunk or in a
state of intoxication and disorderly in any private house or place to such an extent to jeopardize any person or property as to be injurious to the public
morals shall be guilty of an offense.
D. Private Residences: It shall not be a violation of subsection B of this section for any person to be intoxicated on the premises of a private residence with
the consent of the owner or any bona fide resident.
E. Penalty: Any person found guilty of violating any offense included in this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code.
(2011 Code)
6-4D-2: CERTAIN SALES PROHIBITED:
No licensee of the ABLE commission shall:
A. Authority: Receive, possess, or sell any alcoholic beverage except as authorized by the Oklahoma alcoholic beverage control act and by the license or
permit which he holds.
B. Employees: Employ any person under the age of twenty one (21) in the selling or handling of alcoholic beverages. Provided, that a mixed beverage,
beer and wine caterer, special event or bottle club licensee may employ servers who are at least eighteen (18) years of age, except persons under
twenty one (21) years of age may not serve in designated bar or lounge areas, and a mixed beverage, beer and wine caterer, special event or bottle
club licensee may employ or hire musical bands who have musicians who are under twenty one (21) years of age if each such musician is either
accompanied by a parent or legal guardian or has on their person, to be made available for inspection upon demand by any ABLE commission officer
or law enforcement officer, a written, notarized affidavit from the parent or legal guardian giving the underage musician permission to perform in
designated bar or lounge areas.
C. Give Alcohol As Prize: Give any alcoholic beverage as a prize, premium or consideration for any lottery, game of chance or skill or any type of
competition.
D. Happy Hours: Advertise or offer "happy hours" or any other means or inducements to stimulate the consumption of alcoholic beverages, including:
1. Deliver more than two (2) drinks to one person at one time;
2. Sell or offer to sell to any person or group of persons any drinks at a price less than the price regularly charged for such drinks during the same
calendar week, except at private functions not open to the public;
3. Sell or offer to sell to any person an unlimited number of drinks during any set period of time for a fixed price, except at private functions not open to
the public;
4. Sell or offer to sell drinks to any person or group of persons on any one day at prices less than those charged the general public on that day, except
at private functions not open to the public;
5. Increase the volume of alcoholic beverages contained in a drink without increasing proportionately the price regularly charged for such drink during
the same calendar week; or
6. Encourage or permit, on the licensed premises, any game or contest which involves drinking or the awarding of drinks as prizes.
Provided, that the provisions of this subsection shall not prohibit the advertising or offering of food or entertainment in licensed establishments.
E. Open Containers: Permit or allow any patron or person to exit the licensed premises with an open container of any alcoholic beverage. Provided, that
this prohibition shall not be applicable to closed original containers of alcoholic beverages which are carried from the licensed premises of a bottle club
by a patron, closed original wine containers removed from the premises of restaurants, hotels, and motels, or to closed original containers of alcoholic
beverages transported to and from the place of business of a licensed caterer by the caterer or his employee. (2011 Code)
6-4D-3: DISTRIBUTE OR DISPENSE CONTROLLED DANGEROUS SUBSTANCES:
Except as provided by the uniform controlled dangerous substances act of the state2, it shall be unlawful for any person to distribute, dispense or possess
with intent to manufacture, distribute or dispense, a controlled dangerous substance, or to create, distribute or possess with intent to distribute, a
counterfeit controlled dangerous substance; or to distribute any imitation controlled dangerous substance except when authorized by the food and drug
administration of the United States department of health and human services. All definitions and other provisions of the uniform controlled dangerous
substances act of the state are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this section. (2011 Code)
6-4D-4: BEING UNDER INFLUENCE OF DRUGS:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 68/269
No person who is noticeably under the influence of any drug taken for other than strictly medicinal purposes shall be or remain upon any street, avenue,
alley, other thoroughfare, or other public place; and any person who disturbs the peace of any person, or is drunk or in a state of intoxication and disorderly
in any private house or place to such an extent to jeopardize any person or property as to be injurious to the public morals shall be guilty of an offense
within the limits of the city. (2011 Code)
6-4D-5: POSSESSION OF DRUG PARAPHERNALIA:
Except as otherwise provided by the uniform controlled dangerous substances act of the state, it shall be unlawful for any person to possess drug
paraphernalia. All of the provisions of the uniform controlled dangerous substances act of the state pertaining to drug paraphernalia and the factors used in
determining whether an object is drug paraphernalia are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this section. (2011 Code)
6-4D-6: LOW POINT BEER:
A. Definition: "Low point beer" means and includes beverages containing more than one-half of one percent (0.5%) alcohol by volume, and not more than
three and two-tenths percent (3.2%) alcohol by weight.
B. Possession In Public: It is unlawful and an offense for any person under the age of twenty one (21) years to be in possession of any low point beer
while such person is upon any public street, road or highway, or in any public building or place.
C. Transporting Within Vehicle: It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly transport in any moving vehicle upon a public highway, street or alley any
low point beer containing more than one-half of one percent (0.5%) alcohol by volume and not more than three and two-tenths percent (3.2%) alcohol
by weight except in the original container which shall not have been opened and from which the original cap or seal shall not have been removed,
unless the opened container be in the rear trunk or rear compartment, which shall include the spare tire compartment in a station wagon or panel truck,
or any outside compartment which is not accessible to the driver or any other person in the vehicle while it is in motion.
D. Purchase: It is unlawful and an offense for any person under the age of twenty one (21) years to purchase any low point beer.
E. Prohibiting Sale To Minors: It is unlawful for any person to sell, barter or give to any person under twenty one (21) years of age any low point beer.
(2011 Code)
ARTICLE E. OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY
6-4E-1: DESTRUCTION:
It is unlawful for any person to destroy, injure, deface, besmear, or molest any structure, building, outbuilding, fence, or any other property, real or
personal, public or private, belonging to another; or to use any such property wrongfully to the detriment of the owner or other person entitled to its use; or
to interfere wrongfully with the use of any such property by its owner or any other person entitled to its use. (2011 Code)
6-4E-2: TRESPASS:
A. Place Of Lodging: It is unlawful for any person to use or occupy as a place of lodging or to erect dwelling houses, tents or structures of any kind
whatsoever upon any land, lots or tracts of land situated within the limits of any public property owned or controlled by the city.
B. Private Property: It is unlawful for any person to trespass upon the private property of any person within the city.
C. Businesses:
1. Every person, partnership, corporation or other legal entity engaged in any public business, trade or profession, of any kind wherein merchandise,
goods or services are offered for sale, may forbid the entry or presence of any person upon the premises of the place of business, if the person has
been convicted of a crime involving entry onto or criminal acts occurring upon any real property owned, leased or under the control of such person,
partnership, corporation or other legal entity. Such crimes shall include, but are not limited to, shoplifting, vandalism, and disturbing the peace while
upon the premises of any place of business of the person, partnership, corporation or other legal entity.
2. In order to exercise the authority conferred by subsection C1 of this section, the owner or an agent of the owner of a public business, trade or
profession must notify the person whom the owner or agent desires to prohibit from such owner's place of business.
3. No person shall wilfully enter or remain upon the premises after being expressly forbidden to do so in the manner provided for in this section. Any
person convicted shall be guilty of trespass and shall be punished in accordance with law. (2011 Code)
6-4E-3: LARCENY:
A. Personal Property: It is unlawful and larceny, as used in this section, for anyone to take personal property by fraud or stealth, with intent to deprive
another thereof.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 69/269
B. Lost Property: One who finds lost property under circumstances which give him knowledge or means of inquiry as to the true owner, and who
appropriates such property to his own use, or to the use of another person who is not entitled thereto, without having first made such effort to find the
owner and restore the property to him as the circumstances render reasonable and just, is guilty of larceny. (2011 Code)
6-4E-4: THEFT OF SERVICES:
A. Offenses Described:
1. "Theft of services" is obtaining services from another by deception, threat, coercion, stealth, tampering or use of false token or device.
2. "Services", within the meaning of this section, includes, but is not limited to, labor, professional service, cable television service, public or municipal
utility or transportation service, telephone service, lodging, entertainment and the supply of equipment for use.
3. "Tampering", within the meaning of this section, includes, but is not limited to:
a. Making a connection of any wire, conduit or device, to any service or transmission line owned by a public or municipal utility, or by a cable
television service provider;
b. Defacing, puncturing, removing, reversing or altering any meter or any connections, for the purpose of securing unauthorized or unmeasured
electric, natural gas, water, telephone service or cable television service;
c. Hindering and/or preventing any such meters from properly measuring or registering;
d. Knowingly taking, receiving, using or converting to such person's own use, or the use of another, any electricity, water or natural gas which has not
been measured; or any telephone or cable television service which has not been authorized; or
e. Causing, procuring, permitting, aiding or abetting any person to do any of the preceding acts.
B. Prima Facie Proof Of Violation: In any prosecution of this section, the existence of any of the connections of the meters, alterations or use of
unauthorized or unmeasured water, electric, natural gas, telephone service or cable television service, specified in subsection A3 of this section, shall
be prima facie evidence of intent to violate the provision of this section by the person or persons using or receiving the direct benefits from the use of
the water, electric, natural gas, telephone service or cable television service passing through such connections or meters, or using the electric, natural
gas, water, telephone service or cable television which has not been authorized or measured. (2011 Code)
6-4E-5: OBTAINING PROPERTY BY DECEPTION:
Every person who, with intent to cheat and defraud, shall obtain or attempt to obtain from any person, firm or corporation, any money, property or valuable
thing, of the value of less than fifty dollars ($50.00), by means or by use of any trick or deception, or false or fraudulent representation or statement or
pretense, or by any other means or instruments or device, commonly called the "confidence game", or by means or use of any false or bogus checks, or
by any other written, printed or engraved instrument or spurious coin, shall be guilty of an offense against the city. (2011 Code)
6-4E-6: POSSESSION OF BURGLAR'S IMPLEMENTS:
Every person who has in possession a dangerous offensive weapon or instrument whatsoever, or any picklock, crow, key, bit, jack, jimmy, nippers, pick,
betty or other implement of burglary, with intent to break and enter any building or part of any building, booth, tent, warehouse, railroad car, vessel or other
structure or erection, and to commit any crime therein, is guilty of an offense against the city. (2011 Code)
6-4E-7: ENTERING BUILDINGS WITH CERTAIN INTENT:
A. Definitions: The following terms, as used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
DWELLING: Includes every house, trailer, vessel, apartment or other premises, any part of which has usually been occupied by a person lodging
therein at night, and any structure joined to and immediately connected with such house, trailer or apartment.
DWELLING HOUSE: Includes any house or edifice, any part of which has usually been occupied by any person lodging there at any time, and any
structure joined to and immediately connected with such a house or edifice.
B. Prohibited Acts:
1. Every person who, under circumstances not amounting to any burglary, enters any building or part of any building, booth, tent, warehouse, railroad
car, vessel, or other structure or erection with intent to commit any felony, larceny, or malicious mischief, is guilty of an offense against the city.
2. Every person who, without the intention to commit any crime therein, shall wilfully and intentionally break and enter into any building, trailer, vessel,
or other premises used as a dwelling without the permission of the owner or occupant thereof, except in the cases and manner allowed by law, shall
be guilty of an offense against the city. (2011 Code)
6-4E-8: INTENT TO DEFRAUD:
Whenever, by any of the provisions of this chapter, an intent to defraud is required in order to constitute any offense, it is sufficient if any intent appears to
defraud any person. (2011 Code)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 70/269
6-4E-9: DEFRAUDING RESTAURANTS, HOTELS:
It shall be an offense for any person to obtain food, lodging, services or other accommodations at any restaurant, hotel, inn, boarding house, motel or auto
camp with the intent to defraud the owner or keeper thereof. (2011 Code)
6-4E-10: LOITERING IN OR INJURING MOTOR VEHICLE:
It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to loiter in or upon any automobile or motor vehicle, or to deface or injure such automobile or motor vehicle,
or to molest, drive, or attempt to drive any automobile, for joyriding or any other purpose, or to manipulate or meddle with any machinery or appliances
thereof without the consent of the owner of such automobile or motor vehicle. (2011 Code)
6-4E-11: SMOKING WITHIN CITY FACILITIES:
A. For purposes of this section, "smoking" means the carrying by a person of a lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe, or other lighted smoking device.
B. Smoking in any enclosed, indoor facility owned by the city is hereby prohibited.
C. This section shall not prohibit smoking in a private, enclosed room or office occupied exclusively by a smoker or smokers, even if the room or enclosed
office may be visited by a nonsmoker.
D. The city administrator is authorized to promulgate and enforce reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this section. (2011 Code)
6-4E-12: OFFENSES WITHIN OSAGE GARDENS CEMETERY1:
A. Prohibited Acts: It is an offense for any person to commit any of the following acts in any area of Osage Gardens Cemetery:
1. To operate any motor vehicle in excess of five (5) miles per hour or to fail to conform to any posted speed limit.
2. To park any motor vehicle in any area other than the designated streets within the cemetery.
3. To destroy, break, deface, mar or remove any tree, shrub, plant, flower, building, fence, light fixture, tombstone or equipment of any type.
4. To dump or scatter trash, garbage or litter of any kind at any place except in designated containers.
5. To use firearms, fireworks, BB guns, air rifles or slingshots.
6. To throw stones or other dangerous hard objects.
7. To permit dogs, cats or other pets to run loose.
8. To climb trees, fences, light posts, gazebos, mausoleums and other hazardous structures.
B. Hours: Osage Gardens Cemetery, unless otherwise provided for by cemetery regulations, shall be closed to the public from nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. until
six o'clock (6:00) A.M. each day, and it is unlawful for any person to trespass or loiter on any cemetery property when the same is closed to the public.
(2011 Code)
ARTICLE F. OFFENSES BY OR AGAINST MINORS
6-4F-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply to sections 6-4F-3 through 6-4F-8 of this article:
GUARDIAN: A parent, stepparent, legal guardian, foster parent, or anyone who, by virtue of a living arrangement, is placed in an apparent position of
power or authority over a minor.
JUVENILE/MINOR: Any individual who is under the age of eighteen (18).
PARENT: A biological mother, an adoptive parent, or a man to whom the biological mother was married at the time of conception or birth or who has been
found by a court of competent jurisdiction to be the biological father of the juvenile. (2011 Code)
6-4F-2: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION OF MUNICIPAL COURT IN CERTAIN JUVENILE CASES:
The municipal court may elect to have and possess original jurisdiction to hear and adjudicate any offenses committed by persons under the age of
eighteen (18) years and penalize juveniles found guilty as allowed by Oklahoma law. Nothing found within the juvenile code shall be construed to prevent
the imposition of any penalty as otherwise specified in the ordinances of the city. (2011 Code)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 71/269
6-4F-3: CURFEW FOR MINORS:
A. Curfew Hours: It shall be unlawful for any minor to be upon the streets, sidewalks, parks, playgrounds, public places and vacant lots, or to ride in or
upon, drive or otherwise operate or be a passenger of any automobile, bicycle, or other vehicle in, upon, or over or through the streets, or other public
places within the city of Skiatook, between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M., Sunday through Thursday, and twelve
o'clock (12:00) midnight and five o'clock (5:00) A.M., Friday and Saturday. This subsection also provides for a daytime curfew to apply to these same
circumstances, during the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and two thirty o'clock (2:30) P.M. Monday through Friday. Additionally, it shall be unlawful for
any parent to permit a minor to be in those places during the specified hours. The daytime curfew only applies when school is in session. (Ord. 2011-
06, 8-30-2011)
B. Defense:
1. It shall be a defense to subsection A of this section if the minor is:
a. At any time accompanied by a parent, or responsible adult, authorized by a parent to take the parent's place, to accompany the minor for a
designated period of time and purpose, within a specified area.
b. An "emancipated minor", which is defined as a person who no longer has a parent-child relationship as a result of marriage, or as a result of being
recognized as an adult by order of a court of competent jurisdiction.
c. Either engaged in an employment activity, or for the period of time forty five (45) minutes after work; provided, that circumstances suggest the
minor is returning from work to a place of residence.
d. Attending or traveling between home and an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the city,
a civic organization, a religious organization, a public or private school, or any entity that takes responsibility for the minor; provided, that the
activity has not concluded for more than forty five (45) minutes.
e. At any time on a legitimate parentally approved errand.
f. In any motor vehicle involved in interstate travel.
g. At any time the minor is required to leave the residence because of an emergency.
h. At any time the minor is engaged in an activity that is protected by the first amendment to the United States constitution, such as the freedom of
speech, religion or expression.
2. If the juvenile falls within any classification, as listed in subsection B1 of this section and the officer has no other charges to consider against the
juvenile, the juvenile shall be released and no further action shall be taken.
3. Officers coming into contact with a juvenile seventeen (17) years of age or younger shall (within the bounds of good judgment and common sense)
detain that juvenile and issue the juvenile a citation for curfew violation. The juvenile will then be released to a parent or legal guardian. The parent or
legal guardian will also be required to sign the citation. (2011 Code)
6-4F-4: ALLOWING OR ENCOURAGING MINOR TO COMMIT OFFENSE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly or wilfully aid, abet, allow, encourage or, by omission of a duty, encourage or assist a minor to commit any
municipal, state, or federal offense. (2011 Code)
6-4F-5: PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITIES; FAILURE TO CONTROL:
It shall be unlawful for any parent to fail to control a minor that is under the parent's supervision by, after notification of a prior offense committed by the
minor, failing to prevent the minor from committing the same offense, or more than one other offense within one year of the date the minor committed the
first offense. (2011 Code)
6-4F-6: COMMISSION OF CRIME IN PRESENCE OF MINOR:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any municipal, state or federal offense in the presence of any person under the age of eighteen (18) years.
(2011 Code)
6-4F-7: PERMITTING CRIMES OR DISORDERLINESS ON PREMISES:
No owner, operator, proprietor, manager or employee of any place shall permit minors who have congregated on the premises to commit any offense, or to
carouse, make unnecessary noise, disturb, disrupt or annoy the people residing or carrying on business in the immediate neighborhood or so as to disturb
the peace. Furthermore, no owner, operator, proprietor, manager or employee of any place shall permit minors to loiter, litter, or cause any disturbance on
the property of a neighboring resident or business. (2011 Code)
6-4F-8: TRUANCY:
A. Attendance Compulsory; Exceptions: It shall be unlawful for a parent, guardian, or other person having custody of a child who is over the age of six (6)
years, and under the age of eighteen (18) years, to neglect or refuse to cause or compel such child to attend and comply with the rules of some public,
private or other school, unless other means of education are provided for the full term the schools of the district are in session or the child is excused
as provided in this section.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 72/269
1. If any such child is prevented from attending school by reason of mental or physical disability, to be determined by the board of education of the
district upon a certificate of the school physician or public health physician, or, if no such physician is available, a duly licensed and practicing
physician.
2. If any such child is excused from attendance at school, due to an emergency, by the principal teacher of the school in which the child is enrolled, at
the request of the parent, guardian, custodian or other person having control of such child.
3. If any such child who has attained his or her sixteenth birthday is excused from attending school by written, joint agreement between:
a. The school administrator of the school district where the child attends school, and the parent, guardian or custodian of the child. Provided, further,
that no child shall be excused from attending school by such joint agreement between a school administrator and the parent, guardian or custodian
of the child unless and until it has been determined that such action is for the best interest of the child and/or the community, and that said child
shall thereafter be under the supervision of the parent, guardian or custodian until the child has reached the age of eighteen (18) years; or
b. If any such child is excused pursuant to subsection B of this section.
B. School District Excusing Student: A school district shall excuse a student from attending school for the purpose of observing religious holy days if before
the absence, the parent, guardian or person having custody or control of the student submits a written request for the excused absence. The school
district shall excuse a student pursuant to this subsection for the days on which the religious holy days are observed and for the days on which the
student must travel to and from the site where the student will observe the holy days.
C. Valid Excuse For Absence Required: It shall be an offense for a parent, guardian or custodian of such child to allow such child to be absent from school
without a valid excuse for four (4) or more days or parts of days within a four (4) week period or to be absent without valid excuse for ten (10) or more
days or parts of days within a semester. (2011 Code)
6-4F-9: CONTRIBUTING TO DELINQUENCY OF MINOR:
It shall be unlawful, except as otherwise provided by law, for any person who shall knowingly or wilfully cause, aid, abet or encourage a minor to be, to
remain, or to become a delinquent child. (2011 Code)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 2019-01 - YOUTH ACCESS TO TOBACCO. Go to new ordinance.
6-4F-10: PREVENTION OF YOUTH ACCESS TO TOBACCO:
A. Findings And Intent: The city council members find that youth addiction to tobacco products is a public health problem with grave health consequences.
In recognition that almost ninety percent (90%) of all smokers begin smoking by the age of eighteen (18), action is needed to curtail the easy access of
minors to cigarettes and other addictive tobacco products. Furthermore, the city council members find that the Oklahoma state legislature has limited
the powers granted to local governments to address the problem of youth access to tobacco. Therefore, the intent of this section is to: 1) implement the
strictest and most enforceable system allowed under Oklahoma state law to prevent the illegal sale of cigarettes and other tobacco products to minors;
2) periodically amend and update this section as necessary to best utilize any applicable powers which may return to Oklahoma municipalities in the
future; and 3) educate, encourage and assist underage tobacco users in ceasing all use of addictive tobacco products, preferably before daily use of
such products is initiated.
B. Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
PERSON: Any individual, firm, fiduciary, partnership, corporation, trust, or association, however formed.
PROOF OF AGE: A driver's license, license for identification only, or other generally accepted means of identification that describes the individual as
eighteen (18) years of age or older and contains a photograph or other likeness of the individual and appears on its face to be valid.
SAMPLE: A tobacco product distributed to members of the public at no cost for the purpose of promoting the product.
SAMPLING: The distribution of samples to members of the public in a public place.
TOBACCO PRODUCT: Any product that contains tobacco and is intended for human consumption.
C. Distribution And Sales; Identification; Fines:
1. It is unlawful for any person to sell, give or furnish in any manner any tobacco product to another person who is under eighteen (18) years of age, or
to purchase in any manner a tobacco product on behalf of any such person. It shall not be unlawful for an employee under eighteen (18) years of age
to handle tobacco products when required in the performance of the employee's duties.
2. A person engaged in the sale or distribution of tobacco products shall demand proof of age from a prospective purchaser or recipient if an ordinary
person would conclude on the basis of appearance that the prospective purchaser may be under eighteen (18) years of age. If any individual
engaged in the sale or distribution of tobacco products has demanded proof of age from a prospective purchaser or recipient who is not under
eighteen (18) years of age, the failure to subsequently require proof of age shall not constitute a violation of this subsection.
3. If the sale is made by an employee of the owner of a store at which tobacco products are sold at retail, the employee shall be guilty of the violation
and shall be subject to the fine.
4. Proof that the defendant demanded, was shown, and reasonably relied upon proof of age, shall be a defense to any action brought pursuant to this
section.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 73/269
5. For the purposes of determining the liability of a person controlling franchises or business operations in multiple locations for any violation of
subsection C1 or C2 of this section, each individual franchise or business location shall be deemed a separate entity.
6. Any person who violates any provision of subsection C1 or C2 of this section shall be guilty of an offense and may be assessed a fine of not more
than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense, not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the second offense within a two (2) year
period, not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) for a third offense within a two (2) year period following the first offense, or not more than three
hundred dollars ($300.00) for the fourth or subsequent offense within a two (2) year period following the first offense.
7. Upon failure of any person to pay any fine authorized by this subsection C within ninety (90) days of the day of the assessment of such fine, the
court clerk or his/her designee shall notify the Oklahoma department of public safety, as such department is authorized to suspend or not issue a
driver's license to the person until proof of payment has been provided.
D. Distribution Of Tobacco Product Samples Restricted; Fines:
1. It shall be unlawful for any person or retailer to distribute tobacco products or product samples to any person under eighteen (18) years of age.
2. No person shall distribute tobacco product samples in or on any public street, sidewalk, or park that is within three hundred feet (300') of any
playground, school, or other facility when the facility is being used primarily by persons under eighteen (18) years of age.
3. Any person who violates any provision of subsection D1 or D2 of this section shall be guilty of an offense and may be assessed a fine of not more
than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense, not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the second offense, and not more than three
hundred dollars ($300.00) for the third or subsequent offense.
4. Upon failure of any person to pay any fine authorized by this subsection D within ninety (90) days of the day of assessment of such fine, the court
clerk or his/her designee shall notify the Oklahoma department of public safety, as such department is authorized to suspend or not issue a driver's
license to the person until proof of payment has been provided.
E. Sale Of Tobacco Except In Original, Sealed Packaging Prohibited; Fines:
1. It is unlawful for any person to sell cigarettes except in the original, sealed package in which they were placed by the manufacturer.
2. Any person who shall violate subsection E1 of this section shall be guilty of an offense and may be assessed a fine of not more than two hundred
dollars ($200.00) for each offense.
F. Purchase, Receipt Or Possession By Minors Prohibited; Falsifying Proof Of Age; Punishment; Remedial Activities; Expungement Of Conviction:
1. It is unlawful for a person who is under eighteen (18) years of age to purchase, receive or have in their possession a tobacco product, or to present
or offer any person any purported proof of age which is false or fraudulent for the purpose of purchasing or receiving any tobacco product.
2. Any person who violates any provision of subsection F1 of this section shall be guilty of an offense and may be assessed a fine of not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense, not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the second offense and subsequent offenses within a
one year period following the first offense. However:
a. The court may, upon conviction of an individual for an offense under subsection F1 of this section, suspend execution of the sentence and, if so,
shall require the defendant to attend a tobacco education program at the expense of the defendant. The defendant's parent or guardian must also
attend the tobacco education program with the defendant.
b. If access to the tobacco education program is not readily available, the court shall require the defendant to perform eight (8) to twelve (12) hours of
tobacco related community service instead of attending a tobacco education program.
c. The tobacco education program and the tobacco related community service are remedial and are not punishment.
d. No later than the ninetieth day after the date of conviction under subsection F1 of this section, the defendant shall present to the court, in a
manner required by the court, evidence of satisfactory completion of the tobacco education program or the tobacco related community service.
e. On receipt of the evidence required under subsection F2d of this section, the court shall:
(1) If the defendant has been convicted of a previous offense under subsection F1 of this section, which offense occurred within one year prior to
the offense for which the defendant is currently charged, execute sentence, and at the discretion of the court, assess a fine of not less than ten
dollars ($10.00) and not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00).
(2) If the defendant has not been convicted of a previous offense under subsection F1 of this section, which offense occurred within one year prior
to the offense for which the defendant is currently charges, dismiss the complaint and discharge the defendant.
f. If the court dismissed the complaint under subsection F2e(2) of this section, the defendant is released from all penalties and liabilities resulting
from the offense, except that the defendant is considered to have been convicted of the offense if the defendant subsequently convicted of the
same charge if such a repeat offense occurs within one year of the dismissed offense.
g. Any person convicted of an offense under subsection F1 of this section may apply to the court to have the conviction expunged. If the court finds
that the individual has satisfactorily completed the tobacco education program or tobacco related community service ordered by the court and that
there has been no subsequent offense for a period of at least one year after the date of the offense for which the person was convicted, the court
shall order the conviction and any complaint, verdict, sentence or other document relating to the offense to be expunged from the individual's
record and the conviction may not be shown or made known for any purpose.
h. If the defendant does not provide the evidence required under subsection F2d of this section within the period specified by that subsection or upon
failure of the defendant to pay any fine authorized by this section within ninety (90) days of the day of the assessment of such fine, the court clerk
or his/her designee shall notify the Oklahoma department of public safety, as such department is authorized to suspend or not issue a driver's
license to the person until proof of payment has been provided. (2011 Code)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 74/269
G. Reporting: The city clerk or his/her designee shall furnish any information or reports required or requested by the Oklahoma alcoholic beverage laws
enforcement (ABLE) commission in the form, manner and time as may be determined by the ABLE commission. (2011 Code; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-
2013)
H. Nonretaliation: No person shall discharge, refuse to hire, or in any manner retaliate against any employee, applicant for employment or customer
because such employee, applicant, or customer reported violations of any provision of this section. (2011 Code)
6-4F-11: PROVIDING ALCOHOL TO MINORS IN SOCIAL HOST SETTING:
A. Definitions: For purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply:
ALCOHOL: Shall include any type of substance classified under Oklahoma law as containing alcohol or low point beer.
GATHERING: A party, gathering or event where a group of three (3) or more persons have assembled or are assembling for a social occasion or
social activity.
LEGAL GUARDIAN: 1. A person who, by court order, is the guardian of the person of a minor; or
2. A public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by the court.
MINOR: Any person less than twenty one (21) years of age.
PARENT: A person who is a natural parent, adoptive parent, foster parent or stepparent of another person.
PREMISES: Any residence or other private property, place or premises, including any commercial or business premises.
RESPONSE COSTS: The costs associated with responses by law enforcement, fire, and other emergency response providers to a gathering,
including, but not limited to:
1. Salaries and benefits of law enforcement, code enforcement, fire, or other emergency response personnel for the amount of time spent
responding to, remaining at, or otherwise dealing with a gathering, and the administrative costs attributed to such response(s);
2. The cost of any medical treatment for any law enforcement, code enforcement, fire or other emergency response personnel injured responding
to, remaining at, or leaving the scene of a gathering;
3. The cost of repairing any city equipment or property damaged, and the cost of the use of any such equipment, in responding to, remaining at, or
leaving the scene of a gathering; and
4. Any other allowable costs related to the enforcement of this section.
B. Consumption Of Alcohol By Minor In Public Place, Place Open To Public, Or Place Not Open To Public: Except as permitted by state law, it is unlawful
for any minor to:
1. Consume at any public place or any place open to the public alcoholic beverages; or
2. Consume at any place not open to the public any alcoholic beverage, unless in connection with the consumption of the alcoholic beverage that minor
is being supervised by his or her parent or legal guardian.
C. Hosting, Permitting Or Allowing Party, Gathering Or Event Where Minors Consuming Alcoholic Beverages Prohibited:
1. It is the duty of any person having control of any premises, who knowingly hosts, permits, or allows a gathering at said premises to take all
reasonable steps to prevent the consumption of alcoholic beverages by any minor at the gathering. Reasonable steps are controlling access to
alcoholic beverages at the gathering; controlling the quantity of alcoholic beverages present at the gathering; verifying the age of persons attending
the gathering by inspecting drivers' licenses or other government issued identification cards to ensure that minors do not consume alcoholic
beverages while at the gathering; and supervising the activities of minors at the gathering.
2. It is unlawful for any person having control of any premises to knowingly host, permit, or allow a gathering to take place at said premises where at
least one minor consumes an alcoholic beverage, whenever the person having control of the premises either knows a minor has consumed an
alcoholic beverage or reasonably should have known that a minor consumed an alcoholic beverage had the person taken all reasonable steps to
prevent the consumption of an alcoholic beverage by a minor as set forth in subsection C1 of this section.
3. This section shall not apply to conduct involving the use of alcoholic beverages that occurs exclusively between a minor and his or her parent or
legal guardian.
4. Nothing in this section shall be interpreted to prohibit any family activity held in the confines of the family home from providing the use of alcohol to
immediate family members within supervision of parents and guardians. However, if a minor leaves such a family gathering intoxicated and is found
in public, then said providers of alcohol will be held responsible in the same manner as a nonfamily gathering.
5. Nothing in this section should be interpreted to prohibit any religious practice which includes the use of alcohol. However, if a minor leaves such a
religious gathering intoxicated and is found to be in public, then said providers of alcohol will be held responsible in the same manner as a
nonreligious gathering.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 75/269
D. Penalty: Any person who shall violate the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of an offense against the city and, upon conviction thereof,
shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code, plus all court costs and statutory penalties.
E. Reservation Of Legal Options: Violations of this section may be prosecuted by the city, criminally, civilly, or through both processes. The city may seek
administrative fees and response costs associated with enforcement of this section through all remedies or procedures provided by statute, ordinance,
or law. This section shall not limit the authority of peace officers or private citizens to make arrests for any criminal offense arising out of conduct
regulated by this section, nor shall they limit the city's ability to initiate and prosecute any criminal offense arising out of the same circumstances
necessitating the application of this section. (2011 Code)
ARTICLE G. NUISANCES
6-4G-1: ADOPTION OF STATE LAW:
The city adopts all of the applicable provisions of 11 Oklahoma Statutes and any amendments made thereto concerning the general powers of
municipalities, and 63 Oklahoma Statutes section 1-1011 and any amendments made thereto concerning health nuisances, specifically dealing with the
prohibition and abatement of nuisances as defined in this chapter. (2011 Code)
6-4G-2: CODE ENFORCEMENT AND OTHER HEARINGS; ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING OFFICER:
A. Hearings Before Administrative Hearing Officer:
1. Whenever a hearing is afforded before the city council by the provisions of 11 Oklahoma Statutes sections 22-111 (cleaning and mowing of property;
summary abatement; ordinances; definitions; application), 22-112 (condemnation; procedures; administrative officer or body; definitions; nuisances;
damages or loss of property; agricultural property), 22-112.1 (boarding and securing dilapidated buildings; definitions), or any ordinance of the city or
other state statute, the city council may, unless the ordinance or statute provides otherwise, by resolution, direct that such hearing be conducted
before and held by the administrative hearing officer to be designated by the city council. The city council may, by resolution, prospectively decree
that all such hearings shall be held before a designated administrative hearing officer.
2. The administrative hearing officer shall be possessed of all authority in the conduct of such hearing as is vested by law or ordinance in the city
council. Hearings before the administrative officer shall be conducted in the manner provided by law or ordinance.
3. All proceedings before the administrative hearing officer shall be conducted in an orderly fashion and consistent with due process of law. Any person
guilty of conduct before such officer during the course of such a hearing which would be contemptuous if committed before a judicial tribunal of the
state shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and the administrative officer may issue to such person a citation for such offense. (2011 Code)
B. Appeals To City Council; Municipal Court Jurisdiction:
1. The property owner, mortgage holder or other adversely affected person, as the case may be, shall have the right to appeal any decision of the
administrative officer to the city council. Such appeal shall be taken by filing written notice of appeal with the city clerk within ten (10) days after the
administrative order is rendered. (2011 Code; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
2. Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit or diminish the jurisdiction of the municipal court of the city in criminal proceedings brought for
violation of any penal ordinances of the city.
C. Interim Administrative Hearing Officer: Until the city council shall otherwise designate an administrative hearing officer by resolution, the city manager
shall serve as the administrative hearing officer, and all such hearings to be conducted after the effective date hereof shall be before him; and this
section shall have the effect of a formal resolution by the city council designating the city manager as such hearing officer. (2011 Code)
6-4G-3: PORTABLE BUILDINGS, LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any portable structure as a primary structure in areas of the city zoned as any class of office zoning (OL, OM),
commercial zoning (CS, CG, CH), and industrial light (IL) as described in title 11, chapters 5, 6 and 7 of this code, except for the following permitted areas:
A. Golf courses, pitch and putt courses, and miniature golf courses.
B. Temporary buildings used in connection with engineering and construction projects not used for dwellings and not used for a period exceeding the
completion of construction or engineering.
C. Accessory buildings used only incidental to the use of the primary structure.
D. Portable buildings used incidental to municipal or community recreation centers.
E. Police or fire stations.
F. Public buildings and buildings operated in the public interest and not for profit including art galleries, post offices, libraries, and museums.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 76/269
G. Auditoriums, stadiums, arenas, or armories.
H. Community play fields and parks.
I. Public utility and service uses, including electric substations, gas regulator stations, electric, gas, telegraph, telephone, and water transmission, meeting
and distribution equipment and structures, microwave relay towers, water reservoirs or pumping stations, and other similar facilities.
J. Uses incidental to the operation and maintenance of public schools and hospitals.
K. Portable buildings used for office or storage purposes only for a period not exceeding twenty (20) days for such purpose and for no other purpose.
(2011 Code)
6-4G-4: SAWMILL LOCATION, OPERATION:
Both the location and the operation, or either, of a sawmill within the corporate limits of the city, in Tulsa and Osage Counties, are hereby declared to be a
public nuisance and are prohibited. (2011 Code)
6-4G-5: WEEDS AND OTHER NUISANCES:
A. Weeds: It shall be and constitute a nuisance for any person owning or occupying any real estate within the corporate limits of the city, in Tulsa and
Osage Counties, to permit the rank growth of any weeds or other obnoxious plants thereon, or on any abutting street or alley, and the same is hereby
prohibited.
B. Health Nuisances:
1. The city code enforcement officer shall have the authority to order the owner or occupant of any private premises to remove from such premises, at
the owner's or occupant's own expense, any source of filth, cause of sickness, condition conducive to the breeding of insects or rodents that might
contribute to the transmission of disease, or any other condition adversely affecting the public health, within twenty four (24) hours, or within such
other time as might be reasonable. Failure to comply with the order shall be a violation of this code.
2. Such order shall be in writing and may be served personally on the owner or occupant of the premises, or authorized agent thereof, or a copy thereof
may be left at the last usual place of abode of such owner, occupant or agent, if known and within the city. If the premises are unoccupied and the
residence of such owner, occupant or agent is unknown, or is without the city, such order may be served by posting a copy thereof on the premises,
or by publication in at least one issue of a newspaper having a general circulation in the county.
C. Trash And Filth Deposits:
1. Trash In Public Places: No person shall throw any animal or vegetable substance, offal, hay, straw, ashes, soot, glass, or other articles whatsoever in
any street, alley, or public place of the city, or from his or her premises upon any property contiguous thereto.
2. Disposal Of Filth: No person shall conduct into any street, alley, or other public place in the city, any filth, sour or useless water, or offal or waste of
any kind, from his or her kitchen, house, or tenement, or to suffer any such to escape from his or her premises upon any such places or upon
property contiguous thereto.
3. Cleaning Gutters: No person shall allow any filth, dirt, or other obstructions of any kind to accumulate in the gutter in front of his or her premises, and
all owners or occupants of property are required to keep the gutter in front of their premises open, free, and clear from trash, and all obstructions to
the easy and rapid flow of water through such gutters.
4. Sidewalks: No person shall deposit dirt, sweepings, or rubbish of any kind in or upon any of the sidewalks, gutters, streets, alleys or public places, in
or around their place of business or residence or permit or suffer the same to be done. (2011 Code)
D. Outdoor Storage: Outdoor storage on residential property under the conditions as set forth in subsections D1 through D9 of this section is prohibited
and shall constitute a nuisance, unless enclosed by a sightproof screening fence at least six feet (6') in height and erected so as to make such
prohibited outdoor storage invisible from outside the premises:
1. The storage of vehicle or automotive parts which are not going to be used within the next three (3) days.
2. The storage of household furniture or appliances which are customarily located indoors.
3. The storage of building materials which are not currently being utilized in the course of normal construction, repair or remodeling on the subject
property.
4. Personal property displayed for sale or stored in a front yard, side yard or driveway, located either on the ground or arranged on tables for more than
three (3) days concurrently (commonly referred to as a "garage sale" or "yard sale").
5. The storage of junk, dismantled or inoperative lawn mowers, bicycles or children's toys.
6. The storage of junk, dismantled or inoperative charcoal, wood or gas grills customarily manufactured and utilized for cooking food.
7. Any pickup truck, trailer, or similar vehicle containing trash, rubbish, refuse or junk which is parked, placed, stored or kept in such a manner that the
trash or junk is in view of the public for a period of more than three (3) days.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 77/269
8. The storage of commercial or agricultural trailers.
9. The storage of firewood which is not neatly stacked. (Ord. 2013-10, 6-25-2013)
E. Sight Obstructions Along Streets: All trees, hedges, signs or other sight obstructions, or any portion of such obstruction, located within a sight distance
triangle which prevent persons driving vehicles approaching an intersection of streets from having a clear view of traffic approaching such intersection
shall constitute a public nuisance. "Sight distance triangle" shall be defined as the area within an imaginary triangle formed at a street corner as follows:
Extend the curb lines (or the edge of the pavement where no curb exists) into the street to a point where those lines intersect; from that point of
intersection, measure along both curb lines (or edges of pavement) to two (2) points, each of which is thirty five feet (35') from the point of intersection;
the connecting of these three (3) points shall form the "sight distance triangle". The city is authorized to abate sight obstructions along streets within a
sight distance triangle if necessary to protect public health and safety.
F. Tree Limbs, Branches And Shrubbery Abutting Streets, Alleys And Sidewalks:
1. The owner of any property or premises abutting any street, alley or sidewalk within the city shall trim all trees and shrubbery growing between the
sidewalks and street, or adjacent to any sidewalk, street or alley so that the free and convenient passage and travel along said streets, alleys and
sidewalks is not obstructed, according to the requirements set forth in this subsection F. When such property or premises is occupied by some
person other than the owner, such occupant shall trim the trees and shrubbery in the same manner as hereinafter required of the owner.
2. All tree limbs, tree branches or shrubbery which project over or overhang a public street, alley or sidewalk and which said branches, limbs, or
shrubbery, or any part thereof, are less than eight feet (8') above the surface of the sidewalk or which are less than twelve feet (12') above the
surface of a residential street or alley, shall constitute a public nuisance.
3. All tree limbs, tree branches or shrubbery which are adjacent to a sidewalk or project into a sidewalk, and which are less than one foot (1') from
either edge of a sidewalk, roadways, measured horizontally, though such tree limbs, branches or shrubbery are not overhanging such sidewalk, shall
constitute a public nuisance.
4. All tree limbs, branches, or shrubbery which project over or overhang a nonresidential public street or alley, "nonresidential" being defined as a
public street or a part thereof along which the use of the property abutting said street or alley is primarily commercial, industrial, or other
nonresidential nature, and which said branches, limbs, or shrubbery, or any part thereof, are less than fourteen feet (14') above the surface of the
nonresidential street or alley, shall constitute a public nuisance.
5. Any owner or nonowner occupant who shall fail, refuse or neglect to trim trees, branches, limbs or shrubbery as provided in this subsection so as to
abate a nuisance as defined herein, after receiving ten (10) days' notice from the code enforcement officer or the city manager to do so, shall be
guilty of an offense. Every day that the owner or occupant shall fail, refuse or neglect to trim the trees, branches, limbs or shrubbery, after the
expiration of the ten (10) days' notice, shall be a separate offense. If abatement is required immediately to ensure public safety, then the city may
abate the public nuisance and trim any trees, limbs, branches or shrubbery which constitutes a nuisance, upon notice, if possible to the owner of
such tree or shrubbery or nonowner occupant or the premises on which the tree or shrubbery is located. The penalty for violation of this subsection is
as set forth in subsection G, "Penalty", of this section. (Ord. 2014-20, 10-28-2014)
G. Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof, be subject to a penalty as provided
in section 1-4-1 of this code. The city of Skiatook may also take any additional lawful action, including nuisance abatement proceedings or seeking an
injunction or restraining order from a court of competent jurisdiction, in order to restrain further violation of this section and to ensure compliance
therewith. (Ord. 2013-10, 6-25-2013; amd. Ord. 2014-20, 10-28-2014)
6-4G-6: SIGNS ON UTILITY POLES:
No person, firm or corporation shall place, install, maintain, or permit to be kept or maintained upon any utility pole, traffic control device, sign or structure
supporting the same which is located upon any street or public or municipal easement or right of way, any sign, placard, notice, paper, advertisement or
display of any nature. Each day a violation occurs shall be deemed a separate offense. (2011 Code)
6-4G-7: FIREWORKS:
A. Definitions: As used in this section, the following terms shall have the meanings specified below:
DISTRIBUTOR: Any person who sells fireworks to other distributors, wholesalers or retailers for resale.
FIREWORKS: Shall mean and include any composition or device for the purpose of producing a visible or an audible effect by combustion, explosion,
deflagration or detonation and which is defined as common or special fireworks by the United States department of transportation (DOT). Fireworks are
further classified in this law as 1.4G, UN0336 consumer fireworks (formerly "class C") or 1.3G, UN0335 display fireworks (formerly "class B"). The term
"fireworks" shall not include toy cap pistols and caps, blank cartridges, railroad flares and model rockets.
1.3G, UN0335 Display Fireworks (Formerly "Class B" Display Fireworks Or DOT Special Fireworks): All articles of larger fireworks designed primarily to
produce visible or audible effects by combustion or explosion. "1.3G (class B) display fireworks" include, but are not limited to, firecrackers and salutes
containing more than two (2) grains (130 mg) of explosive composition and other exhibition display items that exceed the limits for classification as
1.4G (class C) consumer fireworks according to the department of transportation.
1.4G, UN0336 Consumer Fireworks (Formerly "Class C" Fireworks Or DOT Common Fireworks): Any devices suitable for use by the public that
conform with the requirements of the United States consumer products safety commission and are designed primarily to produce visible effects by
combustion, and some small devices designed to produce an audible effect.
MANUFACTURER: Any person engaged in the making or construction of fireworks.
PERSON: Shall include any corporation, association, partnership or one or more individuals.
RETAILER: Any person who purchases fireworks for resale to consumers only.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 78/269
WHOLESALER: Any person who purchases fireworks for resale only to retailers and consumers.
B. Storage Of Fireworks: 1.4G (class C) consumer fireworks may be legally stored and sold in the city with the exception and conditions specified under
the provisions of this section. No other type of fireworks may be possessed, stored, sold or used within the city, unless specifically authorized herein.
C. Sale Of Fireworks; Regulations, License And Fee:
1. License Required; Fee; Location Approval: The following license fees shall be due and payable to the city on or before June 1 of each year: (Ord.
2012-07, 5-29-2012)
Any person operating a retail location where fireworks are sold shall be required to purchase a retail fireworks license. The retail license fee shall be
fifty dollars ($50.00) annually and must be purchased from the city clerk prior to June 1 of that year, after approval of the proposed location by the fire
chief. Upon application for the license, the applicant shall provide the fire chief with the location of the retail outlet, proof of age of applicant, and
evidence of all licenses required under state law. The fire chief shall refuse to approve any proposed location if, using accepted standards, he
determines the location because of its proximity to other activities or structures would create a significant risk of harm to persons or property. (Ord.
2012-07, 5-29-2012; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
2. Retail License Holder And Salesclerk Requirements:
a. The retail license holder shall be responsible for the safe operation of retail sales to the public. The retail license holder shall be at least sixteen
(16) years of age.
b. A salesclerk over sixteen (16) years of age must be on duty to serve the consumer at the time of purchase. All fireworks offered for retail sale must
be protected from direct contact and handling by the public at all times. Entry within that structure from which sales are made shall be forbidden to
the public.
3. Direct Contact And Handling By Public: Fireworks offered for retail sale must be protected from direct contact and handling by the public at all times.
Self-serve or marketing where retail customers are allowed to move among stocks of fireworks or serve themselves from fireworks stocks or displays
is strictly prohibited. Mail order sales to consumers are prohibited through any medium of either interstate or intrastate commerce. Sales of fireworks
may only be made at properly licensed retail locations within the city. A salesclerk must be on duty to serve the consumer at the time of purchase.
4. Sales Within Buildings; Public Access: Fireworks shall not be sold or displayed to the public within any building or portion thereof or within any
vehicle that allows entry by any persons other than employees within such building or vehicle unless the fireworks are kept where they cannot be
reached or handled by those persons. An enclosed building used for sale of fireworks to the public shall have adequate exits as determined by the
fire chief. The use of tents or nonrigid shelters for the sale or storage of fireworks where the public may move about under or within the confines of a
shelter is prohibited.
5. Sales Permitted In Certain Zoning Districts: The retail sale of 1.4G (class C) consumer fireworks shall be permitted only in those portions of the city
which have been zoned agricultural and commercial. Sales elsewhere are prohibited.
6. No Smoking Signs: All fireworks storage and sales areas shall be conspicuously posted with signs reading:
Fireworks - No Smoking.
7. Dates When Sales Allowed: No person shall offer fireworks for sale to residents of the city at retail before June 15 or after July 6, and before
December 15 or after January 2 in each year.
8. Bottle Rockets And Stick Rockets Prohibited: The sale, gift, distribution or use of skyrockets with sticks as defined by the United States department
of transportation is hereby prohibited within the city. This prohibition shall include, but not be limited to, explosive devices commonly known as "bottle
rockets" or "stick rockets".
9. Proper Labeling Required: Any and all items of 1.4G (class C) consumer fireworks not properly labeled according to the United States consumer
product safety commission and identified with the "DOT" 1.4G (class C) consumer fireworks marking on each retail sale unit is prohibited under the
provisions of this section.
10. Freestanding Structure: The sale of fireworks shall be made only from a freestanding structure which in all cases shall be located no less than one
hundred feet (100') from any permanent structure and one hundred feet (100') from any roadway. Said structure shall be a rigid structure, the sale of
fireworks from tents and/or nonrigid structures being expressly forbidden.
D. Discharge Of Fireworks Prohibited; Exceptions: The discharge, firing or use of firecrackers, rockets, torpedoes, roman candles, or other fireworks or
substances designed and intended for pyrotechnic display and of pistols, canes, cannons, or other appliances, using blank cartridges or caps
containing chlorate of potash mixture, is hereby prohibited, unless any of the following exceptions apply:
1. The city council may, by order or resolution, authorize display and discharge of fireworks, including 1.3G (class B) display fireworks, by properly
qualified individuals or organizations when such display is deemed for the enjoyment of the populace at large and is conducted and located in such a
manner and under circumstances that the city council is satisfied that the discharge or firing thereof will not be hazardous to surrounding property or
endanger any person or persons;
2. Persons within the city limits may use or otherwise discharge permissible 1.4G (class C) consumer fireworks only from three o'clock (3:00) P.M. to
eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on July 3 and July 4, provided the following conditions are met:
a. Such fireworks must be discharged on a noncombustible surface of sufficient size to contain the entire ground portion of the display and not closer
than twenty five feet (25') to any permanent structure. Except: It shall be unlawful to explode or ignite fireworks within five hundred feet (500') of
any church, hospital, asylum, unharvested flammable agricultural crop, public school or where fireworks are stored, sold, or offered for sale. No
person shall ignite or discharge any permissible articles of fireworks within or throw the same from a motor vehicle; nor shall any person place or
throw any ignited article of fireworks into or at such a motor vehicle or at or near any group of people.
b. An adult person (age 18 or over) must obtain a permit from the city at a cost of twenty dollars ($20.00). Said permit must identify the adult in
charge of this use by name and address, and also identify the proposed location on or near the permit holder's property. Applications for said
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 79/269
permits shall be made available during normal business hours (excluding holidays) from April 1 through July 3 of any given year and permits are
valid only for the year of issuance.
c. The possession or the sale of any fireworks to or by any individual under the age of twelve (12) years shall be unlawful within the city, unless under
the immediate and direct supervision of a parent, guardian, or other responsible adult in possession of a current permit.
d. The adult permit holder in charge of the use must be physically present for any household member to use the fireworks and said use shall be
within sixty feet (60') of the front door of the permitted residence. The permit shall be accessible for examination by any law enforcement officer.
The permit holder is further responsible for cleaning up any debris caused by any person discharging fireworks under the permit holder and such
debris must be cleaned up and removed within twenty four (24) hours of the same day the fireworks are discharged. Failure to remove the debris
shall be punished by a fine of two hundred twenty five dollars ($225.00) plus costs.
e. Private persons may not use or discharge fireworks within any city or county park, nor on any highway, turnpike, or any street that has paving in
excess of twenty six feet (26') wide, such as an arterial street, or collector street.
E. Emergency Fireworks Ban: In the event that the governor of the state of Oklahoma, or the board of county commissioners of Tulsa, Osage, and/or
Washington Counties calls a red flag fire alert or burn ban for the area encompassing the city of Skiatook and/or the city of Skiatook fire department
determines that the city of Skiatook is in fire danger due to the weather conditions, the city council may declare an emergency and cause the use of
fireworks to be terminated and declare them to be illegal during the emergency period. Any fireworks used during this emergency is a violation of this
section.
F. Violation: Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof, be subject to penalty as
provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. Violation of this section shall also be grounds for revocation or suspension of any license granted. Each violation
shall be deemed as a separate offense. (Ord. 2012-07, 5-29-2012)
6-4G-8: PROHIBITING OCCUPANCY AFTER DISCOVERY OF METHAMPHETAMINE MANUFACTURING ACTIVITY:
A. Purpose And Scope:
1. The purpose of this section is to protect occupants of real property from hazardous and contaminated living environments by requiring owners of real
property to remediate gross contamination of property caused by methamphetamine manufacturing activity prior to occupancy pursuant to the
standards described in this section.
2. Although other types of synthetic drugs may be manufactured in clandestine drug laboratories, this section is specifically intended to remediate the
contamination and environmental dangers associated with methamphetamine manufacturing activity.
B. Report Of Methamphetamine Manufacturing Activity: Upon discovery that an owner's property is, or has been, the location for any type of
methamphetamine manufacturing activity, an owner shall immediately report such activity to local law enforcement.
C. Prohibition On Occupancy: Until a contractor experienced in hazardous waste removal and remediation, as prescribed in this section, assesses the
contaminated property, cleans up any contamination and prepares a final report, as prescribed in this section, which shows that the levels of
contamination in the property meet the acceptable levels listed in subsection F of this section, use of the property for human habitation is prohibited.
D. Public Notice Of Contamination: Within twenty four (24) hours of discovery, an owner or the owner's designee shall display on the contaminated
structure(s), a public notice of contamination with the following information:
1. The word "Warning" in bold type on the notice.
2. The address of the contaminated property or, if the property has multiple structures upon it, the address of each contaminated structure in bold type
on the notice.
3. A statement with the following language: "Hazardous Substances, Toxic Chemicals, Or Other Waste Products May Be Present On The Property" in
bold type on the notice.
4. An additional warning with the following language "Any Person Who Enters The Structure(s) Without Permission Of The Owner Or Law Enforcement
Will Have Committed A Trespass And May Be Held Criminally And/Or Civilly Liable. Owner Name: ; Owner Contact Number: ; Skiatook Police
Department Contact Number: 918-396-2424" in bold type on the notice.
E. Assessment And Remediation:
1. Upon discovery that an owner's property is or has been the location for any type of methamphetamine manufacturing activity, an owner, prior to
occupancy of the property and after the removal of methamphetamine manufacturing materials and equipment by law enforcement, shall retain the
services of a contractor who is experienced in hazardous waste removal and remediation to assess the level of contamination within the property and
provide a written report documenting the level of contamination. At a minimum, such contractor shall have completed forty (40) hours of hazardous
