H. Ride or use skateboards, rollerblades, bicycles, or similar devices in prohibited areas. (Ord. 2012-09, 7-14-2012)
8-2-12: BOATING:
No boats of any kind are allowed on city owned lakes, ponds or streams except with a permit issued by the city. (Ord. 2012-09, 7-14-2012)
8-2-13: REGULATED ACTIVITIES:
The following activities are prohibited within city parks unless an event permit is issued in accordance with this chapter:
A. Swimming, bathing, floating or wading in ponds, fountains, streams or lakes;
B. Fishing, trapping, seining, or removal of any fish;
C. Boating on ponds, streams or lakes except with a permit from the approving governing representative;
D. Archery;
E. Camping;
F. Throwing or propelling any object in such a manner as to create a hazard to persons or property;
G. Trapping, hunting, shooting or attempt to shoot or molest in any manner any bird, wildfowl or animal or to rob bird nests or wildfowl nests in or on any
city park. The chief of police may grant permission to appropriate officers to remove animals or fowl which constitute a nuisance or menace to health or
property. (Ord. 2012-09, 7-14-2012)
8-2-14: DISCHARGE OF FIREARMS OR HUNTING IN PARKS:
It is unlawful for any person to discharge any firearm or weapon in or on any part of any city park. No game bird or animal or migratory fowl may be hunted
or taken in or on any city park, at any time. (Ord. 2012-09, 7-14-2012)
8-2-15: PERMITS:
A. Permits for special events in parks and recreation areas shall be obtained by application to the city council in accordance with the following procedure:
1. A person seeking issuance of a permit under this section shall file an application stating:
a. The name and address of the applicant;
b. The name and address of the person, corporation or association sponsoring the activity, if any;
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 114/269
c. The day and hours for which the permit is desired;
d. The park or portion thereof for which the permit is desired;
e. Any other information reasonably necessary to a determination as to whether a permit should be issued;
f. Variances required from park rules and regulations, if any.
2. Standards for issuance of a use permit shall include the following findings:
a. That the proposed activity or use of the park will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the general public's enjoyment of the park.
b. That the proposed activity and use will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the promotion of public health, welfare, safety and
recreation.
c. That the proposed activity or uses that are reasonably anticipated will not include violence, crime or disorderly conduct.
d. That the proposed activity will not entail extraordinary or burdensome expense or police operation by the city.
e. That the facilities desired have not been reserved for other use on the date and hour requested in the application.
B. Within thirty (30) calendar days after the receipt of an application the city council may make a decision whether to grant or deny a permit. If the city
council fails to make said decision within the thirty (30) day time period, the application for the permit shall be deemed denied.
C. The decision of the city council shall be final.
D. A permittee shall be bound by all park rules and regulations and all applicable ordinances fully as though the same were inserted in the permit.
E. An applicant for a permit may be required to submit evidence of liability insurance covering injuries to the permittee and members of the general public
arising out of such permitted activities in the amount of the potential liability of the city under "the Oklahoma governmental tort claims act"1 prior to the
commencement of any activity or issuance of any permit unless such insurance requirement is waived or lessened by contract approval, or motion or
resolution of the city council.
F. The city council shall have the authority to revoke a permit upon a finding of violation of any rule or ordinance or upon good cause shown. (Ord. 2012-
09, 7-14-2012)
8-2-16: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to penalty
as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2012-09, 7-14-2012)
Chapter 3
CABLE TELEVISION
8-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter the following terms, phrases, words, and abbreviations shall have the meanings ascribed to them below. When not
inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future tense, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words
in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not directory.
AFFILIATE: An entity which owns or controls, is owned or controlled by, or is under common ownership with grantee.
BASIC CABLE: The tier of service regularly provided to all subscribers that includes the retransmission of local broadcast television signals. Basic cable
service as defined herein shall not be inconsistent with 47 USC section 543(b)(7).
CABLE SERVICE: A. The one-way transmission of video programming or other programming services; and
B. Subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection of such video programming or other services provided through electric or electronic
signals, or which utilizes any facility or equipment of the cable system. For the purposes of this chapter, providers of direct-broadcast satellite
television do not operate a cable service.
CABLE SYSTEM: A facility, consisting of a set of closed transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception, and control equipment or other
communications equipment that is designed to provide cable service which includes video programming and other service to multiple subscribers within a
community, and which utilizes the public rights of way within the city to provide cable service.
CITY: The city of Skiatook or its lawful successor, transferee, or assignee thereof.
FCC: Federal communications commission, or successor governmental entity thereto.
GRANTEE: Community Cable & Broadband, Inc., or its lawful successor.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 115/269
GROSS REVENUES: All cash, funds, monies, credits, property of any kind or nature, or other consideration received directly or indirectly by Community
Cable & Broadband, Inc., its affiliates, subsidiaries, parent and any person in which Community Cable & Broadband, Inc., has financial interest, arising
from or attributed to the sale or exchange of cable communications services provided by Community Cable & Broadband, Inc., within the city of Skiatook,
including, but not limited to, basic cable service, cable programming services of different levels and packages, and pay television paid by subscribers to
the cable system operated by grantee.
1984 CABLE ACT: The cable communications policy act of 1984, as amended from time to time.
1992 CABLE ACT: The cable television consumer protection and competition act of 1992, as amended.
PERMIT: The consent and authorization of the city whether such authorization is designated as a permit, license, franchise, resolution, contract, certificate,
or otherwise, which authorizes use of the public streets and rights of way and construction and operation of the cable system for the purpose of offering
cable service subscribers. The term "permit" shall have the same meaning as "franchise" within the context of applicable state and federal law regulating
the transmission of cable systems and cable service to subscribers.
PERSON: An individual, partnership, association, joint stock company, trust corporation, or governmental entity.
PUBLIC WAY: The surface of and the space above and below, any public street, highway, freeway, bridge, land path, alley, court, boulevard, sidewalk,
parkway, way, public way, drive, circle, or other public right of way, including, but not limited to, public utility easements, dedicated utility strips, or rights of
way dedicated for compatible uses in any temporary or permanent fixtures or improvements located thereon now or hereafter held by the city in the service
area which shall entitle the city and the grantee to the use thereof for the purpose of installing, operating, repairing, and maintaining the cable system.
Public way shall also mean any easement now or hereafter held by the city within the service area for the purpose of public travel, or for any utility or
public service use dedicated for compatible uses, and shall include other easements or rights of way as shall within their proper use and meaning entitle
the city and the grantee to the use of thereof for the purpose of installing or transmitting grantee's cable service or other services over poles, wires, cables,
conductors, ducts, conduits, vaults, manholes, amplifiers, appliances, attachments, and other property as may be ordinarily necessary and pertinent to the
cable system.
SERVICE AREA: The present municipal boundaries of the city and shall include any additions thereto by annexation or other legal means.
SERVICE TIER: A category of cable service or other services provided by the grantee and for which a separate charge is made by grantee.
SUBSCRIBER: A person or user of the cable system who lawfully receives cable services or other services therefrom with grantee's express permission.
VIDEO PROGRAMMING: Programming provided by, or generally considered comparable to, programming provided by a television broadcast station.
(Ord. 2013-07, 5-14-2013)
8-3-2: GRANT OF PERMIT:
A. Grant:
1. The city hereby grants to grantee a nonexclusive permit which authorizes the grantee to construct and operate a cable system and provide cable
service and other related services in the city of Skiatook and to use the public rights of way within the service area; and for that purpose to erect,
install, construct, repair, replace, reconstruct, maintain, or retain in, on, over, under, upon, across, or along any public way and all extensions thereof
and additions thereto, such poles, wires, cables, conductors, ducts, conduits, vaults, manholes, pedestals, amplifiers, appliances, attachments, and
other related property or equipment as may be necessary or appurtenant to the cable system, as long as the grantee complies with terms,
conditions, and provisions of this chapter, and the building, plumbing, mechanical, electric, fire and safety ordinances and health codes of the city of
Skiatook, the state of Oklahoma, or the United States Of America and any other applicable rules or regulations of the federal communications
commission, or federal aviation administration as may be required, and the 1984 cable act.
2. Grantee shall utilize existing poles, conduits and other facilities whenever possible, and shall not construct or install any new, different or additional
poles, conduits, or other facilities, on public property, until written approval of the city is obtained. However, no location of any pole or wire holding
structure of grantee shall be a vested interest and such poles or structures shall be removed or modified by grantee at its own expense whenever the
city determines that the public convenience would be enhanced thereby.
3. This permit granted hereby is nonexclusive and nothing herein shall be construed to divest the city of total control and regulation of the public ways
within the city of Skiatook, Oklahoma.
B. Terms: Pursuant to this chapter, the city of Skiatook grants to the grantee a nonexclusive permit for a term of ten (10) years from the effective date of
this permit, unless otherwise lawfully terminated in accordance with the terms of this chapter. Provided, however, that either party may, upon notice
given sixty (60) days prior to the expiration date of the permit granted herein, request a renegotiation of the terms of this permit, such negotiations to be
completed prior to the expiration of the initial term of the permit.
C. Acceptance; Effective Date: The grantee shall accept the permit granted pursuant hereto by signing the permit and filing same with the city clerk or
other appropriate official or agency of the city within ten (10) days after or the passage and final adoption of this permit. Subject to the acceptance by
grantee, the effective date of this permit shall relate back to the date of its passage and final adoption by the city council of the city of Skiatook.
D. Favored Nations: In the event the city enters into a permit, license, authorization, or other agreement of any kind with any other person or entity other
than grantee to enter into the city's streets and public ways for the purpose of constructing or operating a cable system or providing cable service to
any other part of the service area, the material provisions thereof shall be reasonably comparable to those contained herein, in order that one operator
not be granted an unfair competitive advantage over another. (Ord. 2013-07, 5-14-2013)
8-3-3: STANDARDS OF SERVICE:
A. Operational Standards: The grantee shall maintain and operate the cable system as to provide video, audio, and other signals to be delivered with the
signal strength and quality levels which meet the requirements specified by the FCC and any other normally accepted industry standards. Under
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 116/269
normal operating conditions, each of the following standards shall be met no less than ninety five percent (95%) of the time on an annual basis.
Standard installations shall be performed within seven (7) business days after an order has been placed; and, except when beyond the control of the
grantee, the grantee shall respond to cable system outage promptly, and in no event, later than twenty four (24) hours in those cases involving five (5)
or more subscribers.
B. Condition Of Street Occupancy: All transmission and distribution structures, poles, other lines, and equipment installed or erected by the grantee
pursuant to the terms hereof must have prior approval of the city with regard to location, height, type, and other pertinent aspects, and shall be located
so as to cause a minimum of interference with the proper use of public ways and with the rights and reasonable convenience of property owners who
own property that adjoins any of said public ways. The grantee shall not have a vested right to retain the location of any pole, conduit, or structure
installed by grantee. Such poles, conduit, and structures shall be removed or modified by the grantee at its own expense when necessary for the
convenience of the city.
C. Installation And Maintenance Standards: All cable transmission lines, equipment and structures shall be so installed and maintained so as to cause
minimum interference with the rights and reasonable convenience of property owners and the city and at all times shall be kept and maintained in a
safe, adequate and substantial condition, and in good order and repair. The grantee shall at all times use ordinary care and shall install and maintain in
use commonly accepted methods and devices for preventing failures and accidents which are likely to cause damage, injuries or nuisances to the
public. Suitable barricades, flags, lights, flares or other safety devices shall be used at such times and places as are reasonably required for the safety
of all members of the public. Any poles or fixtures placed in any public way by the grantee shall be placed in such a manner as to not interfere with the
usual travel on such public way.
D. Restoration Of Public Ways: If during the course of grantee's construction, operation, or maintenance of the cable system there occurs a disturbance or
damage of any public way by the grantee, it shall, at its expense, replace and restore such public way in a manner approved by the city to a condition
reasonably comparable to the condition of the public way existing immediately prior to such disturbance. The grantee shall guarantee and maintain
such restoration for a period of one year against defective materials or workmanship.
E. Relocation At Request Of City: Upon its receipt of a reasonable advance notice, not to be less than five (5) business days, the grantee shall, at its own
expense, protect, support, temporarily disconnect, relocate in the public way, or remove from the public way, any property of the grantee when lawfully
required by the city by reason of traffic conditions, public safety, street abandonment, freeway and street construction, change or establishment of
street grade, installation of sewers, drains, gas or water lines, or any other type of structures or improvements by the city; but, the grantee shall in all
cases have the right of abandonment of its property. If public funds are available to any company using such street, easement, or right of way for the
specific purpose of defraying the cost of any of the foregoing, such funds shall also be made available to the grantee.
F. Relocation At Request Of Third Party: The grantee shall, on the request of any person holding a permit issued by the city to move a building or
structure, temporarily raise or lower its wires to permit the moving of such building or structure, provided: 1) the expense of such temporary raising of
the wires is paid by said person, including, if required by the grantee, making such payment in advance; and 2) the grantee is given not less than
seventy two (72) hours' advance written notice to arrange for such temporary wire changes.
G. Trimming Of Trees And Shrubbery: The grantee shall have the authority to trim trees or other natural growth overhanging any of its cable system in the
service area on public property, subject to the supervision and direction of the city, so as to prevent branches from coming in contact with the grantee's
wires, cables, or other equipment. The grantee shall reasonably compensate the city or property owner for any damages caused by such trimming, or
shall, at its cost and expense, reasonably replace all trees or shrubs damaged as a result of any construction or maintenance of the system undertaken
by the grantee. The grantee shall notify the property owner at least twenty four (24) hours prior to such trimming, unless such trimming is necessary
due to a bona fide emergency. Trimming trees on private property shall require the consent of the property owner. Grantee shall indemnify and hold the
city harmless for any and all claims or causes of action arising out of the trimming of trees and shrubbery by grantee.
H. Use Of Grantee's Equipment By City: Subject to any applicable state or federal regulation or tariffs, the city shall have the right to make additional use,
for any public purpose, of any poles or conduits controlled or maintained exclusively by or for the grantee in any public way; provided, that: 1) such use
by the city does not interfere with a current or future use by the grantee; and 2) at grantee's sole discretion, the city may be required either to pay a
reasonable rental fee or otherwise reasonably compensate the grantee for the use of such poles, conduit, or equipment; provided, however, the
grantee agrees that such compensation or charge shall not exceed like charges paid by public utilities pursuant to the applicable pole attachment
agreement, or other authorization, relating to the service area within the city of Skiatook.
I. Emergency Repair Of Public Ways: The city shall not be liable to the grantee for any injury to grantee's cable system caused by any city or Skiatook
public works authority employee while performing emergency repairs within the public ways. In all other circumstances, when city employees
negligently injure grantee's cable system, the city shall only be liable to the grantee for the grantee's actual cost of materials, equipment, and labor
necessary to effect repairs, with no allowance for interruptions to service or loss of revenue, subject to any applicable limits of liability established by
the Oklahoma government tort claims act1. The grantee shall file with the city clerk a schedule of the current costs of materials, equipment, and labor
necessary to make repairs.
J. Safety Requirements: Construction, installation, and maintenance of the cable system shall be performed in an orderly and workmanlike manner. All
such work shall be performed in substantial accordance with acceptable FCC or other federal, state, and local regulations. The cable system shall not
unreasonably endanger or interfere with the safety of persons or property in the service area.
K. Service Interruption: The grantee shall maintain and operate its system and render efficient service in accordance with such rules and regulations as
are, or may be, hereinafter promulgated by the federal communications commission. Whenever it is necessary to interrupt service for the purpose of
making repairs, adjustments, or installations, the grantee shall do so at such times as will cause the least amount of inconvenience to its customers,
and unless such interruption is unforeseen and immediately necessary, the grantee shall give reasonable notice thereof to the customers.
L. Aerial And Underground Construction: In those areas of the service area where all of the transmission or distribution facilities of the respected public
utilities providing telephone communications and electric service are underground, the grantee likewise shall construct, operate, and maintain all of its
transmission and distribution facilities underground; provided that such facilities are actually capable of receiving grantee's cable and other equipment
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 117/269
without technical degradation of the cable system's signal quality. In those areas of the service area where the transmission or distribution facilities of
the respective public utilities providing telephone communications, and electrical service are both aerial and underground, the grantee shall have the
sole discretion to construct, operate, and maintain all of its transmission and distribution facilities, or any part thereof, aerially or underground. Nothing
contained in this subsection shall require the grantee to construct, operate, or maintain underground any ground mounted appurtenances such as
subscriber taps, line extenders, system passive devices (splitters, directional couplers), amplifiers, power supplies, pedestals, or other related
equipment. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this subsection, in the event that all of the transmission or distribution facilities of the
respected public utilities providing telephone communications and electrical services are placed underground after the effective date hereof, the
grantee shall only be required to construct, operate, and maintain all of its transmission and distribution facilities underground if it is given reasonable
notice and access to the public utilities facilities at the time that such are placed underground.
M. Required Extensions Of Service: The cable system, as constructed as of the date of the passage and final adoption of this chapter, substantially
complies with the material provisions thereof. The grantee is hereby authorized to extend the cable system as necessary, as desirable, or as required
pursuant to the terms hereof within the service area. Whenever the grantee shall receive a request for service from at least fifteen (15) subscribers
within one thousand three hundred twenty (1,320) cable bearing strand feet (1/4 cable mile) of its trunk or distribution cable, it shall extend its cable
system to such subscribers at no cost to said subscribers for system extension, other than the usual connection fees for all subscribers; provided, that
such extension is technically feasible, and if it will not adversely affect the operation, financial condition, or market development of the cable system, or
as provided for under subsection K of this section.
N. Subscriber Changes For Extension Of Service: No subscriber shall be refused service arbitrarily. However, for unusual circumstances, such as a
subscriber's request to locate his cable drop underground, existence of more than one hundred fifty feet (150') of distance from distribution cable to
connection of service to the subscribers, or a density of less than fifteen (15) subscribers per one thousand three hundred twenty (1,320) cable bearing
strand feet of trunk or distribution cable, cable service or other service may be made available on the basis of a capital contribution in aid of
construction, including cost of material, labor, and easements. For the purpose of determining the amount of capital contribution in aid of construction to
be borne by the grantee and subscribers in the area in which cable service may be expanded, the grantee shall contribute an amount equal to the
construction and other cost per mile, multiplied by a fraction whose numerator equals the actual number of potential subscribers per one thousand
three hundred twenty (1,320) cable bearing strand feet of its trunks or distribution cable, and whose denominator equals fifteen (15) subscribers.
Potential subscribers will bear the remainder of the construction and other costs on a pro rata basis. The grantee may require that the payment of the
capital contribution in aid of construction borne by such potential subscribers be paid in advance.
O. Service To Public Buildings: The grantee shall provide without charge one outlet of basic service to each city office building(s), fire station(s), police
station(s), and public school building(s) that are passed by its cable system. The outlets of basic service shall not be used to distribute or sell cable
service in or throughout such buildings. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary set forth in this section, the grantee shall not be required to provide an
outlet to such building where the drop line from the feeder cable to said building or premises exceeds two hundred (200) cable feet, unless it is
technically feasible and so long as it will not adversely affect the operation, financial condition, or market development of the cable system to do so, or
unless the appropriate governmental entity agrees to pay the incremental cost of such dropped line in excess of two hundred (200) cable feet. In the
event that additional outlets of basic service are provided to such building, the building owner shall pay the usual installation fee associated therewith,
including, but not limited to, labor and materials. Upon request of the grantee, the building owner may also be required to pay the service fee
associated with the provision of basic service to the additional outlets.
P. Emergency Override: In the case of an emergency or disaster, the grantee shall, upon request of the city, make available its facilities for the city to
provide emergency information and instruction during the emergency or disaster period, at no cost to the city.
Q. Governmental And Educational:
1. The grantee shall provide, at no cost to the user, adequate channels for governmental and educational use and for the networking among
governmental or educational users. The grantee shall also provide technical assistance required for the use of these channels and assist with
recommendations of proper equipment, to be purchased by the user. In no event shall this chapter be interpreted to require the grantee to provide
any equipment necessary for the use of these channels.
2. The grantee shall have the right to temporarily use any unused portion of a channel allocated under this section which is not being fully utilized,
provided such use shall not interfere with any educational or government use. If the channels provided for governmental and educational use are
being fully utilized, the grantee shall provide, at no cost to the user, additional governmental and educational channels. Generally, a channel shall be
considered as being fully utilized if more than an average of forty eight (48) hours per week over a six (6) month period of programming other than
character generated programming is offered.
3. The grantee shall not make any separate or premium charge to a subscriber for access to educational or governmental channels.
4. All channels allocated for governmental or educational use shall be of the same quality as the channels on the cable system for cable service. All
channels allocated for educational use shall be available to subscribers in the service area and the service areas of other cable systems
interconnected with the cable system. (Ord. 2013-07, 5-14-2013)
8-3-4: REGULATION BY CITY:
A. Permit Fee: The grantee shall pay to the city, as compensation of the rights and privileges enjoyed under this permit, a fee equal to four percent (4%) of
gross revenue (as defined in section 8-3-1 of this chapter) received by the grantee from the operation of the cable system on a quarterly basis;
provided, however, that the grantee may credit against such payment: 1) any tax, fee, or assessment of any kind imposed by the city or other
governmental entity on a cable operator, or subscriber, or both solely because of their status as such; 2) any tax, fee or assessment of general
applicability which is unduly discriminatory against cable operators or subscribers (including any such tax, fee, or assessment imposed, both on utilities
and cable operators and their services); and 3) any other special tax, assessment, or fee such as a business, occupation, and entertainment tax. The
permit fee payment shall be due and payable in thirty (30) days after the end of each calendar quarter. Each payment shall be accompanied by a brief
report from a representative of the grantee showing the basis for the computation. If payment of the permit fee is not made by the grantee before the
expiration of thirty (30) days after each quarter, a daily late fee and penalty will be assessed in the amount of three dollars thirty cents ($3.30) per day,
beginning with the thirty first day after the end of each quarter.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 118/269
B. Rates And Charges: The city may not regulate the rates for the provision of cable service and other services, including, but not limited to, ancillary
charges relating thereto, except as expressly provided herein and except as authorized pursuant to the federal and state law including, but not limited
to, the cable act and FCC rules and regulations relating thereto. From time to time, and at any time, the grantee has the right to modify its rates and
charges including, but not limited to, the implementation of the additional charges and rates; provided, however, that the grantee shall give notice to the
city of any such modifications or additional charges ninety (90) days prior to the effective date thereof.
C. Renewal Of License:
1. The city and the grantee agree that any proceeding undertaken by the city that relates to the renewal of the grantee's permit shall be governed by
and comply with the provisions of section 626 of the cable act (as such existed as of the effective date of this chapter), unless the procedures and
substantive projections set forth therein shall be deemed to be preempted and superseded by the provisions of any subsequent provision of federal
or state law.
2. In addition to the procedures set forth in said section 626(a), the city agrees to notify the grantee of preliminary assessments regarding the identity of
future cable related community needs and interests, as well as the past performance of the grantee under the then current permit term. The city
further agrees that such a preliminary assessment shall be provided to the grantee prior to the time that the four (4) month period referred to in
subsection (c) of section 626 of the cable act is considered to begin. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary set forth in this subsection, the grantee
and the city agree that at any time during the term of the then current permit, while affording the public appropriate notice and opportunity to
comment, the city and the grantee may agree to undertake and finalize negotiations regarding renewal of the then current permit and the city may
grant a renewal thereof. The grantee and the city consider the terms set forth in this section to be consistent with the express provision of section
626 of the cable act.
D. Conditions Of Sale:
1. Except to the extent expressly required by federal or state law, if a renewal or extension of the grantee's permit is denied or the permit is lawfully
terminated, and the city either lawfully acquires ownership of the cable system or by its actions lawfully effects the transfer of ownership of the cable
system to another party, any such acquisition or transfer shall be valued at the fair market value, determined on the basis of the cable system valued
as a going concern, unless otherwise agreed by the parties. The city of Skiatook is under no obligation to compensate the grantee for loss of its
cable system or to purchase the cable system from grantee, unless otherwise agreed by the parties.
2. The grantee and the city agree that in the case of a lawful revocation/termination of the permit, the grantee shall be given a reasonable opportunity
to effectuate a transfer of its cable system to a qualified third party. The city further agrees that during such a period of time, it shall authorize the
grantee to continue to operate pursuant to the terms of its prior permit; however, in no event shall such authorization exceed a period of time greater
than six (6) months from the effective date of such revocation. If, at the end of that time, the grantee is unsuccessful in procuring qualified transferee
or assignee of its cable system which is reasonably acceptable to the city, the city and the grantee may avail themselves of any rights they may have
pursuant to the federal or state law; it being further agreed that the grantee's continued operation of its cable systems during the six (6) month period
shall not be deemed to be a waiver, nor an extinguishment of, any rights of either the city or the grantee. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary set
forth in this subsection, neither the city nor the grantee shall be required to violate federal or state law.
E. Transfer Of Permit: The grantee's rights, title, or interest in the permit shall not be sold, transferred, assigned, or otherwise encumbered, without the
prior written consent of the city, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld. The grantee shall give the city at least sixty (60) days' notice of any
such proposed assignment, sale or transfer. No such consent shall be required, however, for a transfer and trust, by mortgage or security agreement,
by other hypothecation, or by assignment of any rights, title, or interest of grantee in the permit or cable system in order to secure indebtedness. (Ord.
2013-07, 5-14-2013)
8-3-5: COMPLIANCE AND MONITORING:
A. Books And Records: The grantee agrees that the city may review such of its books and records, during normal business hours and on a nondisruptive
basis, as is reasonably necessary to monitor compliance with the terms hereof. Such records shall include, but shall not be limited to, any public
records required to be kept by the grantee pursuant to the rules and regulations of the FCC. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary set forth herein,
the city agrees to treat any information disclosed by the grantee to it as confidential and only to disclose it to employees, representatives, and agents
thereof that have a need to know, or in order to enforce the provisions hereof.
B. Customer Service Log: The grantee shall maintain a local telephone or toll free number for the purpose of individuals registering complaints, requests
for repair, installations, or adjustments. In the event of a subscriber complaint, the grantee shall maintain a written log recording the nature of such
complaint, the result of its investigation, and the disposition of the complaint. Copies of all petitions, applications and communications submitted by the
grantee to the FCC, or any other federal or state regulatory commission or agency having jurisdiction, in respect to any matters affecting cable system
operation authorized pursuant to this permit, shall be submitted to the city manager upon request. (Ord. 2013-07, 5-14-2013)
8-3-6: INSURANCE, INDEMNIFICATION, AND BONDS OR OTHER SURETY:
A. Insurance Requirements: The grantee shall maintain in full force and effect, at its own cost and expense, during the term of this chapter comprehensive
general liability insurance in the amount of at least one million dollars ($1,000,000.00); provided if the maximum liability to the city under the Oklahoma
governmental tort claims act2 should be increased to more than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single limit for bodily injury, and property
damage, the amount of liability insurance required hereunder shall be increased to that amount. Said insurance shall designate the city as an additional
insured. The grantee shall file with the city clerk certificates of the insurance required hereunder in the form satisfactory to the city attorney. In no event
shall the insurance coverage maintained by the grantee be less than the limits of liability as set forth in the governmental tort claims act applicable to
the city.
B. Indemnification: The grantee agrees to indemnify, save and hold harmless, and defend the city, its officers, agents and employees, from and against
any and all liability for damages and for any liability or claim resulting from property damage or bodily injury (including accidental death) which arise out
of the grantee's construction, operation, or maintenance of its cable system, or damages arising out of any provisions or requirements of this chapter or
its enforcement, including, but not limited to, reasonable attorney fees and costs.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 119/269
C. Bonds And Other Surety:
1. Except as expressly provided herein, the grantee shall not be required to obtain or maintain bonds or other surety as a condition of being awarded
the permit or continuing its existence. The city acknowledges that the legal, financial, and technical qualifications of the grantee are sufficient to
afford compliance with the terms of this chapter and the enforcement thereof. The grantee and city recognize that the costs associated with bonds
and other surety may ultimately be borne by the subscribers in the form of increased rates for cable services.
2. In order to minimize such costs, the city agrees to require bonds and other surety only in such amounts and during such times as there is a
reasonable demonstrated need therefor. The city agrees that in no event, however, shall it require a bond or other related surety in an aggregate
amount greater than two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) conditioned upon the substantial performance of the material terms,
covenants, and conditions of the city. Initially, no bond or other surety will be required. In the event that one is required in the future, the city agrees to
give the grantee at least sixty (60) days' prior written notice thereof stating the exact reason for the requirement. (Ord. 2013-07, 5-14-2013)
8-3-7: ENFORCEMENT AND TERMINATION/EXPIRATION OF PERMIT:
A. Notice Of Violation: In the event that the city believes that the grantee has not complied with the terms of this chapter, it shall notify the grantee in writing
of the exact nature of the alleged noncompliance. In the event that the city finds that the grantee has not paid the required permit/franchise fees when
the same are due, the city shall send written notice of such failure, and the grantee shall have fifteen (15) business days to remit the permit/franchise
fees then due. Should the grantee fail to remit the permit/franchise fees then due, the city may, at its sole option, cancel and terminate this permit, and
take all lawful actions to enforce its rights hereunder, including, but not limited to, the rights and remedies set forth in subsection D of this section.
B. Grantee's Right To Cure Or Respond: The grantee shall have thirty (30) days from receipt of the notice described in subsection A of this section: 1) to
respond to the city contesting the assertion of noncompliance, or 2) to cure such default, or 3) in the event that the nature of default cannot be cured
within the thirty (30) day period, initiate reasonable steps to remedy such default and notify the city of the steps being taken and the projected date that
they will be completed.
C. Public Hearing: In the event that the grantee fails to respond to the notice described in subsection A of this section pursuant to the procedures set forth
in subsection B of this section, or in the event that the default is not remedied within thirty (30) days after the grantee is notified of the default pursuant
to subsection A of this section, the city shall schedule a public meeting to investigate the default. Such public meeting shall be held at the next regularly
scheduled meeting of the city council which is scheduled at a time which is no less than five (5) business days therefrom. The city shall notify the
grantee of the time and place of such meeting and provide the grantee with an opportunity to be heard.
D. Enforcement:
1. Subject to applicable federal and state law, in the event the city, after such meeting determines that the grantee is in default of any provision of the
permit, the city may:
a. Foreclose on all or any part of any security provided under this permit, if any, including without limitation, any bonds or other surety; provided,
however, the foreclosure shall only be in such a manner and in such amount as the city determines necessary to remedy the default;
b. Commence an action at law for monetary damages or seek other equitable relief;
c. Declare the permit granted hereby canceled, terminated and revoked; or
d. Seek specific performance of any problem which reasonably lends itself to such remedy, as an alternative to damages.
2. The grantee shall not be relieved of any of its obligations to comply promptly with any provision of this chapter by reason of any failure of the city to
enforce prompt compliance.
E. Acts Of God: The grantee shall not be held in default or noncompliance with the provisions of this chapter, nor suffer any enforcement or penalty
relating thereto, where such noncompliance or defaults are caused by strikes, acts of God, power outages, or other events reasonably beyond its ability
to control.
F. Removal At Expiration/Termination Of Permit: At the expiration of the term for which this permit/franchise is granted, or upon the expiration of any
renewal or extension period which may be granted, or the lawful termination of this permit/franchise, the city shall, subject to any other lawful and valid
authorizations the grantee may have to use its system in the public rights of way, have the right to require the grantee, at the grantee's sole expense, to
remove all portions of the cable system from all rights of way within the city and to restore affected sites to their original condition. The city may not
order removal of the cable system, or any portion thereof, until the parties have exhausted all applicable processes governing cable television franchise
renewals as set forth in 47 USC section 546. Should the grantee fail, refuse or neglect to comply with the city's directives, all portions of the cable
system, or any part thereof, may at the option of the city, become the sole property of the city, at no expense to the city, or be removed, altered or
relocated by the city at the cost of the grantee. The city shall not be liable to the grantee for damages resulting from such removal, alteration or
relocation. This section is subject to the provisions of subsection 8-3-4D of this chapter. (Ord. 2013-07, 5-14-2013)
8-3-8: UNAUTHORIZED RECEPTION:
It shall be a misdemeanor for any person, firm or corporation to create or make use of any unauthorized connection, whether physically, electrically,
acoustically, inductively, or otherwise, with any part of the cable system without the express consent of the grantee. Further, without the express consent of
grantee, it shall be a misdemeanor for any person to tamper with, remove or injure any property, equipment, or part of the cable system or any means of
receiving cable service or other services provided thereto. Subject to applicable federal and state law, the city shall incorporate into its criminal code, if not
presently a part thereof, criminal misdemeanor law, which will enforce the intent of this section. (Ord. 2013-07, 5-14-2013)
8-3-9: MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 120/269
A. Documents Incorporated And Made A Part Of Chapter: The following documents shall be incorporated herein by this reference, and in the case of a
conflict or ambiguity between or among them, the document of latest date shall govern:
1. Any enabling ordinance in existence as of the effective date hereof; and
2. Any agreement between the grantee and the city reflecting the renewal of the permit, if any.
B. Preemption: If the FCC, or any other federal or state body or agency, shall now or hereafter exercise paramount jurisdiction over the subject matter of
the permit, and to the extent such jurisdiction shall preempt and supersede or preclude the exercise of the like jurisdiction by the city, the jurisdiction of
the city shall cease and no longer exist.
C. Actions Of City: The city of Skiatook makes no covenant or warranty of any nature relating to the validity or duration of this chapter or any of the rights
created hereby. Furthermore, in any instance where approval or consent is required under the terms hereof, such approval or consent shall not be
unreasonable to withhold.
D. Service Discrimination Prohibited: The grantee is prohibited from denying access to cable service to any group of potential residential cable subscribers
because of the income of the residents of the local area in which such group resides. The grantee shall not discriminate among subscribers and
potential subscribers to the cable service.
E. Legal Compliance: The city shall comply with all applicable federal, state and local laws and standards with respect to the construction, maintenance
and operation of a cable system.
F. Notices: Unless expressly otherwise agreed between the parties, every notice or response to be served upon the city or grantee shall be in writing, and
shall be deemed to have been duly served to the required party seven (7) business days after having been posted in a properly sealed and correctly
addressed envelope by certified or registered mail, postage prepaid, at a post office or branch thereof regularly maintained by the U.S. postal service.
1. The notices or responses to the city shall be addressed as follows:
City Of Skiatook
Attn: City Manager
P.O. Box 399
Skiatook, OK 74070
2. The notices or responses to the grantee shall be addressed as follows:
Community Cable & Broadband, Inc.
Attn: Dennis Soule
P.O. Box 307
Skiatook, OK 74070
3. The city and the grantee may designate such other address or addresses from time to time by giving notice to the other.
G. Descriptive Headings: The captions to sections contained herein are intended solely to facilitate the reading thereof. Such captions shall not affect the
meaning or interpretation of the text herein. (Ord. 2013-07, 5-14-2013)
Chapter 4
OSAGE GARDENS CEMETERY1
8-4-1: CEMETERY DEDICATION:
The property, as more fully described in the plat thereof and attached to ordinance 98-04, is hereby dedicated as a municipal cemetery for the city, and is
to be known as Osage Gardens Cemetery. (Ord. 98-04, 3-31-1998)
8-4-2: GOVERNMENT OF CEMETERY:
The cemetery of the city shall be governed by the city council and operated under the general supervision of the city manager. (Ord. 98-04, 3-31-1998)
8-4-3: CARETAKER AND OTHER EMPLOYEES:
A. Employment And Discharge: The caretaker and other employees of the municipal cemetery shall be employed and may be discharged in the same
manner as other city employees. (Ord. 98-04, 3-31-1998)
B. Duties Of Caretaker:
1. The caretaker shall be responsible, under the general supervision of the public works supervisor/director, for the overall maintenance, care and
management of the cemetery properties, and the enforcement of cemetery rules and regulations as provided by ordinances and resolutions of the
city. (Ord. 98-04, 3-31-1998; amd. 2011 Code)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 121/269
2. The caretaker shall supervise the opening and closing of all gravesites, and the placing of all monuments and markers on a cemetery lot as to
location, footing and proper base.
3. The caretaker shall have the further duty and is fully authorized to maintain order, to supervise all work, workmen, visitors, drivers and operators of
all vehicles, and to expel from the grounds of the cemeteries any person violating the established cemetery rules and regulations or provisions of this
chapter, or whose conduct is offensive toward the cemeteries, other persons or the places of interment. (Ord. 98-04, 3-31-1998)
8-4-4: FEES AND CHARGES SET BY CITY COUNCIL:
The city council may set, by resolution, from time to time, such fees and charges as they deem necessary and reasonable for the purchase of cemetery
spaces, opening and closing of gravesites, disinterments and other provided services. (Ord. 98-04, 3-31-1998)
8-4-5: RULES AND REGULATIONS SET BY CITY COUNCIL:
A. City Council Authority:
1. The city council may, by resolution, from time to time, establish, revise and amend such rules and regulations for the use, care, control,
management, restriction and protection of all or any part of the cemeteries as they deem to be required and necessary.
2. As special cases may arise in which the literal enforcement of a rule or regulation may impose an unnecessary hardship, the city reserves the right,
without notice, to make exceptions, suspensions or modifications to any established rule or regulation when, in the sole judgment of the city, the
same would appear to be advisable. Such temporary exception, suspension or modification shall in no way be construed as affecting the general
application of any established rule or regulation.
3. Until otherwise decreed by the city council, rules and regulations in effect, and not in conflict with this chapter on the effective date hereof, with
respect to the cemeteries shall continue to be in full force and effect. (Ord. 98-04, 3-31-1998)
B. Posting Of Written And Printed Rules: The cemetery rules and regulations promulgated by the city council shall be written and plainly printed and
maintained subject to inspection in the office of the city clerk and at any office maintained within the cemetery. (Ord. 98-04, 3-31-1998; amd. Ord. 2013-
3, 2-12-2013)
8-4-6: CEMETERY LOTS AND SPACES:
A. Use Of Lots: No cemetery lot or space shall be used for any other purpose than the interment of bodies of persons. (Ord. 98-04, 3-31-1998)
B. Deeds To Cemetery Lots And Spaces: Deeds to lots and spaces in the cemeteries shall be issued to the purchasers of said lots or spaces by the city in
such form as shall be deemed adequate. Cemetery deeds shall be signed by the mayor, and attested to by the city clerk, and the same shall carry an
acknowledgment sufficient to authorize the said deeds to be recorded in the office of the county clerk of Osage County, Oklahoma, or in such other
counties as cemetery lots or spaces may therein be located. (Ord. 98-04, 3-31-1998; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
C. Lot Purchase Limitation: No individual person, family or entity of any nature may purchase more than sixteen (16) cemetery spaces (2 lots) without prior
approval of the city council. This limitation shall not apply to any area of the cemeteries designed and designated as family estate areas. (Ord. 98-04,
3-31-1998)
D. Limitation Of Deed Transfer: No owner of any lot or space in the cemeteries shall sell or transfer the same or any interest therein except as permitted by
the laws of the state of Oklahoma and city of Skiatook resolutions, ordinances or established cemetery rules and regulations. No such transfer shall be
effective unless and until the same is approved by the city clerk and such approval endorsed upon the conveyance in writing. This limitation is
necessary in order that the city shall have a complete record of ownership and persons entitled to use such cemetery lot or space. (Ord. 98-04, 3-31-
1998; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
8-4-7: PERPETUAL CARE FUND:
Twenty five percent (25%) of all monies received from the sale of lots, interments, disinterments and reinterments shall be segregated and set aside as a
permanent fund to be known as the "cemetery perpetual care fund". The cemetery perpetual care fund principal shall be expended for purchasing lands for
cemeteries and for making capital improvements as defined at 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 17-110, if necessary. The balance of the fund shall be
invested in the manner provided by law for investment of municipal funds. Interest from the investments may be used for the same purposes as the
principal or in improving, caring for, and embellishing the lots, walks, drives, parks, and other necessary improvements on such cemeteries. When made,
donations, bequests and other like deposits shall be accepted only for purposes of maintenance, upkeep, improvement, beautification, and embellishment
of the cemetery in general. Such donations, bequests, etc., shall be deposited in and become part of the cemetery perpetual care fund principal. All
monies paid into the cemetery perpetual care fund shall be managed and controlled by the city in the same manner as other special funds, and shall be
audited annually along with all other city funds. (Ord. 98-04, 3-31-1998)
8-4-8: INTERMENTS AND DISINTERMENTS:
A. Consent To Interment: No interment shall be permitted in any space without a written order of interment consent form being completed and signed by
the owner, or one of them, showing the exact location of the interment to be made and not then unless a proper burial certificate or permit is furnished.
At least twenty four (24) hours' previous notice shall be required before any interment is made. In extreme emergencies, adjustments in time may be
made.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 122/269
B. One Interment To Space: Only one interment shall be permitted in any adult interment space, except in the case of a mother and infant in one opening,
or two (2) infants.
C. Disinterment By City: No disinterment shall be made except by employees of the city under the direct supervision of the caretaker, with the consent of
the owner, based upon an official permit therefor, or by order of a court of competent jurisdiction. Disinterments and reinterments shall be made in
accordance with the laws of the state of Oklahoma. Under no circumstance shall any disinterment or reinterment be made unless a state of Oklahoma
licensed funeral director is present.
D. Space Paid For Before Interment: No interment shall be made in any space in a lot sold to individual ownership unless the same is paid for together
with charges for opening and closing the place of interment. Should the interment be made upon promise of immediate payment, or upon the faith of an
insufficient or forged check, draft or other bill of exchange, so that such service is obtained by fraud, then the city shall have the right to remove such
body to a single interment space apart from the lot where such interment was made. Should such aforementioned circumstance occur, the owner of
such lot shall be responsible for any and all additional charges and expenses incurred by the city in removal and reinterment of such body.
E. Charges Paid In Advance: All charges for the purchase price of actual spaces for interment and all interment and removal fees or for foundation
charges or other work or services for which charges are made shall be paid in advance and before the services are performed. (Ord. 98-04, 3-31-1998)
8-4-9: OPENING CASKET OR CONTAINER; COURT ORDER:
No casket or container of a deceased human body shall be opened by any person within the confines of city cemeteries without an order of a court of
competent jurisdiction, except when the last services are being held at graveside and then only with the consent of the person having charge and authority
to do so. (Ord. 98-04, 3-31-1998)
8-4-10: STRUCTURES, ENCLOSURES AND TREES:
A. Structures Contrary To Rules And Regulations Prohibited: Lot owners shall make no improvements or erect any monument, marker or structure contrary
to this chapter or to the cemetery rules and regulations established by the city council. Should any monument, effigy, structure or other object
whatsoever, or any inscription be placed in or upon any space, lot, monument or marker which in the opinion of the city is deemed to be offensive or
injurious to the appearance of the surrounding spaces, lots or grounds, the city shall have the right and privilege to enter upon such lot and remove
such offensive object or inscription.
B. Prior Approval Of Monument Or Marker: All owners or anyone duly authorized to act for or in behalf of an owner shall, before ordering any marker,
monument, memorial or structure, secure from the city written approval of the proposed design, size and lettering style.
C. Enclosures Or Fences Prohibited: No enclosure of any kind, such as fence, coping, curbing, hedge or ditch, shall be permitted around any space, lot or
place of interment.
D. Planting Trees Or Shrubs: No trees, shrubbery or plants of any type shall be set, planted, pruned or removed from any space, lot, place or location
within the cemeteries without the written approval of the city. The city shall have the authority to, at any time, prune, remove or transplant any tree,
shrub, plant or flower in the cemetery when such is deemed by the city to be in the best interest of maintaining the beautification of the cemeteries.
(Ord. 98-04, 3-31-1998)
8-4-11: NONLIABILITY OF CITY:
So long as the city and its officers and agents act in good faith and upon reasonable grounds in making interments, removals or disinterments, it shall not
be liable in damages on account of forgeries or frauds of others or mistakes honestly made, but the city shall use all reasonable means at its command
and shall be permitted to correct any such mistakes so that any person affected thereby may not suffer loss by reason thereof. The city and its officers and
agents shall not be liable for the safekeeping, theft or loss by any cause of any flowers, blankets, design or other object authorized to be placed on any lot
or grave and the foregoing will be placed on such lot or grave at the sole risk and responsibility of the lot or space owner. (Ord. 98-04, 3-31-1998)
Chapter 5
MUNICIPAL AIRPORT
8-5-1: PROCEDURES AND MINIMUM STANDARDS ADOPTED:
The procedures and minimum standards set forth in this chapter are hereby promulgated and adopted for the use of any land or facility at the Skiatook
Municipal Airport. (1991 Code § 1-441)
8-5-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
AERONAUTICAL ACTIVITY: Any activity which involves, makes possible, or is required for the operation of aircraft or which contributes to, or is required
for, the safety of such operations and shall include, but not by way of limitation, all activities commonly conducted on airports, such as charter operations,
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 123/269
pilot training, aircraft rental, land sightseeing, aerial photography, crop dusting, aerial advertising and surveying, air carrier operations, aircraft sales and
services, sale of aviation, petroleum products, whether or not conducted in conjunction with other included activities, repair and maintenance of aircraft,
sale of aircraft parts, sale and maintenance of aircraft accessories, radio communication and navigation equipment and any other activity which, because
of its direct relationship to the operation of aircraft, can appropriately be regarded as an aeronautical activity.
AIRPORT: The Skiatook Municipal Airport located on municipal lands and operated by the city of Skiatook.
AIRPORT COMMISSION OR COMMISSION1: The Skiatook airport commission as created by ordinance 434 as it may be hereafter amended.
CITY COUNCIL: The city council of the city of Skiatook.
MASTER PLAN: The scaled dimensional layout of the entire airport property to be prepared hereafter, indicating current and proposed usage for each
identifiable segment as approved by the city council and as amended from time to time.
MINIMUM STANDARDS: The qualifications established herein, as amended from time to time by the city council upon recommendation of the airport
commission, setting forth the minimum requirements to be met as a condition for the right to conduct an aeronautical activity on the airport, and shall also
include all requirements and regulations of the federal aeronautic administration (FAA) which apply to the airport.
PERSON: Any person, firm, general or limited partnership, corporation, trust or association making application for, leasing or using any land or facility at
the airport. (1991 Code § 1-442)
8-5-3: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The standards set forth in this chapter shall be equally applicable to all operators, persons, firms, partnerships or corporations, their assigns or sublessee
with no discrimination on gender, color, race, national origin, religion, age, familial status, or handicap. (1991 Code § 1-450; amd. 2011 Code)
8-5-4: RESTRICTIONS ON LAND AND FACILITY USE:
A. No person shall be permitted to use any airport land for any purpose or conduct any aeronautical activity for commercial purposes or the solicitation of
business in connection therewith unless such activity is conducted in accordance with the standards herein established and as hereinafter amended
from time to time upon the recommendation of the airport commission with the approval of the city council.
B. Use of airport land or facilities contrary to the standards and requirements herein set forth is hereby declared to be a misdemeanor. (1991 Code § 1-
443)
8-5-5: APPLICATION FOR USE OF LAND:
A. Filing Of Application; Contents: Any person desiring to acquire the use of land or establish or use any facility on the airport for an aeronautical activity
shall be furnished a copy of these standards and procedures, as amended from time to time, and shall thereupon make application in writing, filed with
the city clerk, setting forth in detail the following: (1991 Code § 1-444; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
1. The name and address of the applicant.
2. The proposed land use, facility and/or activity sought.
3. The names and the qualifications of the personnel to be involved in conducting such activity.
4. The financial responsibility and ability of the applicant to carry out the activity sought.
5. The tools, equipment, services and inventory, if any, proposed to be furnished in connection with such activity.
6. The requested or proposed date for commencement of the activity and the time of conducting the same.
7. The estimated cost of any structure or facility to be furnished, the proposed specifications for same, and the means or method of financing such
construction or acquisition of facilities. (1991 Code § 1-444)
B. Notice And Hearing:
1. Upon the filing of such an application with the clerk, it shall be immediately referred to the airport commission and considered at the next scheduled
meeting of such commission; and if no meeting is scheduled within thirty (30) days from the filing of such application, a meeting shall be called for
consideration of the same and notice thereof shall be given to the applicant. (1991 Code § 1-445; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
2. If such application involves conduct of an aeronautical activity for commercial purposes, all other persons then conducting commercial aeronautical
activities on the airport shall also be notified of the filing of such application and the time and place of the airport commission meeting to consider the
same.
3. Upon the consideration of the application, the airport commission shall determine whether or not the applicant meets the standards and qualifications
as herein set out, and whether, under the standards set forth in section 8-5-8 of this chapter, such application should be granted in whole or in part,
and if so, upon what terms and conditions, and shall make a written report and recommendation to the city council concerning the same. (1991 Code
§ 1-445)
C. Action On Application By City Council: Upon receipt of written recommendation of the airport commission, the city council shall include said matter upon
the agenda of the next regular meeting of the city council and, at such meeting or at a subsequent meeting to which it may be passed, shall approve,
modify or reject such recommendations and applications. (1991 Code § 1-446)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 124/269
8-5-6: LEASE OR CONTRACT:
Upon the approval of any such application as submitted or modified, the city council shall cause to be prepared a suitable lease or contract agreement
setting forth the terms and conditions of the land and/or facility use, which lease or contract shall in every instance be conditioned upon the following:
A. Original and continued compliance with the standards required for each particular aeronautical activity approved, and shall refer to and incorporate
these standards by reference.
B. That any structure or facility to be constructed upon the airport shall be constructed in conformity with all pertinent regulations of the state and the city,
and shall be erected pursuant to a building permit duly issued and compliance with the requirements of current codes and regulations of the city and
commission; and that all structures will include aprons, taxiways and roads, constructed at the expense of the lessee, from lessee's structure to existing
taxiways, aprons and roads in accordance with specifications previously approved by the city. All construction shall proceed to completion with due
diligence.
C. Shall reserve the right in the city council to modify or add to the standards for operation of aeronautical activities at the airport; shall provide for
termination or cancellation of the lease or contract upon failure to comply after notice. (1991 Code § 1-447)
8-5-7: STANDARDS FOR SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:
In addition to meeting the requirements of section 8-5-6 of this chapter, every person conducting the following specific activities shall meet the additional
requirements as hereinafter set out:
A. Fuel And Oil Sales: Persons conducting aviation fuel and oil sales on the airport shall be required to provide:
1. Hard surface ramp space equivalent to existing taxiway and aprons accessible by taxiway with electric pumps and underground tank storage having
a capacity equal to the minimum tank truckload deliverable for each of those grades of aviation fuel commonly used by general aviation piston driven
aircraft, and, if and when in the judgment of the commission, public demand requires, shall also provide storage capacity approved by the
commission for standard jet fuel.
2. Shall provide properly trained line personnel on duty at least eight (8) hours of every calendar day, seven (7) days a week, and on call by readily
accessible telephone at other hours during the day or night.
3. Proper equipment for repairing and inflating aircraft tires, servicing oleo struts, changing engine oil, washing aircraft and aircraft windows and
windshields, for recharging or energizing discharged aircraft batteries and starters.
4. Shall provide conveniently located heated and air conditioned lounge or waiting rooms for passengers, and crews of itinerant aircraft, together with
sanitary restrooms and public telephones.
5. Shall provide adequate towing equipment and parking and tie down area to safely and efficiently move aircraft and store them in all reasonable
expected weather conditions.
6. In conducting refueling operations, every operation shall install and use adequate grounding facilities at fueling locations to eliminate the hazards of
static electricity and shall provide approved types of fire extinguishers or other equipment commensurate with the hazard involved in refueling and
servicing aircraft.
B. Aircraft Charter And Taxi Service: Local fixed base operators operating aircraft and taxi service shall provide:
1. Passenger lounge, restroom and telephone facilities as required of an operator for fuel and oil sales.
2. Adequate table, desk or counter for checking in passengers, handling ticketing or fare collection, handling of luggage.
3. Properly certificated suitable aircraft with properly certificated and qualified operating crew, one of which shall be located at the airport and ready for
departure during at least eight (8) hours of daylight operation daily and at other times, standby units and crews available upon call within one hour's
notice.
4. Passenger liability insurance of at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per passenger seat and property damage liability of at least fifty
thousand dollars ($50,000.00).
5. A current FAA air taxi permit.
Subsections B4 and B5 of this section shall also apply to all transient operators.
C. Aircraft Engine And Accessory Maintenance: All persons operating aircraft engine and accessory maintenance facilities shall provide:
1. Sufficient hangar space to house any aircraft upon which such service is being performed.
2. Suitable storage space for aircraft awaiting maintenance or delivery after repair and maintenance to be completed.
3. Adequate shop space to house the equipment and adequate equipment and machine tools, jacks, lifts and testing equipment to perform overhauls
as required for FAA certification and repair of parts not needing replacement on all single engine land and light multiengine land general aviation
aircraft.
4. At least one FAA certificated airframe and power plant mechanic available during eight (8) hours of the day, five (5) days per week.
5. Facilities for washing and cleaning aircraft.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 125/269
6. Storage capacity for aircraft undergoing repair and maintenance work; provided, however, that any aircraft or part thereof in a nonairworthy condition
be screened or removed from ground level public view.
7. If spray painting of the aircraft is to be performed, the operator shall provide separately partitionable space with adequate exhaust fans and fire
protection.
D. Aircraft Rental And Sales: Local fixed base operators conducting aircraft rental and sales activity shall provide:
1. Suitable office space for consummating sales and/or rentals and the keeping of the proper records in connection therewith.
2. Hangar storage space for at least one aircraft to be used for sales or rental.
3. For rental, at least one airworthy aircraft suitably maintained and certificated.
4. For new sales activity, a sales or distributorship franchise from a recognized aircraft manufacturer of new aircraft and at least one demonstrator
model of such aircraft.
5. Adequate facilities for servicing and repairing the aircraft or satisfactory arrangements with other operators on the airport for such service and repair.
6. There shall be available, at least during eight (8) hours of the working day, a properly certificated pilot capable of demonstrating new and/or used
aircraft for sale or for checking out rental aircraft and model sold.
7. The minimum stock of readily expendable spare (parts), or adequate arrangements for securing spare parts required for the type of new aircraft and
models sold.
8. Current up to date specifications and price lists for types and models of new aircraft sold.
9. Proper checklists and operating manuals on all aircraft rented and adequate parts catalog and service manual on new aircraft sold.
E. Flight Training: All persons conducting flight training activities shall provide:
1. Continuing ability to meet certification requirements of the FAA for the flight training proposed.
2. Public liability insurance in an amount not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for any one incident and property damage
insurance in an amount not less than seventy five thousand dollars ($75,000.00).
F. Crop Dusting And Spraying: Persons seeking to conduct crop dusting or spraying of agricultural chemicals shall be required to satisfy the airport
commission that:
1. Suitable arrangements have been provided for the safe storage and containment of noxious chemicals and materials and that all operations are in
compliance with all federal and state regulations governing the same. No poisonous or inflammable materials shall be kept or stored in close
proximity to other facility installations at the airport.
2. The operator shall have available properly certificated aircraft suitably equipped for the agricultural operation undertaken.
3. The operator shall make suitable arrangement for servicing the aircraft with adequate safeguards against spillage on runways and taxiways or
pollution or disbursal of chemicals by wind to other operational areas on the airport.
4. He has been issued a current FAA agricultural license under FAR 137.
5. He has been bonded in the state and carries chemical liability insurance.
G. Combination Activities: Any person conducting a combination of the specific activities listed hereunder shall not be required to duplicate the
requirements of the individual activities but where the requirement of one activity is sufficient to meet the requirement of a separate activity to be
conducted, the one activity shall be sufficient to meet both requirements. (1991 Code § 1-448)
8-5-8: STANDARDS FOR USE OF AIRPORT LAND AND FACILITIES:
In determining whether to grant an application and thereby permit a requested use of airport land or facilities, the commission and the city council shall
apply the following standards in addition to the requirements set forth above:
A. Whether there exists a public need for the service or facility proposed.
B. The likelihood of the proposed service or facility being a successful business enterprise.
C. The business acumen, financial resources, character, integrity, experience and past record of the applicant.
D. The effect of the proposed operation or facility on the city, the municipal airport, other airport operations and whether it is in the best interest of the city
and the airport that the application be approved or rejected. (1991 Code § 1-449)
8-5-9: AMENDMENT OF STANDARDS:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 126/269
The airport commission shall review the standards for conducting aeronautical activities at least annually and shall recommend to the city council such
revisions or amendments as shall be deemed necessary under the use circumstances surrounding the airport to properly protect the health, safety and
interest of the city and the public. Upon approval of any such amendments, the operators of aeronautical activities secured hereunder shall be required to
conform to such amended standards. (1991 Code § 1-451)
8-5-10: CERTAIN ACTIVITIES RESTRICTED; RULES AND REGULATIONS:
A. City Council Consent For Conducting Certain Activities: No person, firm or corporation shall engage in any activity at the Skiatook Municipal Airport
other than normal motorized aircraft operations without the consent of the city council given at a duly held public meeting.
B. Regulation Of Airport Use:
1. The city council may from time to time establish rules and regulations for the operation of and activities permitted at the Skiatook Municipal Airport,
including, but not limited to:
a. Defining permissible uses of the airport;
b. Defining prohibited uses of the airport;
c. Establishing restrictions, conditions and limitations upon use of the airport; and
d. Making any other rule or regulation governing operations at and use of the facility. (Ord. 93-09, 11-30-1993)
2. Copies of rules and regulations relating to the airport made by the city council shall be maintained by the city clerk and made available for inspection
by the public. (Ord. 93-09, 11-30-1993; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
C. Suspension Of Rules And Regulations For Public Event: Whenever airshows or other public events are conducted within the city which, in the opinion
of the city council, are beneficial for the city, the city council may suspend any rule or regulation previously made for the duration of such public event
(not to exceed, however, a period of 48 hours) during which time the rules and regulations previously made shall not apply. (Ord. 93-09, 11-30-1993)
Chapter 6
ATHLETIC FACILITIES
8-6-1: PURPOSE AND APPLICABILITY:
A. Purpose: The purpose of this chapter is to provide rules and regulations for the use of athletic facilities owned by the city of Skiatook ("city").
B. Applicability: This chapter shall apply to the use of all city owned athletic facilities, including, but not limited to, football fields, baseball and softball fields,
soccer fields, including soccer fields at public parks, wrestling facilities, and basketball gyms. (Ord. 2015-05, 4-28-2015)
8-6-2: ATHLETIC FACILITIES USE AGREEMENT REQUIRED:
A. Requirement Of Athletic Facilities Use Agreement: An athletic facilities use agreement shall be required when a "youth sports organization" (defined as
a youth sports league, team or club, including booster clubs and referred to in this chapter as "YSO", whether singular or plural) desires to utilize city
owned athletic facilities, including, but not limited to, athletic fields located at the Skiatook Sports Park located at 3020 W. 133rd St. North, John Zink
Park, the soccer fields located at 800 West Oak Street, and the Central Complex Gym, located at 710 South Osage.
B. Agreement Required: No YSO ("youth sports organization") may utilize or use for any purpose city owned athletic facilities unless an athletic facilities
use agreement is entered into and approved by the city council of the city of Skiatook.
C. Preference For Use: Preference for athletic facility use shall be given to YSO based within the greater Skiatook, Oklahoma, geographic area and in
which the participants primarily reside within the Skiatook, Oklahoma, geographic area. (Ord. 2015-05, 4-28-2015)
