8-6-3: REQUIRED TERMS:
A. Any athletic facilities use agreement entered into must include the following terms in substantially similar form:
1. The city shall retain all ownership rights and right of access to the athletic facility at any time.
2. Any athletic facilities use agreement must be for a defined term of not more than one year, but such agreement may be renewable for successive
periods of time.
3. The city shall reserve the right to use any or all portions of the athletic facility in times of natural disaster, emergency or other community wide higher
use need.
4. Cancellation for any reason upon thirty (30) days' written notice.
5. Reservation of the right of the city to utilize the athletic facilities at any time for municipal purposes.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 127/269
6. In the event that a conflict arises with any other YSO which has the right to utilize an athletic facility being the subject of the athletic facilities use
agreement, or any part thereof, regarding practice scheduling, game scheduling or tournament scheduling, and the parties cannot resolve the
dispute between themselves, the city manager, or his designee, shall decide as to the use of the athletic facilities area. The decision of the city
manager or his designee shall be final and nonappealable.
7. The use of the athletic facilities shall be nonexclusive and the city reserves the right to enter into similar agreements with other YSO.
8. All fixed alterations, additions and permanent improvements made during the term of the athletic facilities use agreement shall become the property
of the city and the YSO making such fixed alterations, additions and permanent improvements shall not be entitled to remove such fixed alterations,
additions and permanent improvements without the written consent of the city.
9. The YSO shall retain ownership of any nonpermanent structure installed at the athletic facility provided by the YSO, including, but not limited to,
temporary storage buildings, nonpermanent concession buildings, as well as any nonpermanent referee buildings. Any nonpermanent structures
provided by the YSO which remain on city or Skiatook public works authority property for more than thirty (30) days after the expiration or termination
of an athletic facilities use agreement shall become the property of the city, without further action on the part of the city.
10. The city shall provide access to the athletic facilities for sport and athletic uses only.
11. The city shall provide keys and/or lock combinations for necessary gates and doors to allow access to the athletic facilities which are the subject of
an athletic facilities use agreement. A YSO shall not duplicate any keys or disseminate any lock combinations without the consent of the city
manager. The YSO shall notify the city in writing who has been issued a key and/or who has been provided the combination to any locks.
12. Unless otherwise agreed, the city shall clear the site of unsafe debris that interferes with the intended use of the athletic facility. This shall include
ice storm, severe weather and flood related storm debris.
13. Unless otherwise agreed, the city shall provide basic trash service (typically weekly service).
14. The city shall maintain all fences, backstops and related grounds to ensure public safety.
15. The city shall provide adequate mowing services for all public, nonathletic field areas.
16. The city shall provide proper signage (as determined by city ordinances, codes and/or park rules and regulations) that is enforceable by police, fire,
code enforcement, city staff and the YSO.
17. The city shall have the right to conduct background checks on employees, volunteers or subcontractors of a YSO entering into an athletic facilities
use agreement, or to require that the YSO conduct such background checks, with the results being furnished to the city for the purposes of public
safety and protection of public property.
18. The YSO shall adhere to all city ordinances and/or park rules and regulations, as well as all state and federal laws and regulations.
19. The YSO shall be responsible for the conduct and behavior of their players, coaches and guests.
20. The YSO shall acknowledge and accept the risk of theft, vandalism or other criminal acts occurring within the property comprising the athletic
facility.
21. The YSO shall provide to the city by July 1 of each year, a public liability insurance policy with coverage of not less than one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) per occurrence. The insurance policy must list the city of Skiatook and the Skiatook public works authority as additional insured
parties, with a requirement of written notice to the city prior to any cancellation. In the event that the public liability insurance policy lapses or is
canceled, the city manager may terminate this agreement, effective upon written notice delivered to USER.
22. The YSO shall be responsible for any damages occurring to city or Skiatook public works authority property (buildings, irrigation components,
fences, signs, posts, sidewalks, parking lots, gates, landscaping, roadways, sports fields, gymnasiums, electrical, plumbing and mechanical systems)
that are a result of YSO volunteers, coaches, players, board members, or by the general public during YSO events. The YSO shall not be
responsible for damages or vandalism occurring while the YSO is not using the athletic facility. Evaluation of estimated time of damages or
vandalism acts to be set by the Skiatook police department.
23. The YSO shall place and keep trash confined to city supplied trash receptacles.
24. The YSO shall not make any alterations, modifications or improvements of any type without the prior consent of the city of Skiatook.
25. The YSO shall provide adequate mowing and groundskeeping services for all athletic fields and the areas adjacent thereto.
26. The YSO shall restrict motorized vehicles to designated parking areas.
27. The YSO shall not allow another person or organization to use the property covered by an athletic facilities use agreement, including, but not
limited to, third party tournament hosts (not the YSO) desiring to utilize a city athletic facility for a tournament, or use of the athletic facility for
practices by teams not from the Skiatook geographic area, unless written permission is granted by the city manager.
28. The YSO shall submit an accident/incident report form within twenty four (24) hours for any/all injuries, vandalism, theft, or domestic disputes and
make sure to include any documentation from police, fire, and/or emergency medical services.
29. The YSO shall work in good faith to resolve any scheduling or other conflicts.
30. The YSO shall take appropriate measures to ensure that its coaches and volunteers are not a danger to children participating in youth sports,
including obtaining background checks to determine the criminal and other history for each coach or volunteer at least once yearly. Any coach or
volunteer failing a background check shall not be allowed to serve in either capacity.
31. The YSO shall not discriminate on the basis of race, religion, creed, color, sex, or national origin.
32. The YSO shall indemnify the city against all expenses, liabilities, and claims of every kind, including reasonable attorney fees arising out of: a) the
failure by the YSO to perform any of the terms or conditions of this agreement, b) any injury or damage happening on or about the premises, c)
failure to comply with any law of any governmental authority, or d) any mechanics' lien or security interest filed against the premises' equipment,
materials, or alterations of buildings or improvements thereon. Further, during the times that the YSO is in control of the athletic facilities being
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 128/269
utilized, the city shall not be liable for any injury or damages to any property or to any person using the premises nor for damage to any property of
the YSO.
33. The city manager may terminate any athletic facilities use agreement due to a material breach of the agreement by the YSO which is the party to
such agreement, upon ten (10) days' written notice delivered to the YSO detailing such breach.
B. The city manager is authorized to include any other terms or conditions in an athletic facilities use agreement which the city manager shall deem
necessary and beneficial for the city, subject to approval of the agreement by the city council. (Ord. 2015-05, 4-28-2015)
Title 9
PUBLIC UTILITIES
Chapter 1
UTILITIES, GENERAL PROVISIONS
9-1-1: TRANSFER FEE AND RETURNED CHECK FEE:
A. Transfer Fee: A fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) shall be charged for transfer of utilities. This will be deemed to have occurred when the occupant of
one location switches either residence or commercial operations for which billing occurs. Said transfer will apply to all residential, commercial, and
industrial accounts.
B. Returned Check Fee:
1. If a check is presented for payment for any and all utilities or services and returned by the paying bank, a returned check fee of twenty dollars
($20.00) will be added to the account for which payment was intended.
2. If the check was to cover any other bill from the city, the fee will be applied with the corresponding bill.
C. Modification Of Fees: The transfer fee and returned check fee heretofore described may be modified as necessary by resolution of the city council.
(Ord. 2004-06, 7-27-2004)
Chapter 2
WATER SYSTEM REGULATIONS
9-2-1: AUTHORITY OF CITY COUNCIL:
The city council shall have authority to decide any question which may arise and which is not fully covered by any of the provisions contained in this
chapter, and its decision in such cases shall be final. (1991 Code § 18-24)
9-2-2: APPLICATION FOR INSTALLATION OF WATER SERVICE:
A. Filing Of Application: Any person desiring to have premises connected with the supply system of the city shall present at the utility office a written
application containing the name, a description of the lot, block, and addition, and the official house number of the premises on which the water is
desired.
B. Application Signed: Said application shall be signed by the owner of said premises, or by his duly authorized agent.
C. Payment Of Fees: Said applicant shall pay to the city and take receipt therefrom, the fees for installation of water service as provided by the city council.
(1991 Code § 18-1)
9-2-3: CONTRACT CONDITIONS; NONLIABILITY OF CITY:
The application provided for in section 9-2-2 of this chapter shall contain a contract on the part of the person making the same, to pay for the water applied
for at the rate and in the manner specified in such contract and ordinances and shall reserve to the city the right to charge and collect the rates and
enforce the penalties provided for in this chapter, to change the rates at any time without notice to the consumer, and to install a meter or meters to
register the water consumed, and shall specify that said contract is subject to all the provisions of this chapter and of any ordinance of the city relating to
the subject hereinafter passed, and shall provide that the city shall not be held responsible for any damage by water or other cause resulting from
defective plumbing or appliances on the premises supplied with water installed by the owner or occupants of said premises, and that the fact that the
agents of the city have inspected the plumbing and appliances shall not be pleaded as a basis for recovery in case of damage to premises from defective
plumbing or appliances installed by the owner or occupant of the premises, and shall provide that in case the supply of water shall be interrupted or fail by
reason of accident or other cause whatsoever, the city shall not be liable for damages for such interruption for any reasonable period of time, and the same
shall not be held to constitute a breach of contract on the part of the city or in any way relieve the consumer from performing the obligations of his contract.
(1991 Code § 18-2)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 129/269
9-2-4: TAPPING OF PREMISES; RATES:
A. Abutting Street Where Water Main Exists: Upon payment of fees for installation of water service and the execution of the contract provided for in section
9-2-3 of this chapter, the water superintendent shall cause the premises described in the application, if the same abuts upon a street upon which there
is a city water main, to be connected with the city water main by a service pipe extending at right angles, from the main toward the property line, to a
point not more than two feet (2') within the line of the street curb, where a curb cock, meter and box shall be placed, which connection shall thereafter
be maintained by and kept within the exclusive control of the city. (1991 Code § 18-4)
B. Abutting Street Where Water Main Does Not Exist: In case application is made for water service on premises not abutting upon a street upon which
there is a city water main, the city shall lay its connection from the main toward the premises for a distance not exceeding fifty feet (50'), for each
applicant to be serviced by such connection, and permit connection therewith by pipes laid at the expense and maintained by the owners of the service,
or may, in the discretion of the superintendent upon the payment of actual cost thereof, extend the service to the premises of the applicant along and
beneath any public street or avenue of the city, but not otherwise. (1991 Code § 18-6)
C. Rate Charges: A record shall be kept by the superintendent of the date when the water is turned on for such premises. Rates shall be charged from the
day the premises are connected with the city water main and the water turned on for such premises. (1991 Code § 18-5)
D. Number Of Taps Allowed; Special Permit: No premises shall be allowed to have more than one service connection unless a special permit therefor is
given by the superintendent. The granting of such permit shall be subject to such conditions as the superintendent may elect. Every separate premises
supplied by city water must have its own separate service connection with the city main, and the premises so supplied will not be allowed to supply
water to any other premises. (1991 Code § 18-7)
E. Connection Limited To One Premises:
1. Limitation: From and after the effective date hereof, it shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to obtain, use or procure the use of a
water service connection with the city for the furnishing of more than one premises from any one water service connection. It shall further be unlawful
for any person, firm or corporation who has a water service connection for a particular premises to extend water service to any other premises, and
upon a finding by the water superintendent that this clause has been violated, it shall be mandatory for said water superintendent to disconnect water
service from all such premises, the said service to be reconnected only upon order of the city council, in its sole discretion. (1991 Code § 18-25)
2. Premises Defined: The word "premises", as used in this subsection E, shall be defined to be a home or building under one roof, or the portion
thereof used by any one family or one business establishment; provided, that water may be furnished to outbuildings when the same shall be used
for the sole purposes of the major premises, as subsidiary or ancillary buildings, or for the watering of the grounds of the premises or of the animals
belonging to or under the control of the owner of the premises; and further provided, that nothing in this subsection shall prevent the continued
existence of water service connections presently existing and in conflict with this section; and provided also, that buildings used as multiple-family
residences may be considered as one premises if the same are under one roof and are owned by a single person, firm or corporation who is
responsible for the payment of the entire charges for water service. (1991 Code § 18-26)
F. New Water Taps: New water taps, when permitted to be made from the eight inch (8") water line, shall be made in such a manner so that each user is
metered by one meter and subject to rate charges imposed by the city to persons, organizations, or firms similarly situated; and under no
circumstances shall more than one user be metered through any water meter. "User", as used in this subsection, shall mean a residential single-family
dwelling unit, a continuous commercial or business unit under identical and common ownership, and in other applications has reference to a single
continuous structure occupied by one person, firm or organization. (1991 Code § 18-30)
G. Discretion Of City Council And Utility Board: One water tap of the necessary size, to be determined by the superintendent, shall be allowed to each
apartment or multiple housing development which is under one roof. The city council and utility board shall act on any cases which are considered to
be of an unusual nature. (1991 Code § 18-20)
9-2-5: LAYING OF PIPE; SPECIFICATIONS:
A. Requirements:
1. All persons connecting to a main water line shall use standard galvanized iron pipe, PVC plastic pipe, or cast iron pipe up to and including two
inches (2") in size, and all pipe shall be laid not less than two feet (2') below established grade.
2. The superintendent shall maintain private services from city mains in streets which are being graded, or regraded, and shall have such access on
private property as shall be necessary to maintain such pipes during the work; and shall, as soon as practicable upon the completion of such work,
relay said pipe in such street.
3. Except for such above cause, owners shall maintain their private pipes from the end of the city service to, and into, their property, or in case the
superintendent finds it necessary to maintain same, the owner shall relinquish all rights to said pipes.
4. When necessary, the superintendent may slope services in on property to conform to the slope occasioned by the grading of the street and charge
the expense thereof to the owner of such service.
5. Provided, that where there are no mains in the street adjacent to the property to be supplied, a permit for a temporary connection may be given by
the superintendent for the supply of more than one premises from the same service line, but such temporary permit shall be revocable at any time by
the superintendent, and he shall, in all such cases, place a separate shutoff for each of said premises. (1991 Code § 18-8)
B. Failure To Comply: Where any service now exists or may hereafter be installed contrary to the provisions of subsection A of this section, the premises
supplied by the main service shall be responsible for all delinquent and unpaid charges against any one or all of the separate owners or users, and the
superintendent may, at his discretion, cause the water to be shut off from such premises if the owners thereof fail or refuse to comply with the
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 130/269
provisions of subsection A of this section, after ten (10) days' notice in writing so to do, which notice may be served upon the occupant of such
premises. (1991 Code § 18-9)
9-2-6: FEES FOR INSTALLATION OF SERVICE:
A. Fee Set By City Council: In all cases, the fee for service connection inside and outside the city limits shall be established by the city council, and the
said fee shall be paid to the utility office before any work shall commence upon the installation of such water service.
B. Materials Used Property Of City: The right, title, interest, and ownership in and to any and all the materials, appliances and apparatus of every nature
installed by the city shall be and remain the property of the city.
C. Additional Fee For Additional Water Tap: In case more than one water tap is required for any service, an additional fee as established by the city council
shall be charged for each additional water tap.
D. Excavation Of Paved Street: For all services where it becomes necessary to open a paved street or put a pipe under a paved street, the cost of labor
and materials in laying such service and replacement of the paving shall be included in the fixed fee for installing the service.
E. Connections Extending Along Street With No Main: In such cases of connections extending along a street on which there is no main, the cost of
materials and labor necessary to extend the main to the property of such an applicant shall be estimated by the superintendent, and the estimated cost,
in addition to the fixed fee as provided, shall be paid to the superintendent by the person applying for such installation before the work of connecting
the main with the property is begun; provided, that whenever the estimated cost is not sufficient to cover the total expense thereof, the applicant shall
pay the deficiency; and provided further, that any excess payment shall be returned to the person applying for the installation. (1991 Code § 18-10)
9-2-7: SERVICE PIPES AND CONNECTIONS:
A. Number Of Connections Restricted:
1. Hereafter, no more than two (2) service connections shall be attached to, or connected with, a five-eighths inch (5/8") or three-fourths inch (3/4") tap
from any water main;
2. No more than four (4) service connections shall be attached to, or connected with, any one inch (1") tap from any water main;
3. No more than six (6) service connections shall be attached to, or connected with, any one and one-half inch (11/2") tap from any water main; and
4. No more than eight (8) service connections shall be attached to, or connected with, any two inch (2") tap from any water main in the city. (1991 Code
§ 18-3)
B. Location And Requirements: Before water will be turned on to any premises connected with the city mains, the service pipes upon such premises must
be made to conform to the following regulations:
1. The service pipes must be so located that the supply for each separate house or premises shall be controlled by a separate stop and waste cock of
the best standard make, approved by the superintendent, with the extension handle properly protected from the frost and so placed within the
premises that all service pipes and fixtures may be thoroughly drained during freezing weather.
2. The connection between the city pipes at the curb cock and the service pipes on the premises must be made with a union placed within eighteen
inches (18") of the curb cock. Every existing service or branch service not already equipped as required in this section must be so equipped at the
owner's expense within ten (10) days after notice in writing from the superintendent; and if not so equipped within such time, the superintendent may
cause the water to be shut off from the service without further notice. (1991 Code § 18-11)
C. Reconnecting: When new buildings are to be erected upon the site of old ones and it is desired to increase the size of or change the location of the
service connection, or where a service connection to any premises is abandoned or no longer used, the superintendent may cut out or remove such
connection, after which, a new service shall be placed only upon the owner making application and paying for a new tap in the regular manner. When
the service of any premises comes from a city main not located in front of said premises, the superintendent shall, when the main is laid in front of said
premises, after notifying the owner or tenants thereof, transfer the service connections to the new main without charge and at the same time cut out the
old service connection. (1991 Code § 18-12)
D. Laying Of Main: When a new main is laid in any street, owners of premises on said street who are being supplied with city water from a private main or
a connection to a private service shall make application for a tap and shall connect a separate service connection to the main in front of premises to be
paid for by the consumer as in other cases. (1991 Code § 18-13)
9-2-8: DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE:
Whenever the owner or occupant of any premises connected with the city water supply system desires to discontinue the use of water for any reason, he
shall notify the utility office that the water supply is to be shut off. It shall be unlawful for any owner of any premises connected with the city water supply
system to disconnect the water on said premises unless he shall first file in the office of utilities a written request that the service of water to said premises
be discontinued, and shall pay all arrearages on water charges for said premises. After water has been shut off from any premises upon the application of
the owner thereof, or for nonpayment of water charges or for any other cause, it shall be unlawful for any person to turn on the water again for such
premises, except when authorized so to do by the superintendent. (1991 Code § 18-14)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 131/269
9-2-9: WATER METERS:
A. Installation; Costs: All meters which are hereafter installed by the city on the service of any person, which are larger than three-fourths inch (3/4") in size,
shall be installed and the actual cost necessary to be incurred by the city in purchasing and installing said meter shall be charged against the owner of
said premises and shall be collected without discount at the next succeeding date upon which the charge for service to such consumer is due and
payable; and in the event of the neglect, failure, or refusal of such customer to pay to the city the expense and cost of such meter as aforesaid,
together with any and all service charges and penalties which may have accrued, such failure to pay may result in the discontinuance of said service.
(1991 Code § 18-15; amd. 2011 Code)
B. Multiple Meters; Costs: In the event more than one meter is installed upon the same premises, the city shall be entitled to charge for each additional
meter installed, the actual cost thereof, and the necessary expense incurred in installing each additional meter or meters.
C. Meters Property Of City: All meters, except as hereinbefore or otherwise provided, which are installed by the city at its expense, shall be and remain the
property of the city, and will not be removed unless the use of water on the premises is to be entirely discontinued, or the service connection
abandoned.
D. Replacement Of Lost Or Injured Meters: In all cases where meters are lost, injured, destroyed or broken by the carelessness or negligence of the
owners or occupants of said premises which are served through such meters, they shall be replaced or repaired by or under the direction of the
superintendent, and the cost charged against the owner or tenants of such premises. In case of nonpayment of the expense and cost of making such
repairs, upon the date next following for the payment of such charges, services to such premises shall be discontinued.
E. Failure To Register Properly: In the event the meter shall fail to register properly, the consumer shall be charged on an estimate made by the
superintendent on the basis of the average monthly consumption, during the last three (3) month period preceding immediately. (1991 Code § 18-15)
9-2-10: RIGHT TO SHUT OFF WATER:
The city reserves the right at any time without notice to shut off the water supply for repairs, extensions, nonpayment of rates, or any other reasons, and
the city shall not be responsible for any damage, such as bursting of boilers supplied by direct pressure, the breaking of pipes or fixtures, stoppage or
interruption of water supply, or any other damage resulting from shutting off the water. (1991 Code § 18-16)
9-2-11: WATER RATES AND CHARGES; PAYMENT:
A. Compliance With Requirements; Meter Deposit; Payment Of Charges:
1. It shall be unlawful for any person to make any connection with any service or branch pipe thereof, or make any repairs, additions or alterations of
any pipe, stopcock, stop and waste cock, water closet, or any other fixture connected with or designed to be connected with the city water system,
except in compliance with this chapter, and all such work must be inspected by the superintendent.
2. The city may require a cash deposit of not less than thirty five dollars ($35.00) as security for payment of charges for water services furnished by
meter rates; and in the event of the failure of any consumer of whom such requirements shall be made to make such deposit as security for the
payment of charges, services to him may be withheld or discontinued.
3. In the event the last day for the payment of any bills hereinabove provided shall fall upon Saturday, Sunday, or a legal holiday, then payment may be
made upon the business day succeeding such Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. (1991 Code § 18-17)
B. Water Rates Within Corporate Limits:
1. Residential Rates: Effective October 1, 2014, the rates per month for treated water supplied through meters to all residential places within the
corporate limits of the city shall be as follows (gallonage rates):

D. Annual Rate Adjustment: All rates for each category of use will increase by the lesser of the social security administration cost of living adjustment
(COLA) or one and five-tenths percent (1.5%) annually on each subsequent January 1 beginning January 1, 2009, and each January 1 thereafter until
repealed. (Ord. 2008-02, 1-29-2008; amd. 2011 Code)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 133/269
E. Minimum Multiple-Family Unit Rates: Where two (2) or more family residential units are supplied with water through a single meter, when so permitted
by this chapter or other policies of the city, the minimum charge per month per unit shall be made for the first one thousand (1,000) gallons or fraction
thereof multiplied by the number of units so connected, without regard as to whether or not any such unit or units be vacant or occupied, all hotels,
motels and mobile trailer parks excluded. (1991 Code § 18-21)
F. Due Date For Payment: The water rates as herein prescribed are based upon the consumption and use for each calendar month, and all such bills
mature and become due and payable on the first day of the following month. Said rates are considered delinquent after the tenth day of the month, and
a penalty of five percent (5%) of the amount of the water billed shall be assessed. (1991 Code § 18-22)
9-2-12: TRESPASS TO CITY PROPERTY:
A. Disturbing Meters, Other Property: It shall be unlawful for any person, unless duly authorized by the superintendent, to disturb, displace, interfere with,
cover up, damage or destroy any meter, meter box, water mains, water pipes, machinery, tools, buildings, fire hydrants, curb cocks, curb box, or any
other property belonging to, connected with, or under the control of the municipal water system of the city.
B. Obstructing Access To Fire Hydrants: It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct the access to any fire hydrants by placing around or upon the same,
any stone, brick, lumber, dirt or fencing or any other material.
C. Unlawful Connection: It shall be unlawful for any person to make any connection with any fixture or connect any pipe with any water main or water pipe
belonging to the municipal water system of the city without first obtaining permission so to do from the superintendent. (1991 Code § 18-23)
9-2-13: SURPLUS WATER FROM CITY OF TULSA:
All water purchased by the city from the city of Tulsa as its surplus water, when delivered to the city, becomes restricted and necessary water in the
possession and under the control of the city. All of such water is necessary as by resolution duly adopted by the city council members and required by the
city for its own use and the use of its own inhabitants, and is not subject to resale outside of the corporate limits of the city except by negotiated written
contract between the prospective purchaser on one side and the city on the other. (1991 Code § 18-28)
9-2-14: ABROGATION OF SERVICE:
All water sold and furnished to persons, firms and corporations without the corporate limits of the city, pursuant to taps granted under this chapter, shall be
sold and furnished upon written contracts expressly stating that the contract may be abrogated by the city at any time the city council or the trustees of the
Skiatook public works authority shall declare by resolution that the water being furnished under the contract is required by the city for the use of the
inhabitants and its own use; and such shall be expressly stated in every application to be prepared by the city clerk. (1991 Code § 18-33; amd. Ord. 2013-
3, 2-12-2013)
9-2-15: EXCEPTION; TWELVE INCH LINE:
Nothing contained in the previous sections of this chapter relates in any manner to the twelve inch (12") water line owned and operated by the city. Taps
from the twelve inch (12") water line are governed pursuant to the provisions of section 9-2-17 of this chapter. (1991 Code § 18-34; amd. 2011 Code)
9-2-16: SKIATOOK PUBLIC WORKS AUTHORITY; LEASED PROPERTY:
A. City Approval: The trust indenture dated September 18, 1974, creating the Skiatook public works authority, a copy of which is on file in the office of the
city clerk, wherein the city of Skiatook is declared to be the beneficiary of said trust, is hereby approved and the city accepts said trust as beneficiary
thereof. (1991 Code § 18-35; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
B. Leased Property: Pursuant to approval by a majority of the qualified electors of the city opting at a special election held therein on September 13, 1977,
made and entered into by and between the city of Skiatook, a municipal corporation (hereinafter called the "lessor") and the trustees of the Skiatook
public works authority, an Oklahoma public trust (hereinafter called the "lessee"), for and in consideration of the covenants, agreements, provisions and
conditions hereinafter contained on the part of the lessee to be kept, observed and performed, lessor has demised and leased, and hereby does
demise and lease, unto lessee, the following property (hereinafter collectively called the "leased property"):
1. All of the following described proprietary, revenue producing utility properties, systems and facilities of lessor:
a. All of the water production, storage, transportation and distribution system and facilities, including all tangible property, real and personal, and all
interest therein, appertaining or related thereto or used in connection therewith, and all rights of way, easements, licenses, and other rights and
privileges appertaining or related to such system and facilities or the use thereof, now belonging to the lessor or under its custody, management or
control; and
b. All of the property specifically described in the "Schedule Of Specific Property".
2. Any and all additions and/or improvements to the presently existing water system, properties and facilities mentioned in subsection B1 of this
section, and any and all tangible property, real or personal, and any and all interests therein, appertaining or related to such water system, properties
or facilities, or used in connection therewith, and any and all rights of way, easements, licenses, or other rights or privileges, appertaining or related
to such water system, properties or facilities or the use thereof, which may, hereafter, be acquired by lessor or which shall, hereafter, come under its
custody, management or control; it being the intent of this subsection that any of the foregoing, immediately upon acquisition of ownership, custody,
management or control thereof by lessor, shall become and be a part of the property demised and leased hereunder. (1991 Code § 18-36)

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 134/269
3. Any and all properties, systems and facilities purchased and/or constructed and/or installed by the lessee with the proceeds of indebtedness incurred
by the lessee and secured by its leasehold interest in and to any of the leased property, or by the revenues (or any part thereof) from any of the
leased property shall, immediately upon such purchase and/or construction and/or installation by lessee, become the property of the lessor and
become and be a part of the leased property demised and leased hereunder. (A copy of such lease is on file and in the office of the city clerk.) (1991
Code § 18-36; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
9-2-17: TWELVE INCH WATER LINE:
A. Fees For Taps: All applicants to whom water taps are granted must pay whatever fees and charges are established by the Skiatook public works
authority, and that authority is hereby granted the power to establish a rate of such fees and charges; and all applicants must further agree to pay
monthly water charges at the rate established by the Skiatook public works authority for persons residing outside the city. (1991 Code § 18-42)
B. Use And Assignability: Water taps granted pursuant to the policy set forth in this chapter shall be limited to one single-family residential dwelling unit,
and the water taps granted shall "run with the land" in that the owner of such tap shall always be the person owning the residential dwelling unit which
such tap services. Water taps granted hereby may not be assigned or sublet. Persons receiving water taps from such line may not sell or give water to
any other person, and the use of water from such taps is limited to the single-family residential dwelling to which service is initially established. In the
event that a tract of property for which a water tap is granted hereunder shall hereafter be subdivided or otherwise divided into ownership among one
or more persons, the water tap heretofore granted shall remain appurtenant to that tract upon which there is located the single-family residential
dwelling unit to which service is established hereby. (1991 Code § 18-43)
9-2-18: FINALITY OF DECISION:
All decisions made by the Skiatook public works authority concerning the grant or denial of any application for water taps shall be final and not subject to
review by any other board, agency or tribunal, and the Skiatook public works authority may reject an application for any reason whatsoever even though
the same be deemed arbitrary or capricious, it being the intent of the city to establish only guidelines for use in granting or denying applications for water
taps, and it not being the intention to impose any obligations upon the city or its public works authority to grant any application submitted. (1991 Code
§ 18-45)
9-2-19: WATER CONSERVATION:
A. Authority To Prohibit Use Of Water: The city council and the trustees of the Skiatook public works authority are hereby authorized during periods of
drought to prohibit the use of water for any purposes deemed by them not essential to the health and welfare of the city, such limitation of use to be by
resolution; and the city council and the trustees of the Skiatook public works authority are further authorized to limit any use of water to certain hours of
the day and to certain purposes. (1991 Code § 18-47)
B. Discontinuance Of Use Outside Corporate Limits: In the event that any period of drought continues so that it appears that the city will be unable to
supply adequate water for the inhabitants of the city, the city council and trustees of the Skiatook public works authority in such event are hereby
authorized to disconnect (as provided by the laws of the state of Oklahoma) from the city's water distribution and supply system, all persons residing
outside the corporate limits of the city. (1991 Code § 18-48)
9-2-20: LIMITED USE OF WATER DURING DROUGHT:
A. Drought Defined: "Drought", as that word is used within this section, has reference to those periods during which the city is furnishing to users of its
water system over a mean seventy two (72) hour period, more water than the city is receiving from its supplier so that the storage capabilities of the city
for water are in danger of becoming inadequate to hold a sufficient supply to meet the basic needs of the inhabitants of the city. (1991 Code § 18-50)
B. Prohibition Of Use: The city council is hereby authorized during periods of drought to prohibit the use of water for any purposes deemed by them not
essential to the health and welfare of the city, such limitation of use to be by resolution; and the city council is further authorized to limit any use of
water to certain hours of the day and to certain purposes. (1991 Code § 18-51)
C. Users Residing Outside Corporate Limits: In the event that any period of drought continues so that it appears that the city will be unable to supply
adequate water for the inhabitants of the city, the city council in such event is hereby authorized to disconnect (as provided by the laws of the state of
Oklahoma) from the city water distribution and supply system, all persons residing outside the corporate limits of the city. (1991 Code § 18-52)
D. Delegation Of Authority: The city council may, in its discretion, delegate the right to limit permissible uses of water as set forth in this section to the
mayor, the city clerk, or the manager of the city water system. (1991 Code § 18-53; amd. Ord. 2013-3, 2-12-2013)
E. Penalty: Whenever any limitation is made upon the permissible use of water from the city water system where the use of the same is limited to certain
hours, any person, firm or corporation who shall violate the provision of this section or any resolution limiting the use of water shall be deemed guilty of
a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than thirty five dollars ($35.00), inclusive
of costs. (1991 Code § 18-54)
9-2-21: LEASE-PURCHASE WATER LINE CONTRACTS:
A. Rates: All water furnished to customers of the city through water lines that are the subject of lease-purchase water line contracts which have not been
fully paid shall in all incidents be delivered to such customers according to the ordinances of the city in all respects, except that the rate which those
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 135/269
customers shall pay for the water shall be two (2) times the rates that would be required for such a customer should he be located within the corporate
limits of the city. (1991 Code § 18-57)
B. Provisions Cumulative: The provisions of this section shall be cumulative to all other ordinances, and shall not be deemed to have repealed any
ordinances by implication. (1991 Code § 18-58)
9-2-22: BULK WATER PLANT RESTRICTIONS:
A. Use Of Water: No person, firm or organization shall withdraw, use or remove from the bulk water plant, owned and operated by the city and located at
111 North A Street within the corporate limits of the city, water, when the same is to be used for any purpose other than human consumption and
household purposes. "Household purposes" as used herein means the use of water for purposes normally associated with the maintenance and
occupancy of a residential dwelling unit. The same does not include the use of water for agricultural, industrial, manufacturing, oil and gas operations,
and other nondomestic uses. This enumeration of prohibited uses of such water shall in no way be construed to expand the definition of household
purposes beyond uses normally associated with residences. (1991 Code § 18-59)
B. Manner Of Withdrawal: No person may withdraw water from the Skiatook bulk water plant by use of a container which has previously been used for any
purpose other than the transportation or storage of potable water; and no person may withdraw or take water from the Skiatook bulk water plant in any
container or vehicle of any nature, except in such a manner that the nozzle and hose installed at the bulk water plant remain free from contamination of
any kind or any contact with any soiled surface of any nature. (1991 Code § 18-60)
C. Violation: Any person, firm or organization violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be guilty of a misdemeanor. (1991 Code
§ 18-61)
9-2-23: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
If any person, firm or corporation shall violate the provisions of this chapter, the same shall be deemed to constitute the offense of larceny of water from
the city and the Skiatook public works authority, which offense shall be deemed committed at place where payment for such water should be made, upon
conviction, any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and suffer a punishment not less than
the sum of thirty five dollars ($35.00), inclusive of costs. (1991 Code § 18-46)
Chapter 3
ELECTRIC SERVICE REGULATIONS
9-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms, as referred to in this chapter shall be construed to mean and include:
CITY: The municipal electric service of the city of Skiatook, Oklahoma.
CONSUMER: Any person, firm, corporation, or establishment connected to or using, or applying to be connected to or using the facilities of the municipal
electric service of the city of Skiatook, Oklahoma. (1991 Code § 18-100)
9-3-2: SERVICE PROVIDED:
The city shall provide electric service to all consumers presently receiving service from its electric system and, in addition, if electric service is available,
shall serve all new consumers within the city limits and certain areas outside the city limits; and, where such service requires the use of streets, avenues,
alleys, etc., the city shall construct the distributing lines. (Ord. 2015-01, 1-27-2015)
9-3-3: SECURITY DEPOSIT REQUIRED:
A. Deposit Required; Amount: The city shall require a security deposit at the installation of service from all consumers and shall give a receipt therefor. The
amount of the security deposit required will be established by resolution of the city council.
B. Procedure Upon Termination Of Service:
1. At the termination of service, the city shall refund the deposit upon full payment of all bills for service due to the city and the surrender of the deposit
receipt.
2. Any such deposit may be applied by the city to the payment of any or all bills due the city at the time of termination of service to the consumer, either
for electric or water service, or may be applied on any other outstanding bill due the city, and may be so applied with or without permission or
consent of the consumer. (Ord. 2000-06, 3-14-2000)
9-3-4: READING OF METERS AND PAYMENT OF BILLS:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 136/269
A. Meter Reading And Billing Dates: Meters will be read and bills mailed to consumers on or before the first day of each month for books 11 through 20,
inclusive, and on or before the fifteenth day of each month for books 1 through 10, inclusive.
B. Due Date: All bills for service shall be due upon presentation of the bill and shall be payable within twenty (20) days following mailing of the bill.
C. Meter Improperly Recording; Average Determined: In case a meter does not record or is incorrectly recording or is not read, the bill for that period will
be based upon an average of the preceding twelve (12) months. (Ord. 2000-06, 3-14-2000)
D. Service Disconnection For Nonpayment; Additional Charges: If any bill for service is not paid within twenty (20) days after the mailing of such bill, the
service may be disconnected without further notice. Upon the dispatch of personnel for disconnection of service, a charge of twenty five dollars
($25.00) shall be assessed. There shall be no additional charge if service is reestablished during normal municipal business hours. An additional
charge of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be assessed for reestablishing service at all other times. The assessment for reestablishment of service shall be
added to the consumer's bill. These fees may be changed as deemed necessary by resolution of the city council. (Ord. 2004-06, 7-27-2004; amd. 2011
Code)
E. Service Interruption For Repairs; Nonliability Of City: The city shall have the right at any time to discontinue service or partial service from its lines for
the purpose of making repairs, extensions, replacements or inspections, and for such other reasons as may become necessary. The city, however,
shall arrange such interruptions so that the smallest possible number of consumers will be affected. The city shall not be liable or responsible for failure
to supply electric service or for interruptions of the supply, and the city shall not be responsible or liable for damages resulting to a consumer or to a
third person, company or corporation from the above causes or from the use of electricity or the presence of the city's equipment or apparatus upon a
consumer's premises. (Ord. 2000-06, 3-14-2000)
9-3-5: TEMPORARY SERVICE:
A. Period Of Time: Any electric service for less than twelve (12) months shall be considered temporary service.
B. Consumer Cost: There will be a nonrefundable fifty dollar ($50.00) connection fee for all temporary services. Temporary service connection fees may be
waived by the city manager, in his discretion, for competitive reasons related to economic development and to gain a new customer when negotiating
with a customer or customers that might otherwise choose another utility provider for electric service, where another provider can actually serve the
customer at the location at issue. (Ord. 2015-01, 1-27-2015)
9-3-6: WIRING REGULATIONS:
The following regulations are hereby adopted and prescribed as standards for the wiring of consumers' installations in the city:
A. Compliance With National Electrical Code: All new wiring must be done in accordance with the national electrical code, and such further specifications
as may be set up from time to time by the city.
B. Consumer Requirements: The consumer shall be required to furnish, install and maintain at all times in good condition all interior wiring, apparatus and
equipment, including all fixtures, appliances, and everything pertaining to the use of electric service on their premises. When wiring is to be done before
service wires of the city are extended to the consumer's premises, the city shall be notified and it shall specify the point of service for the consumer.
(1991 Code § 18-103)
9-3-7: SERVICE RESTRICTIONS:
The city may refuse to connect or supply motors or other apparatus of such type or of such installation as may impose low voltage or an insufficient power
factor, or such as may otherwise impair service to other consumers. (1991 Code § 18-106)
9-3-8: ELECTRIC METERS AND EQUIPMENT; INSPECTIONS:
A. Meter Requirements And Restrictions:
1. The city shall supply electricity through meters furnished and owned by it, and delivery of electric current is considered completed at the load
terminals of the meters. No city employee shall be permitted to do any work beyond the load terminals of said metering equipment.
2. The register of the meter shall be prima facie evidence of the amount of electricity used by the consumer, and he shall be held responsible and shall
pay for said electricity in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
3. In case of interference with or unnecessary injury to metering equipment or other property belonging to the city, the city may remove same and
refuse further service until such damage is paid.
4. If the city finds, at any time, that taps have been made ahead of the metering equipment, or tampering with the meter, it shall estimate as nearly as
possible the amount of electric service illegally used, and bill the same to the consumer.
B. Inspection Authorized; Correction Of Defects: The city shall, at all times, have the right to inspect any and all wiring, equipment, installations and
appliances upon the premises for a consumer; and should such inspection disclose dangerous or defective conditions of service or conditions likely to
interfere with proper service to and use of electric facilities to and by other consumers, the city shall have the right to require correction or removal of
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 137/269
such defective wiring, installation, equipment and appliances by the consumer upon reasonable notice; and upon his failure or refusal to do so, shall
discontinue service to such consumer until such defective condition shall be corrected. (1991 Code § 18-107)
9-3-9: OVERHEAD AND UNDERGROUND SERVICES:
A. Overhead Primary And Secondary Facilities: All electrical services provided by the city shall be on the basis of overhead primary and secondary
facilities with secondary service being brought to the customer's service entrance head. The customer shall provide the attachment member with the
necessary strength to support the overhead service. If the customer's point of attachment fails due to rot, decay or any other cause, the city shall have
the right to disconnect service from the structure until repairs are made by the customer. The customer shall obtain the meter base from the city, at no
cost to the customer, and shall furnish and install all other materials required for service except for the service wire and meter which will be furnished
and installed by the city.
B. Secondary Lengths: The maximum secondary length shall be two hundred feet (200'). Secondary lengths greater than two hundred feet (200') must first
be approved by the city manager, and the customer shall pay all costs relating to the additional secondary length requirement.
C. Underground Services: Underground single phase services to residential customers shall be furnished by the city in lieu of overhead service if so
requested by the customer and approved by the electric department supervisor. Lengths of underground. Secondary service shall be limited to two
hundred feet (200'). Underground secondary lengths greater than two hundred feet (200') must first be approved by the city, and the customer shall pay
all costs relating to the additional requirement. The customer shall install the meter base on the structure to which electric service is to be furnished and
shall furnish and install pipe or conduit below final grade as directed by electric department personnel (typically 21/2 inch electric PVC 6 inches below
final grade, or as directed by the electric department supervisor). The city shall be responsible for trenching and backfilling all service lines to the
metering point at a minimum depth of two feet (2').
D. Costs Paid By Customer: The customer shall pay all costs incurred for all primary electrical service extensions in excess of two hundred feet (200'), for
service to a single location, unless the extension of primary electrical infrastructure, in the opinion of the city manager, shall be beneficial and
necessary for future expansion of electrical service beyond the location served. The customer shall be required to pay all costs incurred in secondary
electrical service extensions in excess of two hundred feet (200') to service a single location. In case of such extension of electrical infrastructure,
whether primary or secondary, the customer shall be responsible for clearing any obstructions prior to electric installation and for obtaining necessary
utility easements and rights of way in a form acceptable to the city.
E. Transformers: 3-phase pad mounted transformers will be furnished for new commercial and industrial customers if 3-phase underground service can be
made available at a cost comparable to the cost of installation of an overhead transformer. When pad mounted transformers are not feasible, in the
discretion of the city manager, the city shall have the right to build overhead transformer banks to supply the customer's service. The customer shall be
responsible for building the transformer pad to the city's specifications.
F. Residential Subdivisions: The city may extend its electrical infrastructure to service residential subdivisions, including the provision of primary facilities
and transformers and other necessary equipment, at its cost, if multiple customers shall be obtained from such extension of electrical infrastructure or if
such extension of electrical infrastructure shall be beneficial and necessary to the city for future expansion of electrical service. The city will require the
developer or owner to excavate, trench and backfill the primary service lines of the subdivision; however, the city manager, in his discretion, may direct
the city to trench and backfill when necessary for competitive reasons, for economic development purposes and to gain additional customers when
negotiating with a developer or owner that might otherwise choose another utility provider for electric service, where another electric utility provider can
actually serve the customer at the subdivision location. The final plat must be approved and filed of record with the county clerk of the county in which
the subdivision is located prior to the installation of any electrical service lines. In addition, all excavation and "dirt work" must be complete and at final
grade prior to the installation of any electrical service lines.
G. Residential Voltage: The city shall provide 120/240 volt single phase service for all new residential customers.
H. Commercial/Industrial Voltage: The city shall provide the following voltages for all new commercial/industrial customers:
Single phase, 120/240;
3-phase, 120/208 is the preferred and recommended voltage. However, the following listed voltages can be made available to 3-phase customers
when requested by the customer and approved by the city manager:
120/240, 240/480 or 277/480. (Ord. 2015-01, 1-27-2015)
9-3-10: METER INSTALLATION CHARGES:
A. Determination Of Fee: The fees for installation of electric meters of the following size shall be determined by the city council:
100 ampere overhead - 100 ampere underground
200 ampere overhead - 200 ampere underground
B. Payment Of Fee: The fees shall be paid by the property owner or person requesting the installation of such meter. The fees include the cost of work and
materials furnished in the installation of such meter. (1991 Code § 18-109)
9-3-11: SAFE ACCESS AND CLEARANCE, FINAL PLAT REQUIRED, EXCAVATION, EASEMENT:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 138/269
A. Safe Access And Clearance: The city shall at all times have safe and clear access to all electrical equipment (meters, pedestals, transformers, poles
and other equipment) of city, and shall have the right to remove any shrubs, bushes, trees, fences or any other obstructions that impede access to its
electrical equipment, or that may pose a hazard to the employees of city or the public. The city will not be responsible for removing, repairing, or
replacing any obstruction(s) removed or damaged during outages or regular work operations.
B. Final Plat Required: In the case of platted developments, whether commercial or residential, the final plat must be approved and filed of record with the
county clerk of the county in which the development is located prior to the installation of any electrical service lines.
C. Final Grade: Upon the installation of any electrical service lines whether primary or secondary, installed by city, the developer or builder shall ensure all
buried electric lines maintain their original installation depth of at least two feet (2') once final grade is complete.
D. Easement: When the city provides electrical service, whether overhead or underground, there shall be an implied easement which exists in favor of the
city, ten feet (10') on either side of the centerline of the secondary electrical service line from the primary service line/transformer to the metering
location. This easement shall be solely for the provision, installation, maintenance, reworking, relocating, upgrading, replacing and removing the
secondary electrical service, as well as the right of access to the easement location for the purposes of the easement. (Ord. 2015-01, 1-27-2015)

to changes in the wholesale power cost from Grand River dam authority and southwestern power administration.
All demand and energy rates set forth in each rate schedule shall be increased by a factor of 1.2 times the increase or decrease in demand and energy
costs made by Grand River dam authority and southwestern power administration to the city and as approved by the city council. (Ord. 2000-06, 3-14-
2000)

used for billing purposes shall be obtained from the measured kilowatt hours and the measured reactive kilowatt-ampere hours taken during the
month. The meter for measurement of reactive kilowatt-ampere hours will be ratcheted to prevent reverse registration. If the average power factor
during the month is less than ninety percent (90%) lagging, the total bill for the month shall be increased one percent (1%) for each one percent (1%)
or major fraction thereof by which the average power factor during the month is less than ninety percent (90%) lagging. (Ord. 2000-06, 3-14-2000)

(80%) of the load of maximum phase, the customer shall correct such phase unbalance to meet the above limitation. Should the customer fail to
correct such phase unbalance, the demand, as determined, shall be increased in due proportion to such phase unbalance, or such single-phase
service shall be rendered separately and billed under the appropriate rate coercing such service.
f. All polyphase motors of twenty five (25) hp and larger shall be controlled by reduced voltage starters. Reduced voltage starters shall be of the auto
transformer, resistor or part winding type. Requests for exceptions to this requirement are to be submitted in writing to the city electric department.

9-3A-2: POWER COST ADJUSTMENT CLAUSE:
A. Adjustment Clause: All foregoing electric rate schedules set forth in section 9-3A-1 of this article are based on a base power cost adjustment fee of
$0.023/kWh, which fluctuates monthly based on the fuel cost of generating power by the wholesale electric provider to the city/Skiatook public works
authority. In the event that the power cost adjustment surcharge from a wholesale electric provider exceeds one percent (1%) of the base power cost
adjustment fee in any one month, or exceeds one percent (1%) of the base power cost adjustment fee in any three (3) month period, the electric rate
schedules will be increased by the amount of the increase in the power cost adjustment fee, per kWh, over and above the base power cost adjustment
fee. The electric rate schedules shall be amended effective the billing cycle following the increase in the power cost adjustment surcharge as set forth
in this section without further action by the city council. (Ord. 2016-5, 4-26-2016)
9-3A-2-1: ELECTRIC RATE ADJUSTMENT:
A. Automatic Increase: In the event that a wholesale electric supplier to the city of Skiatook/Skiatook public works authority increases the base wholesale
power rate, the electric rate schedules set forth in section 9-3A-1 of this article shall be increased automatically in the same percentage as the rate
increase by the wholesale electric supplier.
B. Implementation Of Automatic Rate Increase: Any automatic electric rate adjustment authorized by this section shall be implemented in a six (6) month
time period, in increments of one-sixth (1/6) of the total rate increase being effective and implemented each month for six (6) months, thereby
increasing the electric rate schedules accordingly. Such electric rate adjustment implementation shall begin not sooner than ninety (90) days prior to
the effective date of the wholesale power rate increase.
C. Right Of City Council: This section shall not be deemed to impair the right of the city council to establish electric service rates and charges by
ordinance.
D. Notification Of City Council: Upon receiving notice of a wholesale electric rate increase from a wholesale electric supplier, staff of the city of Skiatook
shall notify the city council of the electric rate increase upon receipt of such notice. (Ord. 2016-5, 4-26-2016)

(Ord. 2001-04, 6-26-2001)
9-3A-4: SPECIAL SERVICE:
A. Availability: This service may be available to customers located on or near lines of the city and provides for service for special applications. The rate will
be either small commercial or large commercial as determined by the electric superintendent.
B. Installation Costs: The installation costs shall be calculated on the total labor overhead and material cost including all additional lines, transformers and
miscellaneous equipment required.
C. Overhead Service: Service shall be of the overhead type. Service is for the sole use of the customer, and shall not be resold or submetered. (1991
Code § 18-113)
9-3A-5: PARALLEL GENERATION SERVICE RATE:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 142/269
A. Availability: Electric service, under this schedule, is available to points on the city's existing distribution facilities within the existing service area, to
customers whose total parallel generation facility does not exceed one hundred (100) kilowatts (kW).
B. Applicability:
1. Applicable to residential, small commercial, or large commercial customers who contract for the purchase of capacity and/or energy from the city at
one delivery point and who desire to generate at least a portion of their energy requirements by operating in parallel with the city's system.
Customer's source of parallel generation may include windmills, water wheels, solar generators, geothermal devices, or other renewable resources.
2. This schedule is not applicable to maintenance, backup, interruptible, supplementary, or resale electric service.
C. Character Of Service: Alternating current, sixty (60) hertz, at the voltage and phase of the city's established secondary distribution system at the
location of the customer. The city shall not be required to furnish service, under this schedule, to customers whose 3-phase generator is less than ten
(10) kA in size nor whose single-phase generator is more than fifty (50) kA in size.
D. Net Monthly Bill:
1. The customer shall pay the city for capacity and energy supplied to the customer at the applicable rate for the customer class.
2. The city shall pay the customer for energy supplied the city at the cost of purchased energy per kilowatt hour during the previous month including
fuel cost adjustment.
3. The monthly minimum charge shall be calculated as provided in the tariff applicable to such class of customers, except that if a special transformer
installation is necessary for the benefit of the customer or to protect the quality of service to other customers, such minimum shall not be less than
one dollar ($1.00) per kA of the required transformer capacity. The city will credit the customer's account monthly for energy received from customer.
E. Payment: Monthly bills will be rendered net after deduction for energy received, payable within ten (10) days of the date of the bill, and will become
delinquent thereafter. Five percent (5%) shall be added to the net amount on the date the bill becomes delinquent.
F. Additional Terms And Conditions Of Service:
1. Metering: The city will supply, own, and maintain all necessary meters and associated equipment utilized for measuring capacity and energy
delivered to the customer and energy delivered to the city. In addition, for purposes of monitoring customer generation and load, the city may install
at its expense, load research metering. The customer shall supply, at no expense to the city, a suitable location for meters and associated equipment
used for billing and for load research.
2. Interconnection Facilities:
a. The customer shall furnish, install, operate, and maintain in good working order all facilities beyond the city's metering facilities including such
automatic synchronism, control and protective devices, breakers, relays, locks and seals, as shall be designated by the city as being required for
operation of the generator in parallel with the city's system. Interconnection facilities shall be accessible to city personnel at all times.
b. The customer may be required to reimburse the city for any equipment or facilities required as a result of the installation by the customer of
parallel generation equipment.
c. The customer shall furnish plans and drawings of the generation and interconnecting facilities to the city for the city's approval or disapproval prior
to construction of these facilities. The customer shall notify the city prior to the initial energization and startup testing of the customer owned
generator, and the city shall have the right to conduct and/or witness tests.
3. Limiting Production: The city may require the customer to limit the production of electrical energy from the parallel generator to an amount no greater
than the load at the customer's facility of which the generating facility is a part at certain times and as operating conditions may warrant.
4. Proof As Qualified Facility: The city may require the customer to furnish information that the customer is a "qualified facility" as defined by federal
regulations.
5. Compliance With Technical Codes: The facilities of the customer shall equal or exceed the requirements of the national electrical code, the national
electrical safety code, and any municipal, county, or state codes applicable. The city reserves the right to disconnect facilities if safety or operating
stability warrants such disconnect. (1991 Code § 18-115)
9-3A-6: VIOLATION:
If any person, firm or corporation shall violate the provisions of this article, same shall be deemed to constitute an offense, and, upon conviction thereof,
any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (1991 Code § 18-114)
Chapter 4
SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM
9-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the following meanings:
BOD (BIOLOGICAL OXYGEN DEMAND): The quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 143/269
procedures in five (5) days at twenty degrees Celsius (20°C), expressed in milligrams per liter.
mg/l: Milligrams per liter.
SEWAGE: A combination of the water carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, together with such
ground, surface and storm waters as may be present and includes the domestic waste and industrial sewage in any combination.
SUPERINTENDENT: The person designated superintendent of the sewer department by the city council.
SUSPENDED SOLIDS: Solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in, water, sewage or other liquids, and which are removable by
laboratory filtering. (1991 Code § 18-151)
9-4-2: DISCHARGE OF CERTAIN SUBSTANCES:
No person, firm or corporation shall discharge or cause to be discharged into any public sewer any of the following substances:
A. Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas.
B. Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to
injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process or facility (including the aquaculture fish management program), constitute a hazard to humans or
animals, create a public nuisance or create any hazard in the receiving waters of sewage treatment systems.
C. Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5, or causing the pH of the sewage treatment system to rise above 9.5, or having any other corrosive
property capable of causing damage or hazard to processes, structures, equipment and/or personnel of the sewage works.
D. Solid, viscous or liquid substances in quantities or of such size as to cause or be capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other
interference with the proper operation of the sewage works such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags,
feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails, paper products such as dishes, cups, milk
containers, and the like, either whole or ground by garbage grinders, slops, chemical residues, or bulk solids.
E. Any strong acid, iron pickling wastes or concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not.
F. Any unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes which cause the sewage system to be overloaded.
G. Any substance that may pass through the treatment system without being effectively treated or otherwise reduced to acceptable concentrations by
normal treatment methods such that the sewage treatment system effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over the
discharge to the receiving waters.
H. Any waste containing rhenium, strontium or tellurium.
I. Any waters or wastes containing substances in excess of the limits established in section 9-4-3 of this chapter. (1991 Code § 18-152)
9-4-3: LIMITATIONS ON DISCHARGE:
No person, firm or corporation shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following substances, materials, waters or wastes in concentrations,
quantities or rates in excess of those set forth herein:
A. Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) (65°C), or any substance which causes the
temperature of the total sewage lagoon to increase at a rate of ten degrees Fahrenheit (10°F) or more per hour or a combined total increase of plant
influent temperature to one hundred ten degrees Fahrenheit (110°F).
B. Any water or waste containing fats, wax, grease or oil, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred milligrams per liter (100 mg/l) or containing
substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between thirty two degrees (32°) and one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F)
(0° and 65°C).
C. Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and operation of any garbage shredder equipped with a motor of three-fourths (3/4)
horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to review and approval of the sewer superintendent.
D. Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits to be established by the superintendent on a case by case
basis in compliance with and after consultation with the appropriate regulatory agencies.
E. Any substance with a BOD or suspended solids concentration in excess of three hundred milligrams per liter (300 mg/l) except that, upon receipt of a
written application and establishment of appropriate charges, the superintendent may, if the sewage works has sufficient unused or uncommitted
capacity, authorize the discharge of wastes containing BOD and/or suspended solids concentrations in excess of three hundred milligrams per liter
(300 mg/l) each.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=987 144/269
F. Any waters or wastes with total dissolved solids concentrations greater than three thousand milligrams per liter (3,000 mg/l), plus the dissolved solids, in
the city water supply.
G. Any waters or wastes containing excessive discoloration or causing excess discoloration of the effluent, including, but not limited to, dye wastes and
vegetable tanning solutions.
H. Any waters, wastes or other substances containing one or more of the following constituents in excess of the concentrations listed:

9-4-4: ABATEMENT AND REFUSAL OF SERVICE:
Violation of this chapter is declared to constitute a public nuisance, which may be abated by severance of the offender from the city sewer system. No
building permit or other license of any nature shall be issued by the city to any person, firm or corporation when it appears that the issuance of the same
will result in a violation of this chapter, nor shall such an offender be permitted to use water obtained from the city. (1991 Code § 18-154)
9-4-5: WASTEWATER RATES AND CHARGES:
A. Authority; Rate Determination And Adjustment:
1. Authority: The city of Skiatook and the Skiatook public works authority shall be the sole determining authority for attachment to the wastewater
collection system and may prescribe any additional requirements and inspections as necessary for the health, safety, welfare and proper operation of
the wastewater system.
2. Basis For Rates: Wastewater rates shall be based on the metered water supplied by all sources for each wastewater connection. (Ord. 2008-05, 1-
29-2008)
3. Annual Rate Adjustment: All rates for each category of use will increase by the lesser of the social security administration cost of living adjustment
(COLA) or one and five-tenths percent (1.5%) annually on each subsequent January 1 beginning January 1, 2017, and each January 1 thereafter
until amended or repealed.
